title: The Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy
subTitle: Oh, Lord, won't you let me learn to drive in a Mercedes-Benz?
promoTeaserSmall: Oh, Lord, won't you let me learn to drive in a Mercedes-Benz?
promoTeaser: Oh, Lord, won't you let me learn to drive in a Mercedes-Benz?
metaDescription: The Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy: Oh, Lord, won't you let me learn to drive in a Mercedes-Benz? Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Your teenager may want to drive a Mercedes-Benz, but chances are you would like him or her to practice on something a little more….economical. However, the safety and driver assistance features of the modern Mercedes can’t be denied, and I know if I were suddenly wealthy, I wouldn’t sniff at making every one of my young adults the present of such a car.

That’s why I was interested to see that Mercedes-Benz USA has its own Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy. It’s intended to help teens “develop key decision-making skills…and create safer and more responsible drivers for life.” Sounds good to me, especially since teens are four times more likely to have a serious accident in their first year of driving. There’s a second point to the school, which is to educate parents as coaches for their teenage drivers.

The academy also addresses an interesting safety issue: many teenagers are waiting until they turn eighteen to start driving these days. That’s because Graduated Driver’s License (GDL) laws have rolled out all over the country, requiring teenagers to go through a gradual process from the learner’s permit to a restricted license at sixteen and on to full driving privileges over a period of years.

You’d think this would increase safety on the roads, but there’s a trend of people waiting to turn eighteen and taking the driver’s test, at which time they get full privileges immediately. The Mercedes program is intended to improve skills for those people as well as for drivers of all ages. I’m sure I could learn a few things from this school.

The Academy uses a range of Mercedes-Benz vehicles, each equipped with dual brake controls and dual rearview mirrors in the time-honored driving school style. Only one student is in the car at a time. A full program for the teenage learner costs $1,390—pricier than a traditional driving school, but a relative bargain considering that it includes fifteen hours of online modules, ten hours of classroom work, and sixteen hours of lessons behind the wheel, with complimentary pickup and dropoff.

Perhaps the most tempting of all is the Manual Transmission workshop. I learned to drive a stick in a rented Peugeot subcompact; how about you? At the Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy, manual-transmission learners are behind the wheel of an SLK250 roadster. A two-hour lesson is $230. There’s also a six-hour package ($660) and a ten-hour, five-lesson package for $1,050. This one is for already-licensed drivers or graduates of the academy’s regular program.
So let’s go!

Not so fast (so to speak). Like so many desirable things, the Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy is only in California. The first Mercedes driving school opened in 2011 in Los Angeles, there are programs available in Orange County, and a new fully fledged driving school opened in January in San Diego. There are also Mercedes-Benz Driving Academies in Germany, Canada, the U.K., the Netherlands, and China.

Mercedes-Benz is also offering free parent/teen workshops through schools and dealerships. Check the Driving Academy website for details on this and other programs.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Have you ever played a game called Forza Motorsport? Now in its fifth edition, the game lets you customize, collect, and virtually drive some of the most exciting cars in the world. You have to think that a lot of the gamers would choose that fetish tuner car, the Honda Civic Si. And you're right: players have downloaded more than a million Honda accessories through their relationship with this game.

So it's logical that Honda would come up with a tie-in promotion. Players were invited to design a Civic Si within the game and enter it into a contest. The gamers themselves voted and chose a winner. Okay, can you picture the car-crazed teenage boy (or middle-aged dreamer) who won? Guess again.

Tiffany Labedz won. That's right, I said it, a girl. She is an avid player of Forza Motorsport 4, saw a popup for the contest, and entered it. One look at her customized Civic Si, which I got to see in person at the Chicago Auto Show, and you understand why her car was chosen out of 170 entries.

Tom Peyton of Honda told me a little about the rationale for the contest. "We understand that the gamers are a point of entry for getting into the actual vehicles," he said. "We're trying to get people to have an affinity for our products," with the idea that they'll buy a real one when the time comes. "People have a huge emotional relationship with the cars" in Forza Motorsport, he explained.
One look at her customized Civic Si, which I got to see in person at the Chicago Auto Show, and you understand why her car was chosen.
That makes sense to me, as a northern Michigander who has spent many hours listening to the Chevy truck and Ford truck guys sitting in bars arguing over why the brand they own is better.

And it clearly makes sense to Tiffany. She lives in Mesa, Arizona, where she works for U-Haul. I asked her, "Do you find that you're a little lost in this whole boy world?" She said her best friend is a gamer, too, and she was extremely articulate about her reasons for liking Forza Motorsport, including the fact that you can add realistic options onto the car and customize the interiors. She even knows people who have taken the game further and actually gone out and test driven the cars they enjoyed most in the game.

Other than the Honda Civic Si, Tiffany has driven a Cadillac CTS during game play. I asked her, "Can you tell the difference from one car to the other in the game?" She says you can. She and others of her ilk will enjoy a new Honda Legends Car Pack for the newly released Forza Motorsport 5, which includes the 2014 Civic Si, the 1984 Mugen CRX, and the 1994 Prelude. The game is only playable on the also newly released Xbox One gaming system.

The Chicago Auto Show appearance must have been a fun perk for Tiffany, and she also won prizes including an Xbox gift card and a steering wheel for gaming, but she doesn't get to drive her Honda Civic Si away. The car will continue on a publicity tour without her.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The first crazy thing that happened on our trip to the Westminster Kennel Club's 138th annual dog show was yesterday. We came down in the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter to get the lay of the land and were able to find parking on the roof, which is like a miracle. We only had to walk a few steps to an escalator, go straight down, and we were in and walking around.

This morning, entrants could bring their dogs in starting at 5:30 a.m., and people line up to come in at that hour. Well, we thought we'd leave for the show at 8:00 a.m. instead, but we found out the roof parking had been filled by 6:30 a.m. My husband, Tim, dropped us off. We brought everything in while Tim made friends with the parking guys on the roof. So, the minute a space opened, they called his cell phone, and he went up and parked on the roof.

Our handler, Kelly Leonard, knows about half the people here at Westminster. A lot of her friends have come. I've never met them, but they know who Bob is, which is cute. There is fierce competition here. The #1 Chesapeake in the country from last year is here and being handled by a woman who has won Best in Show two different times, not with Chesapeake Bay retrievers like Bob, but she's very well known among the judges. I knew all the top dogs would be here, and they are really spectacular-looking.
Bob and I are just happy to be here. He has let a lot of kids pet him, and he loves being with people, although we're keeping him close in his cage until showtime.

We walked around a little and looked in at Ring 8 just in time to see our friend Mark Bettis, one of the top handlers in the country, watch his Flat-Coated retriever from ringside. His dog won among twenty-eight entries. Everyone around him was crying and hugging him. He's a real tough guy, but he was in tears, too. Mark is a great friend who has shown Bob once or twice for fun.
The top five breeds entered at Westminster this year are Labrador retriever (76 entries), Golden retriever (58), French bulldog (52), Rhodesian ridgeback (46), and Australian shepherd (44).
What kind of chance did Bob have as one of twenty Chesapeake Bay retrievers entered at Westminster?

In his favor, he finished eighth in the country last year despite not competing in many dog shows. We're not sure what his ranking is this year. However, we do know that he is at his peak age and condition, and he won his first four shows of the year, all four of which had an unusually large number of Chesapeakes in the ring, and a third place in the Sporting group.

Against him? We’re not breeders, we’re not professional handlers, and we don’t advertise regularly in dog magazines that judges read. We’re going because we love dogs and it’s great fun to see the top dogs in the country in every single breed in one place for two days. And because we’ve been watching it on TV virtually all of our lives. It’s just cool to be here.

So how did Bob do? He did make the cut among Chesapeakes, but in the end he did not place. But did we have fun? I did! My husband, Tim, did! Handler Kelly did (and thank you so much, Kelly, for handling him so beautifully in the ring). And Bob? His bait was sliced-up steak from last night's dinner. He was in ecstasy.

Now we're back in the Sprinter and on our way out of New York City, headed for I-80, then across Pennsylvania headed for home. Bob is sound asleep in the back. We'll have video of our adventure here soon.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: Great works of art and design are ageless, but the work is also a reflection of the era in which it was created. In 2010, the global auto industry was in a precarious place, still reeling from the economic crises that rattled car culture to its core. The demand for change was at its height. The question of how future drivers would interact and use their cars was paramount in the media, as car companies were under pressure to evolve. New fuel sources and car sharing became viable topics discussed by the mainstream media. That spring, BMW announced that the artist Jeff Koons would introduce the seventeenth car in the BMW Art Car Series. There were only seventeen made in the thirty-five years since Alexander Calder created the first car collaboration in 1975. The art cars are part of the BMW Museum’s permanent collection and have been widely exhibited.
When the Koons-BMW partnership was announced, Koons revealed the conceptual nature of his car: kinetic energy. Think “razzle dazzle” and “Christmas tree lights."

When the Koons-BMW partnership was announced, Koons revealed the conceptual nature of his car: kinetic energy. Think “razzle dazzle” and “Christmas tree lights,” as he later described the crisp bursts of red, yellow, black, and blue stripes on the M3. The Koons car made a joyful statement in a pensive era. The car as we know it was still alive.

The ideas surrounding the Koons car seem to bear significant weight three years later as the car made its American debut at Art Basel in Miami, Florida, this December. The setting provided an entirely different context from the 24 Hours of Le Mans, where the Koons car raced in 2010. At Art Basel, it was surrounded by thousands of works of art from contemporary artists that transform the city of Miami into a week-long art capital of ideas and imagery.

The BMW Art Car series has serious roots in contemporary art. Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, and Robert Rauschenberg created art cars that solidified the blueprint for a series that encapsulated serious works of car art. In 2007, Olaffur Eliason made the sixteenth art car into a transformed work of steel and ice, wildly bending the scope of what the art car could be as he examined the resources it takes to make a car. Koons chose to return to a more functional car creation and paid homage to the Warhol with his creation, drawing cues from Warhol’s motorsports aesthetic. His car, too, would race, he asserted when the design was announced.

Koons reflected on the car at the Miami unveiling orchestrated by BMW. He spoke about some of his experiments that led to the final design. “I looked at images of novas exploding and how energy repels against something,” he said. Model Karolína Kurková assisted Koons in the unveiling. Thomas Girst, who heads up BMW Cultural Communications and is also an art scholar, was there on behalf of BMW.
Koons chose to return to the functional with his art car creation, drawing cues from Warhol’s motorsports aesthetic. His car, too, would race, he asserted.

Girst and Koons interacted frequently during the six-month design process, during which Koons worked on the car. “Koons pays homage to Warhol and Lichtenstein, but he is an artist of this time, using methods of the moment,” said Girst. “Koons made the car in the year that energy was discussed at the height of the economic recession, when the future of the car was precarious, and the car shows the possibilities.”

While the current climate has shifted to more banner times for car companies, the discussion about what’s coming in energy has not. The future is still up for grabs. One thing is certain: the art car is not a dead conversation. “With Jeff, it came it around full circle. It tells you that the art car is continuing. It went racing again at the 24 Hours of Le Mans,” said Girst.

The Koons car acts as a bridge between two eras in thinking about the relationship between cars, technology, and energy. During the first era of art cars, the the world was facing its first full-blown fuel crisis, which ended the same year Warhol made his #79 art car. It’s ironic that the Koons car makes it American debut the same year as the BMW officially launched its sustainable driven i brand—a decidedly more technical discussion about energy and mobility. Or perhaps it’s an image that will become more reflective of an era through the lens of time and the eye of one of its most prominent artists. “He is a very tough act to follow,” said Girst.

Three years after the fact, the Koons car makes a statement about what it means to move forward.

title: 4 Scooters to Try
subTitle: Dolce vita motoring at popular prices. If we're showing you scooters, can spring be far behind?
promoTeaserSmall: Dolce vita motoring at popular prices. If we're showing you scooters, can spring be far behind?
promoTeaser: Dolce vita motoring at popular prices. If we're showing you scooters, can spring be far behind?
metaDescription: 4 Scooters to Try

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: Catering to urban riders who are more concerned with pragmatism than with puffery, scooters aren’t just a fun way to get around. They’re easier to ride and less intimidating than motorcycles. Having no-muss-no-fuss automatic transmissions and step-through, rather than swing-a-leg-over, designs that let the fairer sex dress like sophisticates rather than gearheads, they’re also less expensive to buy and to operate.
Scooters start at a mere $2,000 and boast fuel economy figures that are likely to inspire a double take: 100-plus mpg.

While the average U.S. passenger car costs about $30,000 and chugs along at 23 mpg, and a typical motorcycle stands at a slightly improved $14,000 and 50 mpg, scooters start at a mere $2,000 and boast fuel economy figures that are likely to inspire a double take: 100-plus mpg.

Available in a surprising array of sizes and styles, ranging from 50cc college campus runabouts to 650s that can pack an extra person and even luggage for a cross-country trip, it’s no surprise that scooters are so popular among women. So let me walk you through a handful of models to get started.

Vespa LX ($3,399+)

The gold standard of scooters, Vespa is the brand that birthed the whole concept back in 1946. In the years since, its iconic Italian style has barely changed. It is the only scooter with a body built from a single sheet of stainless steel rather than a tubular frame covered with plastic. Available in a palette of classic colors, including mint green, the Vespa LX 50 gets 85 mpg and has a top speed of 39 mph, as well as a disc brake on its front wheel to help it stop more effectively. Under-seat storage can accommodate a half helmet. The LX is also available with a larger 150cc engine, which jacks up its top speed to 59 mph and its price to $4,599.

Genuine Scooter Co. Buddy ($1,999+)

It’s funny that a bike looking so shamelessly similar to something else—Vespa—calls itself Genuine, but the twelve-year-old Chicago-based scooter maker has distinguished itself with one of the top-selling scooters in the United States, the Genuine Scooter Co. Buddy. Coupling vintage style with modern technology, its Buddy model offers modern conveniences such as a twelve-volt cell phone/iPod charger. It’s available in a range of perky colors and increasingly peppy engine sizes, from a 50 cc (with a starting price of $1,999 and top speed of 30 mph) to a 125 cc ($2,799 and 50 mph top speed) and 170 cc ($3,349 and 55 mph). Think Vespa, only the Buddy is made in Taiwan and costs about half the price.

Honda Ruckus ($2,649)

If attention is what you want, you’re likely to get it on board the Honda Ruckus. One of the more eye-catching scooters on the market, the Ruckus is a so-called “naked” because the bodywork is missing and the frame is exposed. In Honda’s home country, scooterists were ripping the body panels off their scooters to make them look more radical, so the Japanese company cut to the chase and did it for them. Powered with a 49-cc single-cylinder engine and weighing just 194 pounds, the Ruckus’s biggest strength is its style and its fuel economy, which Honda estimates at 114 mpg.

Yamaha Zuma ($2,590+)

Yamaha is best known for sport bikes that can go 100 mph in first gear, but the Japanese company imports some of that technology to the Yamaha Zuma scooter, which can be had as both a 50 cc ($2,590) and a 125 cc ($3,390). The Zuma’s windswept body work and twin headlamps give it a a more sporty, modern style that also plays out under the hood. Its tires are wider than most scooters, and they’re stopped with a front disc brake painted racy red. Under-seat storage can even hold a sport biker-esque full-face helmet.

pageElements.text:
2014 Nissan Altima 2.5 SL

Price: $28,550 (base price of this model, including destination)
$30,625 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 182 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable (CVT)
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/38 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated leather-wrapped steering wheel
Option I can’t live without: Lane departure warning (part of $1,090 Technology package)
Notable standard features on this model: Easy Fill Tire Alert, remote start
Notable options on this model: Blind spot warning, land departure warning, moving object detection, and a navigation system, all included in the $1,090 Technology package; Moonroof ($800)
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Toyota Camry

I associate Nissan with slightly quirky design—think Cube, Juke, Leaf, and even Murano. But, when it comes to the Altima, Nissan has always leaned toward a more conservative style. It is number three in the jam-packed mid-size-sedan segment in sales behind the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord, and it did not get to this lofty position by taking risks.

In 2013 the Altima was completely redesigned. It achieved a modern appearance without straying far from its predecessor. A curving character line flows from the front headlight and along the side, leading nicely into the small spoiler on the rear. The trapezoidal grille that is integrated with the standard halogen headlights delivers a slightly aggressive look to the front. It is more Miss Congeniality than Miss Mid-Size Sedan, but really, with whom would you rather spend the day?

I drove the 2.5-liter four-cylinder version and stayed mostly to city driving. I found the experience sportier than I had anticipated. There was plenty of power, and the car delivered adequate acceleration for passing when I did take a quick highway drive. For buyers who want an even sportier family sedan, there is also a 3.5-liter with a V-6 that includes paddle shifters. As a fan of paddle shifters, I vote for the V-6, but if fuel economy is paramount in your decision stick with the four-cylinder, since the V-6 gets 22 mpg in town and 31 mpg on the highway, which compares unfavorably with the four-cylinder's 27/38 mpg. Both engines are paired with a continuously variable transmission that helps achieve the impressive mpg numbers, but it does make for a louder ride.

Warning to coupe buyers: Nissan is no longer offering the coupe version. In fact the Honda Accord is your only coupe choice, unless you jump up to the premium category. Some buyers whose main desire is for a mid-size coupe may opt to move into the muscle car category and take a look at the Chevrolet Camaro or the Ford Mustang.

There are three available trim levels, the S, the SV, and the top-of-the-line SL, each of which can be paired with either engine. It is worth mentioning that every Altima comes with push-button start and a clever feature called Easy Fill Tire Alert. This feature is perfect for me (and anyone who's not mechanical): you can just start adding air to your tires, and when you achieve the proper pressure the horn beeps. Genius.

During the snowy week when we tested the Altima, I was glad to have the SL, which comes standard with a triumvirate of heated features: front seats, steering wheel, and outside mirrors. To put the icing on the cake and take the ice off your windshield, the SL comes standard with remote start—cue the angels singing. Had the Altima arrived in Los Angeles for a drive the same week, I might have overlooked these details and bestowed my praise instead on the virtues of the LED taillights, the eight-way power driver's seat (with power lumbar), or the premium Bose sound system.

We opted to add a moonroof for $800, carpeted floor and trunk mats for $185, and the Technology package for $1,090. This reasonably priced package includes navigation, blind spot warning, lane departure warning, and moving object detection that up the safety features of this model and to me are a must.

If safety is guiding your decision, you will need to step up to an SV or SL. In either version, the Technology package is an option and a backup camera is standard. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) gave the Altima the top five stars overall and five stars each for front and side crash protection. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety rated it Good, the IIHS's best rating, in three crash tests: offset front (moderate overlap), side impact, and roof strength. In the new small-overlap front test, the Altima earned the second best Acceptable rating.

The interior of the Altima follows the same conservative design cues as the exterior. The SL has wood-tone trim that left me unimpressed, but the NissanConnect that integrates apps such as Pandora gets my nod. The hands-free texting is a good idea in theory, but in my opinion a step too far. Please wait until you are not responsible for piloting a 3,200-pound vehicle down the road to send your text messages.

The cabin is generally roomy, but the rear headroom may have your taller passengers calling foul. The 4.0-inch LCD screen for driver information is situated between the speedometer and the tachometer. The seats were inspired by research done by NASA on "zero gravity" seats, and the SL version is leather. These seats are among the most comfortable seats my behind has ever experienced, especially at this price. All trim levels have a 60/40 rear seat that affords a wide pass-through to the trunk.

The Verdict:

If you are in the market for a mid-size sedan, the fuel economy of the Altima demands your attention. The upscale interior at a fraction of the cost of a premium-price sedan may be enough to entice you to plunk down the modest cost of the Altima. If economy or luxury don’t win you over, the NASA-inspired seats may push you over the edge if you are a long-distance driver. Your tush will thank you.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: You can't tell by looking at the Altima how pleasant it is to drive. Even with the four-cylinder engine, it has enough of everything: power, spirit, and comfort. Kudos to Nissan for getting 38 highway miles per gallon out of a sedan that doesn't feel like a compromise. It explains why it's a strong seller in the ultracompetitive mid-size segment. You can get a nicely equipped Altima for under $25,000, but I would strongly recommend getting the upper trim levels to be eligible for the Technology package, which contains many of the latest safety features for a reasonable $1,090.

Having said that, if I were buying a Nissan, I might want to go with some of the more colorful ones, such as the Juke or even the Leaf. It would be hard for me to sail past those at the dealership in favor of the rather bland Altima, but it just might be the right thing to do.

title: 5 Tips from Winter Driving School
subTitle: My day at Bridgestone's school showed me the cold, hard facts about driving well in ice and snow.

metaDescription: 5 Tips from Winter Driving School: My day at Bridgestone's school showed me the cold, hard facts about driving well in ice and snow. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: Even in years that haven’t experienced a Polar Vortex, ten percent of U.S. vehicle crashes are due to snow, sleet, ice, and slush, according to the Department of Transportation. That’s a lot of slipping, sliding, and insurance claims that might be avoided if more drivers knew how to operate their vehicles when the weather turns.

As a general rule, if you live in a part of the country where it snows and you can see your breath, you should have winter tires that offer more grip when the going gets slippery. A set of winter tires lasts about four winter seasons and will set the average driver back about $1,000, but the payback is potentially significant. A driver could pay that much in a deductible if she lost control of her car and cracked a fender. Or worse.
If you live in a part of the country where it snows and you can see your breath, you should have winter tires that offer more grip when the going gets slippery.

I have just been schooled in the benefits of winter tires at the Bridgestone Winter Driving School in Steamboat Springs, Colorado, where I spent a half day wheeling various Lexus vehicles around two snow-packed tracks, each with multiple types of turns and inconsistent surfaces. Designed to improve drivers’ inclement weather skills while simultaneously promoting the use of winterized wheels, regardless of what brand is stamped in the rubber, the school starts at $495 for a half day. One- and two-day schools are also available with passenger's-seat coaching in the techniques that will keep a car where it belongs: on the road.
After that eye-opening experience, I made this list of five techniques to remember when the roads are coated with snow:

1. Slow down.

Speed is not your friend when a road is coated with snow, slush, ice, or even worse—a combination of all three. Lighten up your lead foot, and you’ll be rewarded with more control.

2. Avert your eyes from that hulking snowbank.

In fact, keep your eyes off any other object you’d like to avoid. The surest way to make unwanted contact with a ditch or another driver’s bumper is to fixate on it. Look where you want to go, and the car is more likely to do the same.

3. A little steering goes a long way.

When you’re steered into a turn and the car still isn’t going where you’d like, the temptation is to steer in the same direction even more. The opposite action is needed. Steer less when entering a turn. And if you’ve already steered too much, unwind the wheel slightly to straighten out the car and try steering again—gently.

4. Don’t attempt to steer when accelerating or braking.

In slick conditions, steering, accelerating, and braking should be separate actions. Brake and accelerate in a straight line, and keep your foot off the pedals entirely when turning.

5. No sudden moves.

It might work on dry pavement, but sudden movements, such as manhandling the steering wheel or abruptly pressing the brake and accelerator pedals, are magnified by snow or ice. Handle the car as if it was a newborn baby, and you’re less likely to fishtail or spin out.

title: Bruce Weber's Detroit
subTitle: Detroit-themed company Shinola is behind a brilliant set of images by the famous photographer.
promoTeaserSmall: Detroit-themed company Shinola is behind a brilliant set of images by the famous photographer.
promoTeaser: Detroit-themed company Shinola is behind a brilliant set of images by the famous photographer.
metaDescription: Bruce Weber's Detroit: Detroit-themed company Shinola is behind this brilliant set of images by the famous photographer. Read our thoughts about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: This is not the best time of year for Detroit’s closeup. The gray snow by the side of the road calls for hibernation, not glamour shots. So this is an especially nice time of year to see the photography of Bruce Weber, who has teamed with high-end watch and bicycle maker Shinola on a set of photos and videos to communicate the beauty of Detroit and its people.
These images and videos, titled “The Spirit of Detroit,” are up on the Shinola website now.
Video from Shinola's YouTube channel

If you’ve never heard Bruce Weber’s name, you’ve probably seen his work in places like Vanity Fair and Vogue magazines and the Abercrombie & Fitch store. You might also recognize blond model Carolyn Murphy, brought in to be part of the Detroit photos because she represents “the independent spirit of the American tomboy.”
We choose to enjoy these photos, hoping they help more people around the world think of Detroit as the vibrant, viable city it is.

These images are gorgeous, but are they an authentic picture of the struggling metropolis that is Detroit? Well, here's the thing. As the automakers return to their former greatness, buildings are repurposed, and the city in general begins to rise from the ashes, it’s important, we think, to avoid an “us versus them” mentality that holds Detroit back. So we choose to enjoy these photos, hoping they help more people around the world think of Detroit as the vibrant, viable city it is.

I asked young Detroit entrepreneur and grassroots change agent Andy Didorosi, who is the guy behind the nascent Detroit Bus Company and the Thunderdrome racing series, what he thinks about the Shinola/Bruce Weber photo project. He offered an incisive commentary on the project that's worth reading:

"Shinola is one very carefully executed marketing campaign.
While it's presented like a story of a die-hard Detroit-based company, it's really more similar to Astroturf.

"But the takeaway is: Let them spend their money. Let them hire Detroiters. Not everyone is going to be authentically local and we should be proud that the allure of the history of Detroit is strong enough to attract capital of that scale.
We're certainly not at the point—nor should we ever strive to be—where we can turn people away from taking part simply because they weren't born or raised here. And that goes for both brands and people.
"Is it marketing? Totally. Is it constructed? Every bit. But they're marketing us to the rest of the world and they're doing a damn good job of it."
The Bruce Weber videos and photography perfectly sum up the warmth I feel for Detroit, my birth city. - Jean

Setting aside all philosophical marketing arguments, Jean loves Shinola's products enough to have bought three different Shinola watches (The Runwell, The Gomelsky, and The Birdy) with leather straps made by Hadley-Roma in Largo, Florida; a set of small linen notebooks (made by historic Edwards Brothers Malloy in Ann Arbor); and a gorgeous leather envelope for her iPad Mini made by craftsmen in Missouri from hides tanned by a 100-plus-year-old Chicago company, Horween. She explains: “I love my watches, I love the thickness and richness of my iPad cover, and I love to use the little notebooks. The specialness is not only in knowing where each one came from, but in actually knowing the name of the people who made each of the Shinola pieces I bought.

“I’ve gotten over the fact that the company is owned and led by people who aren’t Detroiters, but who are using Detroit to give themselves an air of urban authenticity. In the end, they are creating jobs and they’re producing desirable, fashionable products, and they’ve stamped MADE IN DETROIT on them. I like that very much. The Bruce Weber videos and photography perfectly sum up the warmth I feel for Detroit, my birth city.”

title: Winter Maintenance: 4 Musts
promoTeaserSmall: In any season, but especially during the cold months, keep these four items in working order.
promoTeaser: In any season, but especially during the cold months, keep these four items in working order.
metaDescription: Winter Maintenance: 4 Musts. Four things you need to watch on your car so it gets you to spring. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Back in the fall you equipped yourself for winter with that long down coat, texting gloves, and an infinity scarf, but how about your car? To make sure all the winter car prep bases are covered we asked Michael Calkins, the manager of technical services at AAA’s national office, to run down the four most important maintenance considerations for safe winter driving.

1. Tires

Maintaining proper traction is a challenge in winter conditions, so if you live where there is heavy snow, consider purchasing snow tires for the season. If you're counting on all-season tires to get you through, they won't be as useful if you have let the tread wear down. “If any tire has less than 3/32 inch of tread,” cautions Calkins, “it should be replaced.” Also, tire pressure drops along with temperatures, so make sure yours are properly inflated. Appropriate PSI for your tires can be found on the driver’s door frame, or check your owner's manual.

2. Battery

Batteries become less efficient with colder temperatures so if your charge wasn’t optimal in the first place you may have trouble starting the car once the winter chill begins in earnest. Calkins recommends having your car’s starting system and battery charge tested to make sure you won’t get caught out in the cold.

3. Brakes

On icy roads, we put an almost unreasonable amount of faith in our brakes. Give yours a fighting chance by having them checked. Calkins reminds us, “Brakes that tend to grab or pull on dry roads are likely to lock on ice or snow-covered pavement, resulting in a loss of stopping power and/or steering control.” So, if you had questions about your brakes in the summer, don’t bet on them getting you safely through the winter months.

4. Wipers

Visibility is hard enough when slush covers the lane paint and also splatters the windshield, so worn out wipers will just make the whole mess worse. If your wipers are streaking and missing sections of the glass they should be replaced. In a long snow season Calkins says to consider winter wipers like the new "beam" type designed to discourage ice and snow buildup. Remember to use an antifreeze washer fluid and keep some extra handy. Speaking of visibility, don’t forget to clear off your car’s head- and taillights so you can see, and be seen, during winter’s dreary days and dark nights.
Once you’ve gotten the car in good working order, throw a well-stocked Winter Emergency Kit in the back, and a shovel, since at some point in all our lives there’s a snowbank with our name on it.

subTitle: 600,000 riders take New York taxis each day. Few get to do what I did: drive one on a road trip!

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Photography by Susan Campbell

When you picture traffic on the streets of New York City, it's unthinkable not to imagine yellow taxis. It's really true that 600,000 people a day ride in taxicabs in New York. But how many people get to drive them? So I was very excited to have the opportunity to take the brand-new Taxi of Tomorrow, the Nissan NV200, from the Chicago Auto Show back to Ann Arbor. That's about a 250-mile drive.

The best part of the deal was that our cab had all of the New York City taxi graphics, including the flat rate to John F. Kennedy International Airport (FYI: the flat fare is $52 between Manhattan and JFK, plus any tolls). I have ridden in taxis in many cities and even in a few different countries, but I have never driven one. My test drive would differ from most cabbies’, since I would rack up all those miles without stopping to pick up a new passenger.

But first, a little history about this taxicab that isn't shaped like a traditional cab: The Ford Crown Victoria,  previously the cab of choice, went out of production in 2011. That left a spot wide open for a new darling in the Big Apple. The purpose-built Nissan 200NV won a Taxi of Tomorrow design competition in 2011 to become New York City's exclusive taxi provider for a decade, and Nissan was set to bank some serious coin. Unfortunately, from the moment they stepped off the podium, the lawsuits started to be filed. First up was the United Spinal Association, followed by fleet owners, and then the powerful taxi lobby. As of today, the NV200 is an approved New York City taxi, but it's far from the exclusive choice.
Nevertheless, Nissan is looking to win over the fleet owners and the taxi community as a whole to prove that the NV200 really is the Taxi of Tomorrow.
A typical New York City cab travels approximately 70,000 miles per year and is on average 3.3 years old.

Photographer Susan Campbell and I received a quick debriefing on the unique attributes of the Nissan taxi before we hit the road. The biggest news is its partition between the driver and the back seat. It's factory installed, which Nissan calls a first. Nissan is also proud to state that this is the only taxi to have been crash tested with the partition in place. Nissan's Travis Parman told me that the NV200 taxi was tested at "an external facility and was verified to comply with applicable U.S. federal motor vehicle safety standards with the partition installed."

For both passenger and driver safety, the partition is made out of bullet-resistant plastic. I have been in many taxis that I assure you would not have passed a crash test, and I would be pleased to have a thick piece of plastic between the driver and me. The NV200 taxi has roof-mounted curtain supplemental air bags for side impact and rollover protection; those rear passengers who choose not to buckle receive no extra padding from the partition. So, remember, the same physics apply to taxis as to a normal passenger car, and buckle up!

Antimicrobial Vinyl: Nice Touch

A typical New York City cab travels approximately 70,000 miles per year and is on average 3.3 years old. This taxi was obviously spanking new, so it did not suffer from ground-in dirt and the stench that I automatically associate with cabs. But Nissan has added a few features to stave off the odors and germs that hover inside a cab. The rear seats are an antimicrobial vinyl that can easily be wiped off, and there's an active carbon material in the headliner. It is difficult to tell how effective these weapons will be against the nauseous overserved or other less than clean passengers, but hats off to Nissan for giving it more than an air freshener hanging on the rearview mirror.

Points of Passenger Control

The passenger also has control over the HVAC, interior lighting, two USB plugs, and a twelve-volt outlet. I am constantly running my phone in the red zone, so I give another point to the NV200 from a passenger's perspective. Possibly the best feature for the rider is the legroom. It is positively roomy for three passengers, and I am sure there will be late-night riders cramming a half-dozen friends into the sliding side doors (although it would be illegal to transport more people than seatbelts can hold). Luckily, there is a small sliding window in both doors to give a little extra air into the cabin.

Chicago from Inside an NYC Cab

As we tooled around the Windy City, we realized the very best feature of the NV200 was the view out the giant moonroof. Passengers can see the tops of the skyscrapers without smashing their heads against the side windows.

Having never piloted a taxi, I found it a bit challenging to weave in and out of the bustling Chicago traffic, but I felt it was important to get a feel for how the NV200 would navigate in its natural habitat before we took it on the relatively calm highway between Chicago and home. I would assume a driver would rip out the tiny rearview mirror and install an aftermarket mirror that would increase the rear perspective, but that being said, the curving edge of the partition adds an odd distortion that could be annoying if you spent nine and a half hours behind the wheel, as the average NYC taxi driver does each day.
In Chicago, we received a few hails and lots of attention as we tooled around taking photos through the moonroof. The NYC graphics confused more than one pedestrian.

In Chicago, we received a few hails and lots of attention as we tooled around taking photos through the moonroof. The NYC graphics confused more than one pedestrian. We pulled over to set the navigation for home and received a call from a stranded colleague seeking a ride home from the auto show. Well, why not? We punched in the address of Union Station, where his train was being delayed for several hours, and took the detour to save the day and selfishly get to actually taxi someone.

As our guest passenger situated himself in the rear, I reminded him to fasten his seatbelt. The NV200's belts have bright yellow accents to remind the passenger to buckle up. Perhaps this will improve New York City’s current 38 percent buckle rate in cabs. We threw his luggage into the absolutely cavernous cargo area and followed the navigation route to I-94, leaving his colleagues in the dust. He claimed to feel bad, but he didn’t really seem too concerned as he settled in for his chauffeur-driven drive.
The NV200's belts have bright yellow accents to remind the passenger to buckle up. Perhaps this will improve New York City’s current 38 percent buckle rate in cabs.

Susan and I chatted away in the front cabin while he acted like a real paying customer; plugging in devices, talking nonstop on his phone, and even pulling out his laptop to tackle a few e-mails. The NV200 does not have a Wi-Fi hotspot, but that is the type of accessory that can easily be added in the aftermarket. He pointed out the built in credit card reader. In New York City, every taxi must accept credit cards, and in fact 55 percent of passengers pay with a card. There is a large monitor in the center of the partition, but Nissan explained that for New York City it was not installed; the taxi companies want to install their own systems. I have not been in a Gotham City cab lately, but I assume you are bombarded with advertising as you are ferried about the city.

How Does It Feel?

The NV200 is front-wheel drive, with a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine mated to a continuously variable transmission (CVT). The relatively small engine size, coupled with the CVT, delivers an acceptable combined 24 mpg in fuel economy. I am confident that the true number dips much lower because of the inherent stop-and-start nature of the taxi lifestyle.

As our guest passenger shared, the ride is slightly bumpy on the highway, especially since the seat is directly over the rear wheels. In reality, the NV200 will spend the majority of its life darting around the city for quick jaunts. It's really meant for passengers who care more about space and cleanliness than about a premium ride experience.

The NV200’s handling is what you would expect from a slightly underpowered small van. The steering felt a tad disconnected but acceptable, and it did not feel top-heavy but actually rather nimble. On the highway I found the road noise quite loud, but I easily drowned it out with a little more volume from the Sirius satellite radio. I was pleased to see that the navigation screen doubles as the monitor for a backup camera.

How Does It Drive?

For the driver, the experience is nothing like the luxury they may remember from their puffy Ford Crown Victoria days, but there are some amenities that should please them. It has a six-way adjustable driver's seat with a manual lumbar control, and it is able to slightly recline. I found it quite comfortable on my ride, but I would have preferred the NASA-inspired seats that have popped up in other Nissan vehicles. Since the average cab is in service for three years and will likely have well over 150,000 miles before it retires, I am thinking that the seat comfort will be greatly reduced as the miles pile on, but that would happen with any seat. And be sure that wooden bead seats will be quickly installed for many. Bluetooth is standard, but note that New York City's laws forbid a driver from using a phone while driving, even hands-free. So rest assured no driver will use this function.

How Cabdrivers Will Use It

Every taxi in New York City has a distress button the driver can push that lights up on the exterior of the cab to alert police or savvy observers that something is amiss in the cab. In the NV200, the button is just left of the steering column and will activate a flashing red 911. It made me think perhaps the passengers deserve a button, too. Agreed?

The maximum shift a NYC cabbie can have is twelve hours. If you are spending half your day in a vehicle, you are going to customize it to make it work for you. The NV200's front passenger's seat folds down to create a flat surface that I imagine many cabdrivers will love. There is no center console, so the cup holders, mirror adjusters, and lighting controls are way down between the seats. I assume the drivers will want to take advantage of that space and get the cup holders up to a more convenient level. The steering-wheel-mounted controls for audio and cruise control are a nice touch, and the intercom can be turned off from either cabin. There is a hearing loop system for the hearing impaired. For the hearing public, the horn is considered low-annoyance, but when you have dozens of taxis honking at random, how can it not be annoying?

Why No Hybrid?

The sticking point for me in understanding how the NV200 was chosen as the Taxi of Tomorrow is the mileage. The current fleet of NYC yellow cabs is 60 percent hybrid-electric, and since this vehicle is not available as a hybrid and in fact only gets a combined 24 mpg, isn’t that a step backward for mankind and pocketbooks as well?

Nissan currently offers a hybrid version in the Asia market called the Serena S-Hybrid. The New York Taxi & Limousine Commission is interested in a hybrid, Nissan's Parman says, but "additional consultation" still has to happen before the wheels are set in motion to bring a hybrid version of the NV200 here as a taxi. Until that time, it doesn’t seem like hybrid buyers are going to want to eat into their profits to make the experience nicer for customers.

The Passenger's Point of View

We swung into the Amtrak parking lot to drop off our guest passenger, a full three hours ahead of his co-workers whom he had abandoned at Union Station. I explained to him that his bill for the ride would arrive in the mail shortly. The next day, he shared with me the story that he will add into his Christmas letter eleven months from now.

"This winter, Amtrak has been about as predictable as Toronto mayor Tom Ford, so a 240-mile fare in the back of a Nissan NV200 taxi seemed like the sure-fire bet. And on a Friday afternoon in February, the ride was most appreciated. The passenger compartment in the new cab is roomy and well appointed, and the big, wide sliding door is a certainly the right solution for a quick pickup in front of Chicago's Union Station. Driver Molly had to just slow down for me to jump in, and away we went. Eastward, ho!

In transit at highway speeds—which admittedly most taxi riders won't experience—the ride is not exactly Checker soft, suffering from highway hop on Michigan's cruel roads, but this Nissan cab is certainly quieter than any Checker ever was and feels solidly built. In my quiet, partitioned-off cabin, I was able to catch up on work as the miles rolled past, making calls and connecting with old friends and associates. Riding home from Chicago in a taxi was a novelty indeed and is now a story I am glad to have. I think driver Molly and co-pilot Susan were fine hosts, though a bit chatty and directionally challenged.

Overall: A welcome ride. Certainly better than Amtrak could do that day. And the fare was affordable. Thanks, Jean Knows Cars."
Actually, thank you, Nissan. Next time I spot a Nissan NV200 taxi, I will certainly hail it so that I can see how it is holding up to the grueling taxi life.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. pageElements.text: IntelliChoice, the automotive value analysis firm, announced its picks for Best Overall Value of the Year (BOVY) awards this week, and the results are interesting, even if they probably won’t surprise you.

Each year, IntelliChoice looks at data from each car model sold to determine the vehicles that have not only low overall ownership costs, but also lower than expected costs compared to similar models. It then picks several cars in each category (convertible, coupe, hatchback, sedan, utility, truck, van, and wagon) for the BOVYs. IntelliChoice also picks overall winners for the best value in a popular and premium vehicle and a popular and premium brand.

Together, Toyota and Lexus swept the four top honors, adding credence to the carmaker’s reputation as a smart buy. Toyota and Lexus were named best overall value in a popular brand and premium brand, respectively. The 2014 Toyota Yaris two-door hatchback was named best overall value for a popular car.
The Lexus RX350 crossover took best overall value for a premium vehicle. Together, Toyota and Lexus won twelve classes, including a sweep of the truck, hatchback, and van categories.

While Japanese carmakers earned many of IntelliChoice’s awards in 2014, German automakers held their own in the premium and performance categories. Audi made a strong showing in the convertible and coupe segments, earning BOVYs for several versions of the Audi R8 supercar and Audi A5 sport coupe.
The brand-new Mercedes-Benz CLA45 AMG was recognized the best value in a premium performance car, earning Mercedes-Benz’s only BOVY award for 2014.
Other awards were garnered by BMW, for the BMW Z4 28i (shown here) and 528i, and the Mini Cooper convertible.

By contrast, only two American-brand vehicles snagged awards. The 2014 Ford Mustang GT was recognized as BOVY for a performance car, while the Chevrolet Tahoe took home honors in the premium full-size utility category.

There’s a lot to consider when buying a car. If you’re looking for a Lamborghini or a Bentley, value probably isn’t as high on your list as style or brand cachet. For the rest of us, though, the BOVY awards can be a valuable tool in the car-buying process. They look beyond sticker price to see how much a car will cost to own, and how it stacks up to its direct competition. If you’re in the market for a new car, take a look at IntelliChoice’s rankings to see if your top choice made the cut.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I went to Bentley’s historic headquarters in Crewe, England, for the first time in my long career as an automotive journalist. I wasn't there to test cars (except for a few exceptional backseats behind a chauffeur). Instead, I was welcome where few have been invited—the back rooms where veneers are mirror matched by hand and finished by skilled artisans, and where large southern German bull hides are scrupulously examined for the slightest flaws (unacceptable!) before a laser cuts pattern pieces dictated by a computer.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/wqFXxH3pZzs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
I was able to take part in some of the hand work, which I found much more interesting than scrapbooking, I must say!
We made a short video before we jumped on the Eurostar for Paris, where we toured Bentley's inaugural furniture collection at the Paris furniture show, Maison et Objet. That video is on its way!

images.caption: Skilled Bentley artisans do make dreams happen in the private workrooms at Crewe.
A fortune in superior quality wood veneers are stored on the premises until they are mirror-matched by hand, cut, layered over soiled wood substrate, formed, finished, and polished to perfection.
Finished veneer trim pieces are examined for flaws.

Leather hides are stretched and imperfections are marked, then scanned by laser and event to a computers the computer arranges pattern pieces and send to the laser cutter which cuts the patterns while avoiding all imperfections.
A day in the company of the talented artisans at Bentley is a fine day, indeed.

pageElements.text: When Ford announced a one-year partnership with Rent the Runway (RTR), I was slightly confused. RTR is a service where members can rent designer dresses and accessories for 90 percent off the retail price. I wondered how the partnership would work. If you purchase a Ford, you drive out of the dealership in a designer gown? Perhaps Ford throws in a free RTR rental or two depending on the vehicle you purchased? Or maybe RTR was consulting on the interior fabrics that would be used in upcoming models?

I attended a press conference at the North American International Auto Show, where Ford senior interior designer Anthony Prozzi, co-founder of RTR Jennifer Fleiss (I don’t believe she is related to Heidi), and Ford’s marketing manager of global cars and crossovers, Amy Marentic, enlightened us on this somewhat odd relationship. They went to great lengths to explain how the two brands are focused on saving their buyers time. Ford has chosen the Fusion as the vehicle portion of the initiative and points out its time-saving features of keyless entry, easy-fill capless gas tank, and park assist.

Prozzi shared his passion for design and talked about how he has been influenced in the interior of the Fusion and more recently the F-150 by the fashion industry. Fleiss shared the time-saving virtues of being able to shop for designer clothing from any device that can connect to the Internet. I left the press conference unclear on why these two companies were forming an alliance.

Once I returned to my office and started to dig through the RTR website, I realized that Ford is brilliant. According to Fleiss, RTR has five million members with an average age of twenty-eight, and a majority of the members hold a college degree. The demographics of these women are enough to give a grown marketing exec heart palpitations.
After foraging through the site, I am hoping to be invited to an event worthy of this Allison Parris dress or this Kate Spade number.

You look through the website and select a dress from one of the 170-plus designers on the RTR roster, and then you order it much as you'd order a movie from Netflix. You choose a guaranteed delivery date, and your dress comes in the mail. You are even sent two sizes of your choice to ensure you get a good fit. You can select four or eight days as the rental period. Then, simply pop it into a postpaid bag and return it. They even dry-clean it for you when they get it back.

Rent the Runway has a social network on its site: customers can post photos of themselves in the dresses and comment about how they fit, so you can imagine the dress on someone other than a model. I found it helpful to see the dresses on the different body styles. But the real genius part for me, is I would not have to look at the dress in my closet for the next twenty years. If you wear a fabulous designer dress to an event, it is unlikely you want to wear it to another event where some of the same people may attend. But who can keep track?

Back to the partnership. What does this mean to you? Beginning this week and running through June, you have a chance to win a Ford Fusion and a $1,000 gift card to RTR. In addition, there will be pop-up events in Los Angeles and New York in the spring where the Fusion will be on display and you can actually try on RTR dresses and accessories.

It is refreshing to see an automaker that understands how important women are to its bottom line. If Ford can get a fraction of these women to consider purchasing a Fusion, someone is going to have earned a promotion.

pageElements.text: The head of Lexus design, Yasuo Kajino, is a beautifully articulate man on the subject of design. We were fortunate to have his simultaneous translator on hand so we could bring you his very specifically chosen words. It worked like this: I asked Kajino-san a question, which was translated as I spoke by Andrew Gillman, who was standing a half step behind him. As Kajino-san answered in Japanese, his translator spoke the words in English into senior editor Molly Jean’s iPhone voice memo, which she was hanging over his shoulder.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/_mtopwrvZwo?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

So, while you are looking at Kajino and me on screen, know that there were three others in close proximity, trying to keep out of one another’s way and off camera.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Few people appreciate or even remember the La Femme, the auto industry’s first attempt to market directly to women. Based on the 1955 Dodge Custom Royal Lancer, it was paradoxical then, and nearly sixty years later,  the few remaining traces aren’t easy to read.

Maybe the result would have been better if this two-door hardtop model hadn’t expressed the worst styling cliches of the 1950s. To begin with, the Royal had too much ornamentation. Its chrome face was an atrocity. The hood scoop was fake, and the diving beltline failed to distract from the body’s ungainly proportions. Stupid little fins were tacked on atop the rear fenders.
Discern for yourself whether the special La Femme trim level aimed at women was a cynical ploy to move some sheetmetal out of showrooms or a genuine effort to create a new market niche.
“Won’t the gals love this?” we can imagine Dodge president W.C. Newberg saying.

“Won’t the gals love this?” we can imagine Dodge president W.C. Newberg saying to vice-president R.C. Somerville and sales manager L.F. Desmond before unveiling the La Femme option. This was in the spring of 1955—the middle of the model year. "Yes, Boss," we can imagine Somerville and Desmond answering.
The La Femme was cloaked in a pink-and-white paint job, but the name Heather Rose was used. To ensure irresistibility, a unique rosebud pattern was chosen for the jacquard-weave upholstery.

Personal accessories—all in pink—were included: a four-button raincoat, rain hat, and umbrella. Additionally, a large and awkwardly shaped purse, very tall and narrow as if for storing nightsticks, contained a compact, a cigarette case, and a lighter.
These extras stowed away in pouches that clung to the backs of the first-row seats.
If the Dodge La Femme website is to be believed, the accessories were widely coveted:  “Unfortunately, many…disappeared before they even reached the dealer showroom."

If the Dodge La Femme website is to be believed, the accessories were widely coveted. “Unfortunately, it seems that many…disappeared before they even reached the dealer showroom,” the site says. (We presume Pinkerton detectives couldn’t track down the pilfered goods.)
One ad supported the La Femme with the slogan, “Now for the first time anywhere, a car glamorously, personally yours.” It promised “every sophisticated touch your heart could desire!”
Another played on the Royal name, saying, “By appointment to Her Majesty...the American Woman.”

We can’t pin down exactly how many examples of the La Femme were sold. Did women demand them and—rare at the time—independently transact the purchases? Did men buy the cars as gifts? A combination of both?

Some 30,500 Custom Royal Lancers were produced in 1955. No figures are broken out for Her Majesty’s favorite trim level, but we imagine dozens of women lining up in Coral Gables alone. After all, the pink handbag in combination with Dodge’s Red Ram V-8 engine represented the new automotive black.
Only twelve surviving examples are listed in the La Femme website's registry, though.
The worst thing Dodge did after the '55 La Femme? When repeating it one more time, in 1956, they deleted the purse.
That’s what we call a pink slip.
