contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pageElements.text: We are stopped at a red light, and an orange L.A. Metro Local bus lurches to our side.  The bus driver draws opens his passenger door and calls out to Richard Pietruska, “That’s beautiful!”  And then Richard and I, in his exotic black on black 1996 Acura NSX, zoom off along the Pacific Coast Highway, the motor’s big purr a more seductive sound than some music.  Richard has driven the car at 110 mph, but we didn’t go quite that fast.

Richard Pietruska is an award-winning sculptor of car-derived artwork like those shown here.  He describes these works as “sort of an automotive fantasy without the wheels.” Richard is also a professor of automotive design at Pasadena’s Art Center College of Design.

I peer into the pristine garage of his Santa Monica home, a few blocks from the beach. Richard also possesses a 2001 Porsche 911 and requires a van for transporting his sculptures, but it’s the 1996 Acura two-door coupe that he loves. He says, “It was just one of those unique cars. It came along and I just happened to have money for another car, so I sold my 300ZX Nissan and moved up to the NSX.
"It’s such a great car to drive.  The interior’s open, the vista’s great, and it sounds good.  And it’s comfortable.  It’s a really amazing car.”

Honda had originally developed the NSX (New Sportscar eXperimental) in the 1980s to compete with Porsche and with the Italians, particularly Ferrari and Lamborghini.  In some ways, the Japanese beat the Europeans at their own game.  And at a lower price point.  It premiered VTEC (Variable Valve Timing/Lift Electronic Control), and its high-strength aluminum monocoque construction made it hundreds of pounds lighter than other athletic sports cars. The rear wheels were an inch larger than the front wheels.

The two-seater’s interior visibility was based on an F-16 cockpit concept, and riders noted superb ergonomics and extraordinary acceleration and performance. The cars were all hand-built in a unique factory in Tochigi, Japan.

It was a prohibitively priced car to make, and Acura stopped manufacturing the NSX in 2005, after a fifteen-year run. Many consider it one of the most influential sports cars in history. Demand for its blend of high performance, exceptional reliability, and drivability continues. There is also extreme brand loyalty; NSX clubs are found worldwide.

Fortunately for those aficionados, Honda’s 2015 production will include an ultra-high-tech second-generation Acura NSX, equipped with a mid-engine V-6 hybrid drivetrain, being manufactured in Ohio. The original NSX won Automobile Magazine’s Automobile of the Year and Design of the Year in 1991. I wonder how this supercar will be received next year!

Some enthusiasts have said the Acura NSX has the performance and looks of a Ferrari with Honda reliability.  Richard’s vehicle is both sexy and comfortable, crowned with a removable targa top.  It has power windows, locks, and mirrors and hand-sewn leather interiors and steering wheel trim. His car has a  3.0-liter V-6 that makes 270 horsepower with a five-speed manual transmission. It offers traction control and dual front airbags, a power driver’s seat, Bose stereo, and an alarm system.
While Richard has only around 70,000 miles on his, some NSX owners claim mileage in the 200,000 range with the cars still running impeccably, without maintenance headaches.

Richard Pietruska knows car design as few others do.  As a professor of transportation and product design at the Art Center, he has taught many of the most illustrious designers in the field. And in recent years, he has been pleased by the increase in female students.  He says, “Some of the women designers are getting more famous than the guys.”  Richard’s students have included Frank Stephenson, head of design for McLaren; Ford master designers Freeman Thomas, J Mays, and Chelsea Lau; Chris Bangle, the former chief of design for BMW; Henrik Fisker, former designer for Aston Martin and Fisker; Shiro Nakamura, head of design for Nissan; Franz von Holzhausen, chief designer at Tesla; GM design studio chief Frank Saucedo, and Cadillac senior designer Christine Park.  A couple of Richard’s alumni even helped design the original NSX.

Although he loves his Acura NSX, Ferraris have probably been Richard’s favorite car to sculpt, and he is the author and illustrator of the humorous book Fantastico Ferrari Fever as well as Perpetuating Porsche Paranoia. He also pursues the sculpting of “a lot of old cars, the Talbot-Lago, Bugattis, Jaguars.”

Richard shows me an intriguing anthropomorphic sculpture, a curving bronze Alfa Romeo with a female body reflected beneath it. He casts editions of his artwork in bronze, resin, stainless steel, aluminum, and fiberglass. He also sculpted our brother publication Automobile Magazine's Automobile of the Year trophy for the Porsche Boxster, in 1998. His preferred sculpture materials are those that are "related to automotive qualities,” says the member of the Automotive Fine Arts Society and proud owner of an Acura NSX.

pageElements.text: Evidence is mounting that the doomsayers had it wrong when they told us that young people don’t care about cars. The newest study to suggest that people under the age of thirty-five like and want cars comes from Enterprise Holdings, the rental-car company. It says that young people are often inspired to start shopping for a new vehicle after a positive experience in a rental car.
The survey data came from more than 1,300 car owners, all over the age of twenty-five, all of whom had rented a car within the past six months. And here are five interesting things it revealed.

1. As a mind changer.

Enterprise found that, for 88 percent of millennials—twenty-five-to-thirty-four-year-olds, for these purposes—a positive car rental experience could change their opinion of a particular make or model. Just 71 percent of older respondents had their perception of specific cars altered by a rental experience.

2. As a technology showcase.

The study also found that young people were most likely to experience new automotive technology by using it in rental cars, since many don’t have access to brand-new cars of their own to drive. In the study, 68 percent of millennials reported they were more likely to experience new automotive technology as part of a rental car experience than any other way. This likely contributed to their potential to be impressed by rental cars, which are typically not the most thrilling cars on the road.

3. As an image enhancer.

We’ve heard before that young people are especially concerned with image when purchasing a car and want a brand and model that they feel will reflect their own personal style and sensibilities. Enterprise says youngsters approach choosing a rental car the same way: 57 percent of twenty-five-to-thirty-four-year-olds believe that a rental car choice says a lot about a person’s style, personality, and values. Young people aren’t just walking onto the lot and choosing the first car they see; they’re seeking out just the right vehicle to complement their character.

4. As a temporary change of pace.

Young people also view the car rental experience as an opportunity to try something new. More than half of the millennials surveyed indicated that they had a “desire to try something new” when driving a rental car. Older drivers want to play the field, too, if not in quite the numbers of their more youthful counterparts. More than one-third of all respondents said that they want to try something “completely new” when they drive a rental car.

5. As a pre-purchase test drive.

A good rental-car experience can do more than just change brand perception. It can actually propel people to the dealership. According to Enterprise, 58 percent of those surveyed consider cars they have previously rented when shopping for a vehicle, and 28 percent of surveyed millennials were inspired to start shopping for a car after a positive rental experience.

Drivers tired of boring rental cars can hope that this study inspires carmakers to flood rental fleets with fun new models aimed at buy-curious renters, but don’t expect too much: Escapism aside, nearly half of all the women surveyed said that fuel efficiency was one of the most important features in a rental car.

pageElements.text:
If you have ever printed directions from Google Maps, you are going to thank today’s complete update of Google Maps for saving you from the dorky Luddite’s fate. In fact, if you’ve ever planned a trip online, you’re going to love this complete revamp of this powerful online planning tool. Google did a refresh of the mobile version of Google Maps early in 2013, but today, if you use it from a Web browser, you will find it cleaner, prettier, more organized, better informed, and more integrated with your phone. Some fifteen percent of heavy users of the service have been getting access to some of the new tools for a few weeks. But, if you aren’t one of those, you should check it out before you go anywhere. 
Here’s why.
As of today, if you use Google Maps from a Web browser, you will find it cleaner, prettier, more organized, better informed, and more integrated with your phone.

Plane? Train? Drive?

Thinking of heading to the Big Apple for the weekend? But what’s the best way to go? Is it too expensive to fly? Would it be more onerous to drive? Now when you ask Google Maps for directions, it will weigh all these options for you. If a flight is available to your destination, it will do a quick calculation—based on actual flights—and include the time and cost of that option in your directions. Deciding on a mode of transportation no longer requires a visit to Kayak or Travelocity (although you still might want to hit your favorite travel site to book the flight). The decision, at least, is now a matter of a quick glance. Love it.

Get What You Need

Once you get to New York, you’ll want to have some fun. Search for a museum from Google Maps, and the map display will grok what you are thinking. Suddenly the most interesting tourist destinations are more visible than the bazillions of other scraps of information on that busy map. Search for Italian restaurants, and now those are more focused. Google Maps doesn’t eliminate the other information; it just brings to the fore what it knows you want to know.

Plans Already Included

Did you book a hotel or make a restaurant reservation online? How about a flight? Those will show up in your map, too, while you are searching for fun things to do. So you can eyeball how far the museum is from your hotel and how hard it will be to get to that restaurant from where you plan to be.

Transit Help

Not sure how to get from the hotel to your lunch meeting? Ask Google Maps for directions. It will display various driving options and, where public transit is an option, the subway. Choose the bus icon, and click “List all times and options.” It will show you a grid of your options so you can see how far you’ll have to walk (so you can pack the right shoes!), what train to take, and when you need to leave to get where you’re going on time.

What’s Going On?

Thinking about hitting a blues club? Taking in a play? Want to make sure there’s a ballet worth seeing while you’re there? Check out a venue from Google Maps, and click “Upcoming Events” to see what acts will be playing there in the coming weeks. No more opening six browser windows just to plan a simple evening out.
Google Earth is now integrated into maps. (No, it wasn’t before. They were completely separate.) So when you zoom in, you get a real feel for where you are going.

Better Visuals

It used to be a bit of a pain to get to street view from Google Maps. Not anymore. Bring up a museum, restaurant, or nightclub, and you’ll get a panel that shows you everything you might want to know about that destination. Not just how to get to it but the street view of it and user uploaded images of the place. Some venues even have an interior map so you can do a virtual tour from your browser. (These look awesome.) And Google Earth is now integrated into maps. (No, it wasn’t before. They were completely separate.) So when you zoom in, you get a real feel for where you are going.

Real-Time Traffic

Since Google bought Waze—the app that uses the army of smartphones traveling on the roads to track slow traffic, accidents, and other road events in real time—Waze data is being fed right into your Google Maps directions. (This has been working in the mobile apps for a while.) So, if you ask it to plot a route from where you are to where you want to go, it will show you construction sites, closed exit ramps, accidents, and other events that will have an impact on your journey. Click on these—represented as smashed cars, working guys, or exclamation point icons—to find out what’s going on. The directions panel will even let you choose if you want to look at real-time traffic or traffic that’s typical at a particular time of day. From your smartphone, the app might simply route you quietly around nasty events. So don’t be too surprised if it takes you a different way to smooth your commute.

Share Your Plans

Planning to take a trip with a special someone? Don’t waste your alone time talking about routes and timing. Click “My Custom Maps” to create a map you can customize and share—with just your paramour or everyone in your travel plans. This is a super powerful tool and I can’t possibly explain it all here. So, after clicking “My Custom Maps,” and “Create,” select the gear icon in the top right hand corner. Then go to "Take a Tour" to take a walk-through introduction to creating a map.

Map to Go

Did you spend your lunch break planning your mini break? And how did you plan to take that plan on the road? No worries. Just click "Save" from the directions panel, and all your research and routes will be saved to your smart phone. (As long as you sign in from your phone with the same Google e-mail address you use for Google Maps online.)
Maybe the last time you traveled, you showed up with a manila folder full of printouts from the Web. But it’s time to let go of the Nineties. Here’s why: It’s so much easier now.

metaDescription: Flag-Draped Marketing That Fails: We've seen two new car ads that go beyond merely wrapping themselves in the American flag. The ads, for the 2015 Chrysler 200 and 2014 Cadillac ELR, display an ugly streak of jingoism. Read the commentary on JeanknowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Vanity would have me believe you’re reading this because you’re a devoted fan of my writing. In that case, you may want to know that I also edit the magazine’s Ignition section, read lots of Kurt Vonnegut, and would eat sushi at every meal if it were socially acceptable. Reality tells me you just want to know how I landed this amazing job. Fine. Based on my experience, here’s some advice.

1) Major in journalism. Most of us here aren’t racecar drivers -- we’re writers and reporters. It probably helps if you’ve attended journalism school, as I did at the University of Maryland, or worked for some periodical. That said, deputy editor Joe DeMatio now claims he was more intrigued by my second degree in Jewish studies, even though he’s never once asked me to write about the exploits of Simon bar Kochba.
2) Know how to operate a manual transmission. Seems obvious, but I actually did not upon being hired. I taught myself during my first month on the job by visiting six Ann Arbor dealerships to test drive stick-shift economy cars. My sincere apologies to whoever ended up buying that Ford Focus.
3) Learn everything you can about cars. I grew up pouring over car magazines and memorizing zero-to-sixty times as if they were catechism. People have been asking me for car-buying advice since before I could drive.
4) Realize you actually know nothing about cars. A brief conversation with design editor Robert Cumberford, editor-in-chief Jean Jennings, or any other of the veterans here leaves you humbled and astounded by their wealth of automotive knowledge. It’s truly one of the best parts of working here.
5) Be persistent. I wrote to Automobile’s editors. And called. And wrote them some more.
6) Be lucky. I really have no idea why then deputy editor Joe DeMatio answered my unsolicited voicemail. I hadn’t even pronounced his name correctly (it’s De-MAY-shee-oh, not De-MAH-tee-oh). But he did, and here I am, driving cars and writing about them for my devoted fans.

pageElements.text: American car companies love to remind us they're American. That's nothing new. Chevrolet, of course, is as American as baseball, hot dogs, and apple pie. More recently, George Washington defeated the British behind the wheel of a Dodge Challenger.

But in the last two weeks, we've seen two new car ads that go beyond merely wrapping themselves in the American flag. The ads, for the 2015 Chrysler 200 and 2014 Cadillac ELR, display an ugly streak of jingoism.
"We will build your car"
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/KlSn8Isv-3M" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Against a montage of rodeos, cheerleaders, and baseball games, Bob Dylan proclaims all the ways we're the first and the best. We have vision, pride, and true cool. Our assembly line workers have hearts and souls. All these things, Dylan insists, "you can't import."
"Let Germany brew your beer. Let Switzerland make your watch. Let Asia assemble your phone," Dylan concludes. "We will build your car."

The first, and most obvious question for this ad's creators, the agency GlobalHue, is, What foreign-made cars is Dylan referring to? The 2015 Chrysler 200's key "import" competitors are built in Ohio (Honda Accord), Kentucky and Indiana (Toyota Camry), and Tennessee (Nissan Altima, Volkswagen Passat). I also couldn't help but notice there was no reference to letting the Italians—who now own Chrysler—cook your pasta.

Beyond the complexities of what actually constitutes foreign lies a more basic question: why does it matter? Before you insult my intelligence in the comments section, let me say I know why it matters. I grew up in a town that suffered badly when a General Motors factory closed (Framingham, Massachusetts) and I live in Southeast Michigan, where not just the assembly workers, but also doctors, lawyers, and writers rely on the health of the American auto industry. American cars are not important because we have diners, Route 66, Bob Dylan, or factory workers. I've visited assembly lines in Mexico, Japan, England, and Germany. The workers on those lines appeared to have hearts and souls, too.
Now, let's re-watch the brilliant ad Chrysler showed at the 2011 Super Bowl:
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/SKL254Y_jtc" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Note how this advertisement consciously avoids the old tropes about American versus foreign manufacturing. It doesn't even say, "America," until the very end. Rather, it presents an honest picture of Detroit, using the embattled city as a metaphor for ethos we all hold dear, like hard work and resilience. If anything, there's a subtle dig at the rest of the country for forsaking Detroit and these ethos. "We're certainly no one's Emerald City," the narrator reminds viewers.
"We're crazy, hard-working believers."

Chrysler isn't the only domestic automaker thinking it can sell more cars by telling us how superior we are. The first advertisement for the 2014 Cadillac ELR, which was developed by Lowe Campbell Ewald and debuted last week, indulges in clichés similar to the Chrysler commercial. We went to the moon! We have Bill Gates! But the commercial's core message is that Americans work harder than people in "other countries."
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Q4hI6koIRYk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Poolside - Lowe Campbell Ewald

images.caption: 2014 Cadillac ELR in the Super Bowl commercial.
2014 Cadillac ELR in the Super Bowl commercial.
2014 Cadillac ELR in the Super Bowl commercial.

pageElements.text: "Other countries, they work, they stroll home, they stop by the café. They take August off," explains the pitchman (played by Neal McDonough—apparently Macaulay Culkin was not available to reprise his role as Richie Rich).

This spiel, and the potshots at Europe, will probably appeal to Red State conservatives. Unfortunately for Cadillac, most in that audience are unlikely to buy an electric car from so-called Government Motors. (Even those who supported the bailout may chortle when the ad proclaims, "You work hard; you create your own luck.")

The ad opens Cadillac to uncomfortable questions. Like, if Europeans are so lazy and unproductive, how come their luxury brands have been cleaning Cadillac's clock since the 1980s? Why did Cadillac hire a former BMW executive (the very European Uwe Ellinghaus) to run its marketing? How does the brand expect to establish itself in Europe, as it still hopes to, if it derides Europeans? And, finally, what's a Cadillac ELR? The ad never really bothers to tell us.
Contrast this with rap artist Macklemore's ode to Cadillacs, "White Walls."
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/8PLifPUIuic" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Macklemore, too, presents Cadillac as the reward for American ambition and hard work. But he does so with tongue firmly in cheek, and without alienating anyone. He also shows lots of actual Cadillacs.

To be perfectly clear, there's nothing wrong with celebrating America, and there's nothing wrong with Detroit-based automakers celebrating their role in the American story. The problem is with trumpeting American superiority as an argument for buying American cars. It's the difference between saying Chevrolets are as American as baseball and saying that baseball is much better than foreign sports and thus Chevrolets are better than foreign cars (a line of reasoning we're unlikely to hear so long as Chevrolet is locked into its sponsorship of the Manchester United soccer team). The Chrysler and Cadillac ads—both of which, it must be noted, were developed by local Michigan-based agencies—display the insular chauvinism that got American carmakers in trouble.

pageElements.text:
Price: $70,020 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 3.6-liter twin-turbocharged V-6, 410 horsepower, 369 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/24 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Driver Assist package with Adaptive Cruise Control, Automatic Collision Preparation, automatic braking
Option I can’t live without: No options on this model
Notable standard features on this model: Magnetic Ride Control with rear air springs, heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, heated steering wheel, adaptive remote start, head-up display, front and rear park assist
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Lexus LS460

You’d be forgiven for looking at the 2014 Cadillac XTS Vsport and thinking it looked more like a cruiser than a sport sedan. Yes, the XTS Vsport is new for 2014, and it packs a 410-horsepower twin-turbo V-6 under the hood. But it also feels huge out on the road and has all the soft luxury touches of a car built for a driver long past his or her street-racing days. As a twenty-two-year-old woman, I’m hardly the kind of person Cadillac was imagining when they built this car. But I drove it for a weekend anyway, and I was surprised to find myself perfectly comfortable in it.

The XTS Vsport is a step up from the base XTS and a step down from Cadillac’s racing-inspired V line in terms of performance. Aside from the more powerful engine, which offers 105 extra horses compared with the XTS’s base 3.6-liter, normally aspirated engine, the Vsport flies under the radar. You won't find any big, screaming badges here. Just one “V” label on the rear bumper and a unique grille announce the larger engine.

Otherwise, the XTS is the picture of Cadillac design and packaging sensibilities. The exterior’s angles and creases fit in perfectly with the rest of the current Cadillac lineup. The interior is swathed in leather and wood and has heated and cooled seats, a heated steering wheel, and an eight-inch color touchscreen with Cadillac’s Cue infotainment system. I fought with Cue on voice commands, which were consistently misunderstood, but if I took the time to manually enter a destination before pulling out of the driveway, the navigation system was effective and accurate.
The Cadillac XTS Vsport is, for better or worse, exactly what I think of when I think of Cadillac.

Cadillac's XTS comes with a choice of two engines, the 410-horsepower twin-turbo V-6 in the Vsport model) or a normally aspirated 3.6-liter V-6 that makes 305 horsepower. Fuel economy with the standard engine is only marginally better than the twin-turbo, at 17 mpg in the city and 26 mpg on the highway for the all-wheel-drive version. When compared with our test car's 16/24 mpg, it's easy to see the value, as well as the fun, in getting the more powerful engine, but be warned: the base price goes up $17,495 immediately when you choose the Vsport.

You also have three trim level choices on the 2014 XTS: Luxury, Premium, and Platinum. The Platinum model we drove has its own set of 20-inch wheels with chrome inserts, a satin-chrome grille finish, and special interior materials and trim. It also has a seemingly endless list of luxury features as standard, including adaptive lighting, heated and auto-dimming outside mirrors, and rain-sensing wipers, and a interior items including a power rear window shade, real wood trim, heated seats and steering wheel, full leather seating with perforated inserts, a leather-wrapped instrument panel, and a head-up display with color readouts. If you're going to go for this kind of car, why not step up and get all the goodies?

Also on the Platinum edition is a standard Driver Assist package that includes adaptive cruise control, automatic collision preparation, and automatic front and rear braking. The 2014 XTS has automatic parking assist that makes easy work of parallel parking. Add that to the standard Driver Awareness package (also standard on the Premium level), which includes lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, side blind zone alert, and forward collision alert, and you've got a full slate of active safety features on board.

The XTS doesn’t really have the character of a sport sedan. Having said that, it would be a good fit for a driver who wants to feel simultaneously comfortable and in control. Our model's all-wheel drive kept the car planted and confident, even during a snow squall. Rear legroom is more than adequate; one adult of above-average height can sit comfortably behind another. Trunk space is stellar; Cadillac claims "five or more suitcases" will fit in there. Our tester’s blue-black exterior with touches of chrome looked upscale and expensive, although maybe not as expensive as its hefty $70,020 asking price might call for. For that price, you could snag one of its German competitors, and a lot of people probably will.

The Verdict:

The Cadillac XTS Vsport is, for better or worse, exactly what I think of when I think of Cadillac. The XTS is built in Canada, but it feels distinctly American. It’s luxurious and powerful, sure. But it also feels a lot like the car of a wealthy retiree. It’s the kind of car you could take almost anywhere without feeling out of place; it blended in with other cars on the streets of Ann Arbor and was perfectly at home on a trip to the Detroit Institute of Arts. The XTS Vsport will serve its driver well, that is without doubt. But during my weekend with the XTS Vsport, I was never convinced that I wouldn’t be served just as well by one of its competitors.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: When I sat on the cushy leather seats and closed the door, the giant instrument panel behind the steering wheel auto-magically lit up—it knew I was there. Creepy? The entire area is a computer screen; there are no actual dials. Three circles come spinning onto the screen, and then, voilà, you have three dials. Awesome. The center instrument panel features an eight-inch touchscreen that was effortless for me to use. The whole front cabin had swoopy lights that were actually a tad distracting. But the entire experience seemed futuristic, and I am hopeful that this is the direction that automakers are headed.

Laura Sky Brown: I am glad Cadillac has grown out of its Best Little Whorehouse in Texas aesthetic, but I would have been disappointed if this XTS had become as sober as a Volvo inside, and it's not. I know Molly thought the light-up instrument panel was creepy, but I rather liked it. Cadillacs should be a bit wacky-luxurious inside. Case in point: how about that swooping glovebox with a separate control on the dashboard that you need to press to flop it open? But as for driving it, there's nothing wacky or soft about that. It felt great: powerful, capable, and smooth. I also appreciate all the safety features on board. If this is, as Annie says, "the car of a wealthy retiree," I feel good knowing that's one more older person whose car is looking out for him or her. And as Molly says, I do hope all cars, and the people driving them, will be so lucky in the future.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: Three years since entering the market, electric cars remain a novelty. Even if most people haven’t driven one, they’ve at least heard of the Tesla Model S, Chevrolet Volt, and Nissan Leaf.

The same can’t be said for their two-wheeled counterparts Zero, Brammo and Mission. Six years since the first production electric motorcycles started rolling onto the market, they continue to be an obscurity.

But women are a natural market for e-bikes. Lacking a hand-operated clutch and foot-actuated gearshift, in most cases, they don’t require the usual coordination of limbs to manage control, leaving a vehicle that’s as easy to ride as a scooter. Just twist the grip and go for emissions-free riding that costs mere pennies per day to operate.
For all those reasons plus the intangible one, fun, you ought to have a look at products from these West Coast companies that are powering 2014’s electric motorcycle lineup.

Zero Motorcycles

Zero Motorcycles first whispered its way onto the market in 2008 with a groundbreaking all-electric dirt bike. Since then, the Santa Cruz startup has added an S sport bike and a DS model that can be ridden both on-and off-road, as well as an all-new supersport model for 2014 called the SR, which can accelerate as fast as a Ferrari. Its 0-to-60-mph acceleration time is a lickety-split 3.3 seconds on its way to a 102-mph top speed.

New for 2014, a Z-Force Power Tank accessory can extend the range of its S and DS models to as much as 171 miles of city riding or eighty-eight miles on the highway. Recharging takes six to ten hours, depending on the size of the battery pack, and is done with a regular 110-volt wall outlet and charge cord that is built into the bike. The starting price is $12,995 for the S or a steep $16,995 for the SR, but operating costs are one penny per mile, versus fifteen cents for most cars.

Brammo

The Brammo company, based in Ashland, Oregon, makes the prettiest and fastest production electric motorcycle currently on the market. With a style that mimics Ducati’s bestselling Monster, the Empulse is a stylish commuter that can travel up to 128 miles per charge in city driving and about 80 miles per charge in combined city and highway riding. A top speed of 110 mph comes courtesy of an electric motor and 9.3-kilowatt-hour lithium-ion battery pack, which is showcased like the V-twin engine of a Harley-Davidson.

The only electric motorcycle to use a gearbox, the Empulse operates as a six-speed, similar to a clutched and gas-powered motorcycle.  In place of the gas tank is a carbon fiber shell that houses the same J1772 Level 2 charging port used on electric cars such as the Nissan Leaf and the Chevrolet Volt. Recharging takes about three hours with a Level 2 charger, or eight hours with a regular wall outlet. Pricing starts at $16,995.  Fuel economy is an astounding 438 mpg electric equivalent.

Mission Motorcycles

True to its name, Mission Motorcycles is on a quest much like Tesla’s. It seeks to combat the notion that electric vehicles are merely for tree-hugging do-gooders. It does this by offering a stylish, high-end electric sport bike that comes close to matching the performance of its gas-powered counterparts. The first bike from the San Francisco startup is limited to a forty-vehicle production run and is expected to hit the market in the summer. For $74,000, the Mission RS is a track-tested sport bike that boasts a top speed of 150 mph and a 0-to-60-mph acceleration time of just three seconds. A $30,000-plus R model will be available later in the year, with an estimated range of up to 140 miles per charge and a recharge time that’s as little as thirty minutes, using a Level 3 fast charger

pageElements.text: After watching this video of the guy in the Sochi polar bear suit struggling to fit his formidable fur head into the passenger's seat of an Olympic vehicle until he gives up and lies down in the back seat, I had to wonder: Was there no larger auto at the Olympic organizers’ disposal to accommodate the top-heavy mascot? Turns out that Volkswagen Group Rus, a collection of VW’s brands in Russia, is supplying the fleet of about 3,000 support vehicles from VW, Audi, and Skoda for the Olympic and Paralympic Games, and they actually do come in all shapes and sizes.

Skaters, skiers, bobsledders, and pipe riders, plus their gear and coaches, have access to transport en masse via VW commercial vehicles with names unfamiliar on the U.S market like the Multivan, Transporter, Caravelle, and Crafter. (Any of these vehicles would have better suited the oversize Sochi mascot.)

Of course, not every job calls for massive interior volume. Sedans make up about 25 percent of the Sochi fleet, putting Audi’s four-wheel mastery to work on Russia's roads with A4, A6, and A8 models. The Olympic committee can also call on the less stylish Skoda Octavia and Superb when needed, as well as VW’s Polo, Passat, and Phaeton to get them around the Olympic Village and beyond.

Snow and ice are easily handled by the VW Touareg and the Audi Q5 and Q7 but when conditions go from worrisome to beyond manageable, organizers can call on a tricked-out version of the VW Amarok. It’s a mid-size truck that boasts an efficient diesel engine and is seemingly available everywhere but the U.S. The specially modified Sochi Polar Expedition Amarok with monster wheels recently off-roaded its way into the Guinness World Records book on a pre-Olympic publicity traverse across Russia.

Given such a wide variety of Olympic vehicles, surely the Sochi bear shouldn’t have had to suffer such global viral indignity in a Skoda Yeti.  Or maybe I’m looking at it all wrong.  Perhaps, like any resourceful Olympian, the polar bear simply found a way to get the job done in difficult conditions.

pageElements.text: I need a car. I’d like to buy a used one, something luxurious with a few miles on it. But I dread that trip to the dealership for any car, new or used. Hunting Craigslist and negotiating with strangers for a car with a suspect history is even worse. And my husband hates any kind of shopping so much that to get him involved would require roofie drugs and duct tape. So I’ve been procrastinating this purchase for over a year.

When I heard about Carvana, a site that would let me buy that car—and arrange to have it delivered—in less than fifteen minutes without getting up from my desk, I had to try it. “Buying a used car is the worst experience that exists,” opines Ernie Garcia, Jr., founder and president of Carvana. “And used-car salesman are the least trusted people. It is also an expensive experience where a lot of the money goes into running dealerships in high-priced locations. The industry is spending $2,000 per transaction to give customers an experience they hate.”

Carvana aims to change that, simply by cutting out salespeople and showrooms and thereby making a profit on the car sale so no one has to sell you extra stuff like warranties. “There is no combination of choices where we lose,” explains Garcia. “So we don't have to talk you into something in order to profit. We are trying to undercut that crappy experience with something easy.”

Cautious (and perhaps sneaky) by nature, I was unwilling to venture my own hard-earned cash without dipping my toes in first. So I used my position as a writer for JeanKnowsCars.com to convince Garcia to let me test-buy a car with their money.

Even though the money wasn’t mine, I had to drag the shopping out. I think it’s actually possible to buy a car in fifteen minutes at Carvana. But spending $25,000 that fast would have me outspending Justin Bieber (who, if Internet gossip and my feeble calculations are to be believed, spends an average of $350 every fifteen minutes). So I dawdled as much as possible. I browsed the online inventory of cars slowly and at random. Then I searched by criteria: price, color, body style, miles, brand. I collected a half-dozen cars in my online garage. Then I explored each in exquisite detail.
Carvana posts detailed photos of the car you will be buying, complete with scratches, wear on the interior, and other imperfections, called out so you won’t miss them.

Carvana posts detailed photos of the very car you will be buying, complete with scratches, wear on the interior, and other imperfections, all called out so you won’t miss them. It also gives you a thorough tour of the features, gas mileage, and other relevant information. That's the sort of thing it’s difficult to keep straight with a clipboard and memory when shopping in the real world. (That is, if you ever get around to comparing more than one car. According to Carvana’s Garcia, more than 70 percent of buyers drive only one used car when shopping.)

I spun the cars around. I zoomed in. I compared prices to the Kelley Blue Book. When I had winnowed my garage down to three cars, I sent a link to my garage to friends so they, too, could look over my options and vote. My husband voted willingly and immediately (saving me a tidy sum on drugs). But the entire decision process still only took about an hour. By the time Carvana had the votes tallied, I knew what car I wanted: a 2011 Infiniti M37 with nearly 30,000 miles on it for $24,500. And I was satisfied I was getting it at a fair price.

Paying for it (with fake money anyway) was pretty easy, too. I entered some financial information, uploaded my proof of residency, an ID, and proof of insurance. Then I fake-paid my deposit and scheduled delivery of my vehicle.

Carvana keeps its cars in Atlanta. The closer you live to Atlanta, the cheaper the delivery. It’s free if you’re within seventy-five miles, $199 if you are seventy-six to 250 miles away. It goes up from there. To have my car delivered to Wilmington, North Carolina, where I live, would cost $480. If I lived in Oakland, California, the cost jumped to $1,250. Or I could fly to Atlanta, pick my car up in an automated “vending machine” where I’d enter a code to unlock the garage and free my car, and road-trip my new wheels home. And, for that, the company would give me $200 toward a plane ticket and pick me up at the airport.

Can you get a Certified Pre-Owned car this way? And what about inspections? Carvana offers its own 100-day, 4,189-mile Carvana Certified program, plus a seven-day "no questions asked" money-back guarantee. That leaves time to get it to your mechanic for a look.

I didn’t actually take delivery of my fake-bought car. But the site claimed it could have it to me within three days. If, within seven days, I decided I didn’t want it, I could return it, no questions asked.

I’m convinced. I am going to buy my next used car this way. I am clearly much too lazy to buy a used car the old way. I’m just grateful that I live in the year 2014 where, if I procrastinate long enough, someone will invent a better way for me to sit around and have the things I need delivered to my door.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The idea of entering an automotive parts superstore is so daunting for some of us that even if we need something as simple as windshield washer fluid, we will pay a premium to have the dealer to do it rather than buy it ourselves. I checked in with Advance Auto Parts store's Brian Bartholomew to find out what the five most common purchases were.

1. Fluids

Even if you are not planning to become a shade-tree mechanic, you should know what products your car uses. Check the owner's manual for the specs, and then check out the savings if you buy them ahead of time from a superstore (instead of in an emergency at the 7-11). Particularly with older engines, check your oil regularly, and if it is running low, having a quart available to top off your supply will be most welcome. Plus most stores have used oil recycling programs, making it a no-brainer to dispose of that spent oil responsibly. While you are there, pick up a gallon of windshield washer fluid, which is generally cheaper here.

2. Batteries

Did you know you can not only buy a battery at the auto parts store, but have one installed? I didn't. A common culprit when your car struggles to start, the battery’s charge is easily checked by your auto parts store. Brian notes batteries are a large part of his store's business: “In winter, we might sell thirty-five to forty batteries in a day.” Which is why many retailers like Advance Auto Parts offer free diagnostic, installation, and charging services. They'll recycle the old one, too. While you are waiting for the new powerplant to be hooked up, browse the jumper cables just in case.

3. Car Wax and Detailing Supplies

There is a dizzying array of products to shine, clean, and recondition your car inside and out, so it makes sense to check with the experts at your superstore before buying. Chances are they’ve used the products themselves and have had lots of helpful feedback from auto-obsessed regulars. Like so many other leisure pursuits, doing a really good job of washing your car yourself is satisfying

4. Windshield Wipers

Replace your blades at least once or twice a year, recommends Brian. Those who live in wintry climates will know that the change of seasons usually requires a fresh set of wiper blades anyway. Here's where online shopping can be helpful. Advance Auto Parts' website, for example, lets you select your exact year, make, and model of car and will show you the blades that are an exact fit so you can go to the store armed with that information. Or, at the superstore, there's usually a printed guide to blades, or ask the clerk to look up the proper style for your car; he or she can also advise you on the tradeoffs between price and quality. It takes just a few minutes to remove the old ones and click the new ones on.

image.altText: rugged ridge all terrain floor mats

pageElements.text:
5. Floor Mats

All manner of unspeakable detritus gets ground into the carpet of your car’s floor on a daily basis, wearing and tearing until once proud fibers are rubbed bare. A good set of all-weather floor mats is one of the most satisfying aftermarket items to put into your car, and even high-end mats aren't that pricey; at Advance Auto Parts, for example, you can get a pair of heavy-duty WeatherTech all-weather floor mats for under $100. Auto stores carry a variety of aftermarket mats made to fit most vehicles, but if you need or want something in particular the store can order it for you. Consider a seat protector while you are at it, especially if you have light-colored upholstery.

Remember these big chains have purchasing power for lower prices and are staffed by the kinds of people who live and breathe autos. Brian says he’s noticed women are increasingly present and seem more comfortable shopping the store. And I think we can all agree that that's exactly how it should be.

pageElements.text: From back in the days when people subjected one another to interminable slide shows of their trips abroad, the vacation photo has been an essential souvenir to bring home. But how often have you come home from an unforgettable trip only to realize that you have no good photos of the whole family together?

Smartphones make it easier than to take snapshots, but it's a lot harder than it looks to capture both the people and the overall feeling of a place by snapping away with your iPhone. Theme parks have been exploiting that need for years, sending marginally qualified employees out with cameras to take a smiling group photo, say in front of the entrance to Sea World—and then sell you a hastily developed photo for a ridiculous price. (I've bought them anyway.)

A new service called Flytographer could be the fix for the photo issue. This website will set you up with a half-hour, one-hour, or two-hour photo session at your vacation spot with a professional photographer. The result: studio-quality shots that will really serve as treasured mementos of your vacation.

Flytographer is relatively new, having launched less than a year ago. Founder Nicole Smith said she was inspired by a trip to Paris, when she and a friend got someone to take good photos of them strolling around the city. She now has photographers lined up in seventy cities. The most booked locations so far have been New York City, Hawaii, and Disneyland, but you can book all over the world, from Melbourne to Bangkok to Copenhagen and from Buenos Aires to Vancouver.

In a half-hour shoot ($250), you get shots in one location and fifteen digital photos. For $350, you can get photos in one or two locations or neighborhoods and go home with thirty digital images. For $600, you can be photographed in multiple locations around your vacation spot and get sixty digital images. And, yes, you will be in the family photos this time, not behind the camera. Kind of makes you want to plan a trip somewhere glamorous, doesn't it?

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I went to Bentley’s historic headquarters in Crewe, England, for the first time in my long career as an automotive journalist. I wasn't there to test cars (except for a few exceptional backseats behind a chauffeur). Instead, I was welcome where few have been invited—the back rooms where veneers are mirror matched by hand and finished by skilled artisans, and where large southern German bull hides are scrupulously examined for the slightest flaws (unacceptable!) before a laser cuts pattern pieces dictated by a computer. I was able to take part in some of the hand work, which I found much more interesting than scrapbooking, I must say! We made a short video before we jumped on the Eurostar for Paris, where we toured Bentley's inaugural furniture collection at the Paris furniture show, Maison et Objet.

title: Consumer Reports Picks
subTitle: The 2014 model ratings are out from the consumer publication. What weight should shoppers give them?
promoTeaserSmall: The 2014 model ratings are out from the consumer publication. What weight should shoppers give them?
promoTeaser: The 2014 model ratings are out from the consumer publication. What weight should shoppers give them?
metaDescription: Consumer Reports Picks: The 2014 model ratings are out from the consumer publication. What weight should shoppers give them? Read our perspective on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Every year about this time, Consumer Reports publishes its April Best Cars issue. Even though this nonprofit organization, founded in 1936, does extensive testing and surveying to come up with its rankings, the question remains: who decides what “best” means, and is this or any publication’s “best” choice the best for you? Awards and top picks belong in any shopper's tool box of information, but as one among many research tools you should avail yourself of.

Consumer Reports is well known for placing a high value on reliability. The organization does its own road testing and consults National Highway Transportation Safety Administration (NHTSA) and Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) crash testing results, then rounds out its rankings using data from subscribers on the actual problems they experience with their vehicles. All well and good, but it’s important to understand what “problems” might mean. It’s not necessarily something mechanical, such as early brake failure; often, it’s difficulty in learning to use the telematics and electronic systems.

This directly affected ratings for Ford and Cadillac this year, because subscribers criticized both brands for their Ford Sync MyFord and MyLincoln Touch, and Cadillac Cue systems’ user-unfriendliness. Would this stop you from buying and enjoying the cars? That’s another question, and that’s why it is important to understand what the ratings are based on. Let's take Ford as an example, since that company was kicked all the way to the basement for 2014, ranking at the bottom of the brand rankings next to Jeep. Consumer Reports put that down to "widespread reliability problems" with its infotainment systems, as well as problems with the automatic transmissions in two models, the Focus and Fiesta. These issues were weighted more heavily than the Ford lineup's "fairly high test scores" in road testing. Since Consumer Reports doesn't skimp on details, numbers, and charts, the information is available, although most can only be accessed by subscribers.

In a separate ranking, CR did a survey in December about “brand perception” in which Ford came in second and Cadillac made the top ten (at the #9 position, between Volvo and BMW). Ford also made the top five in perception of Technology/Innovation, Value, Performance, Safety, and Quality.

Here's the full list of Best Car Brands:

Best Overall Goes to Tesla

CR gave its best-in-show award, Best Overall, to the Tesla Model S. The organization is in good company: our brother publication Automobile Magazine named the Model S its 2013 Automobile of the Year. The car, priced just under $90,000, is undoubtedly a game changer. CR ranked it tops in road testing, reliability, and safety measures. The average Consumer will be hard pressed to afford one, of course.

Top Picks

Listed by category, the Top Picks are:
Honda Accord (Mid-size sedan): "Handling is agile, although the ride isn't quite as comfortable as that in some competitors. Just avoid the HondaLink infotainment system that comes on EX-L versions."
Subaru Impreza (Compact car): "Easy to live with, thanks to a roomy interior, spacious rear seat, simple controls....our only serious gripe is pronounced road noise. But it's no deal breaker."
Toyota Prius (Green car): "Our Green Car pick for the eleventh year in a row," but "skip the slow, noisy Prius C econobox."
Audi A6 (Luxury car): "A sumptuous, impeccably finished, first-class cabin that's brimming with the latest high-tech features."
BMW 328i (Sport sedan): "Excellent handling and a high fun-to-drive factor....roomier, more luxurious, and more fuel-efficient than past models."

Subaru Forester (Small SUV): "The easiest access and best visibility in its category....OK, the ride is a bit firm and the in-car electronics are behind the curve; there's still room for improvement."
Hyundai Santa Fe (Mid-size SUV): "A lot of features for the money, including a standard backup camera. But the tiny third-row seat is for kids only."
Honda Odyssey (Minivan): "The most complete family vehicle you can buy....also relatively fun to drive for a minivan, with its vigorous V-6 engine, responsive handling, and supple ride."

Ram 1500 (Pickup): "Surprisingly refined and inviting...effortless power while returning a relatively good 15 mpg overall. The Chevrolet Silverado outscored the Ram in our testing, but its reliability is unknown."

It's always good to read widely when looking for a new car. IntelliChoice lets you research cars by make and model, check out costs of ownership in seven areas from insurance to fuel, and offers real-world fuel economy numbers—and, unlike Consumer Reports, gives up the data without requiring a subscription.
But, if your fascination with the Consumer Reports model continues, check out Automobile Magazine's 2013 behind-the-scenes look at CR HQ.

title: Toyota RAV4 to Mackinac Island
subTitle: You've heard the Great Lakes are frozen over? We drove the small SUV up north to see for ourselves.
promoTeaserSmall: You've heard the Great Lakes are frozen over? We drove the small SUV up north to see for ourselves.
promoTeaser: You've heard the Great Lakes are frozen over? We drove the small SUV up north to see for ourselves.
metaDescription: Toyota RAV4 to Mackinac: You've heard the Great Lakes are frozen over? We drove the small SUV up north to see for ourselves. Read our story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Like most people in Michigan, I was suffering from cabin fever when I climbed into a Toyota RAV4 at the start of a frigid February weekend. My husband, Tom, and I considered hitting I-75 and driving south until our tires reached sand, but we decided instead to go the “polar” opposite direction—Mackinac Island.

This car-free island just a few miles off the eastern shore of Michigan’s Upper Peninsula in Lake Huron is infested with tourists in the summer, but when the snow starts to blow, it becomes a ghost town. A ferry continues to run until the icy waters become too treacherous, but after that the only way to get there is to make a quick trip in an airplane to or from Saint Ignace, the town on the Upper Peninsula side of the Mackinac Bridge.

That is, until, at some point early in the New Year, an ice bridge forms linking Mackinac Island to the real world. Then, for a short period of time it is possible to walk, bicycle, or snowmobile between Saint Ignace and the island. We had to see that (and try it) for ourselves.

The ice bridge is sanctioned by no official organization, and no one will deem it safe for passage, whether officially or even in conversation. The islanders explained to us how unnamed individuals test the depth of the ice, and once they feel it is safe, they plant discarded Christmas trees along two paths. The northern route is the shortest distance; it lands on the island at the opposite end of the main street.

The second route is called the Beeline. It is longer, but it delivers you much closer to the main street. However, it is also considered more dangerous. Both begin in the harbor behind the Mackinac Grille restaurant in Saint Ignace, which boasts a large parking lot that is free for all—but pack a shovel, because you could easily get plowed under. On the weekend when we went, there were plenty of snowmobilers, and we also saw a group of fat-tire bikers and even a few walkers. Be aware when you plan a trip that the ice bridge is fickle. It can last for two months or only a few days.
Be aware, if you plan a trip to Mackinac in winter, that the ice bridge is fickle. It can last for two months or only a few days.

Since we do not own a snowmobile or a fat-tire bike and weren’t ready for a five-mile hike, we opted to take the air option to get to Mackinac Island. But first, we needed to get to Saint Ignace. Since we would be flying over in a small plane, we thought it made sense to pack light. However, once we packed snowshoes and enough winter gear to keep us warm in the single-digit temperatures, we were more in the heavy range. The RAV4 has plenty of room for two, but if you threw in a dog and a couple of kids, it would be helpful that the XLE comes standard with roof rails. Optional crossbars are available, and they'd be needed.

Mackinac Island is a straight shot up I-75 from Ann Arbor, but we opted to take the scenic route and spend a night in the upscale tourist town of Glen Arbor. In the morning our route hugged the Lake Michigan coastline, revealing a winter wonderland that the Sochi Olympics organizers would envy. We were a little disappointed that there was not a remote start, but spring is only twenty-three days away, so I will forgive Toyota. Since there are no heated seats even available on the XLE, I was glad it had cozy cloth seats. The seats, however, seemed to attract lint and crumbs, and a power driver’s seat is not available in this trim, either.

To remedy my complaints, if you bump up to the Limited package, your behind will thank you. Standard features are leather seating, an eight-way power driver's seat with lumbar support, and best of all, those front seats are heated. My bum says Limited all the way. Plus, it also is the only trim level with which you can get a blind-spot monitor, lane departure signal, and auto high beams.

The RAV4 has a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine that makes 176 horsepower. Ours was equipped with all-wheel drive (AWD). Actually, it operates in front-wheel-drive mode until the dynamic torque control senses slipping in the front tires and then automatically switches to AWD, or the driver can elect to push a button to lock it into AWD. The roads were mostly snow covered, but the RAV4 was stable and performed as if were traveling on clear pavement. But once we were far north enough to be sharing the roads with snowmobiles,  we locked in the AWD. The transition was undetectable, and we surefooted our way until we returned to a road that had seen the blade of a snowplow to unlock the AWD.
If I owned this car, I am sure I would quickly get addicted to the apps. I love the idea of pressing a button and seeing a weather radar right on the on-board monitor.

For the remainder of our drive, the sun was shining, and we were able to enjoy the scenery rather than white-knuckle our way North. The sport-ute proved to drive more like a car, and the ride was both smooth and sturdy. Our RAV4 was equipped with the optional Entune premium audio with navigation and app suite, a $1,030 option. The navigation system proved a little tricky until I found the control to change the view from direction-based to a mode that kept north always at the top. I had easily linked my phone, but I did not bother to download the Entune app on my phone to use Pandora, traffic, and weather right on the vehicle monitor. If I owned this car, I am sure I would quickly get addicted to the apps. I love the idea of pressing a button and seeing a weather radar right on the on-board monitor.

As we drove over the Mackinac Bridge that links the Upper and Lower Peninsulas of Michigan, all that we could see was a giant sheet of ice. There was a long mark where an icebreaker had broken a path that clearly showed the shipping route, but it had since frozen over. On the day we crossed over the bridge, the Great Lakes were 88 percent frozen, and Lake Huron was estimated at 97 percent. I grew up with snowmobiles, and I was conflicted as to which method of transportation was safer. I have a faint memory from my childhood of being on snowmobiles crossing a lake when the top layer suddenly was less than solid. But flying in a small plane ranks high on my list of fears as well.

Once we reached the tiny Mackinac County Airport in Saint Ignace, we hopped on a six-seater plane from Great Lakes Air (round trip $50) and made the five-minute flight to the island. The view was phenomenal. We could easily see the ice bridge with snowmobilers hightailing it to the island. I stumbled over a quick Hail Mary, and we were on the ground.
The 500 year-round residents rely on the freedom that the snowmobiles deliver. In fact, most of the kids drive themselves to school by snowmobile once they turn twelve.

A horse-drawn carriage taxi met us at the airport, and we clip-clopped our way from the center of the snow-globe island to the Pontiac Lodge. At first it seemed wrong to see all the snowmobiles zipping around on the normally gas-free island—other than the horses' odoriferous contributions, of course. But I quickly realized that the approximately 500 year-round residents of Mackinac Island rely on the freedom that the snowmobiles deliver. In fact, most of the school kids drive themselves to school via snowmobile once they are twelve. Just the idea of that makes me envious of the islanders. A bike is one thing, but imagine the freedom of a snowmobile.

This is not a vacation spot for shoppers or indoor enthusiasts. There are only two restaurant/bars, a grocery store, and just  a handful of accommodations that are open during the winter. But the true beauty lies outside. It is a paradise for snowmobilers, cross-country skiers, and snowshoers. Fat-tire bikers told us that the snowmobile paths were great for them, but they shared that much more than four inches of snow does make pedaling difficult.

Cawthorne’s Village Inn held a chili cookoff the day we arrived, and the locals and visiting snowmobilers filled the place way past capacity. We had our sights set on the lantern-lit cross-country or snowshoe event that was scheduled for 6:00 to 8:00 p.m. So we took a trip to Doud's grocery store and cobbled together a snack.

The one horse-drawn carriage available is actually less than available: we called several times, and each request was rebuked. So we headed out to the start of the hike on foot, carrying our snowshoes. I haven’t been to the island in at least twenty years, and I had forgotten how steep the climb is to the Michigan Governor's Summer Residence. Seriously, I wished we had a Sherpa, and I was the load they were carrying. Or how ‘bout a mule?? I don’t think we were trespassing as we walked through the drifts and looked out over the straits of Mackinaw from the governor’s porch. I felt like, since I pay taxes, it was a legit visit.

From here we skirted around Fort Michilimackinac. Built by the British during the American Revolutionary War and surprisingly part of the War of 1812 as well, the fort is now part of the Mackinac Island State Park. I am sure few visitors know that the park is actually over seventy percent of the island. A map of ski trails highlights the miles of trails that are available.
We struggled to capture the evening, but our photos in no way matched the beauty or the complete silence that we experienced as we laughed our way through the inky night.

By the time we reached the beginning of the two-mile lit loop it was quite dark, but a big fat full moon beamed down and made the path clear. That is, until we reached the dense woods. We popped on our snowshoes and headed out into the night. On our hike we only saw a half-dozen skiers, and most of them were in the first half hour. It was seriously dark between the lanterns, and we were happy to have headlamps to lead the way.

When we reached the famous rock formation that overlooks Lake Huron known as Arch Rock, we had the night to ourselves. We struggled to capture the evening with our amateur camera, but our shots in no way matched the absolute beauty, coupled with the complete silence, that we experienced as we laughed our way through the inky night. The loop seemed more like five miles than two, and at the end was a campfire with hot chocolate provided by the state park. We mingled with locals who shared stories of living on the island. It was fascinating to imagine living on less than four square miles—relying on bikes and foot power to move about for most of the year. I can imagine this simpler life, but I would look forward to the snow when I could get on my snowmobile and hit the ice bridge to the mainland.

Also, I would seriously miss the freedom that a car represents.

The next day we hiked around the village and had a leisurely lunch at the Mustang Lounge. We walked to the ice bridge, where one of the fat tire bikers was kind enough to let us take a spin on his $2,500 bike. Tom was enamored with the bike but not the price. We were bundled like toddlers sent out to play in the snow in their snowsuits, and we felt like kids on a playground. We poked around the deserted Grand Hotel and ended up at Cawthorne’s for a quick meal with an individual TV at our table to enjoy the Winter Olympics. As the sun was setting, we walked back out on the ice bridge just in time to catch the sun setting behind the Mackinac Bridge.

The forecast for the next day was for rain, sleet, and windy conditions, and we needed to get back to reality, so we arranged for a taxi to catch the first flight of the day. I secretly decided that if the conditions were horrid, I would stay on the island until spring. But luckily the storm was still several hours away when we stepped aboard the Lilliputian plane. Since I am able to share this tale, obviously we landed safely. As idyllic as the island experience was, it was nice to be back to the mainland. Once we were in the RAV4 we headed south on the real Beeline, I-75.

I highly recommend a winter trip to Mackinac Island, and the snowier and colder the better. Remember, it must be very cold for a long period of time before the magical ice bridge is ready for travel. I would seriously consider renting a snowmobile in Saint Ignace and having full run of the island, and next time I will stay at one of the B&Bs. Other than that, I wouldn’t change a thing.

2013 Toyota RAV4 XLE AWD

Price: $26,535 base price (including destination); $28,552 as tested (including destination)
