pageElements.text: What could be more twenty-first century than carbon fiber? This ultra-lightweight, durable, and—let's face it—awesome-looking material has been used on cars for years, starting with Formula 1 cars in the 1990s. It has expanded to be used for a variety of products: violins and cellos that play well consistently, even in humid conditions, for example, as well as sillier purposes such as mouse pads and phone cases.

Most recently, the electric BMW i3 made its debut in Germany last fall, claiming the bragging rights as the first mass-production car made mainly of carbon fiber. The plug-in hybrid BMW i8, our brother publication Automobile Magazine's Design of the Year, will likewise have a passenger cell made of weight-trimming carbon fiber.
So it is only fitting that owners of the new BMW i8 can accessorize it with this smashing four-piece luggage set made of (you guessed it) carbon fiber from Louis Vuitton.

The set includes a Weekender GM i8 for the trunk, with both shoulder and hand straps; the Garment Bag i8, which is intended to fit snugly on the rear shelf; the Business Case i8, a hardshell piece that is shaped to match the i8's rear seats and "is also ideal for carrying laptops"; and the Weekender PM i8, a smaller bag that's designed to fit onto the rear seat.

Adrian van Hooydonk, design chief at BMW, says the tie-in with Louis Vuitton makes sense because both companies "share both a profound appreciation of tradition and a commitment to constant further development."

If you share that sensibility, bring some cash along. Louis Vuitton has not released pricing yet, but a comparable Weekender bag made of the traditional Vuitton brown patterned fabric runs $1,830, while a comparable leather Garment Bag is priced at $3,900.

Whether or not you're prepared to buy an i8, which will retail at $136,625 when it goes on sale in the spring, you can aspire to own the luggage: it's sold at Louis Vuitton's stores in eight cities worldwide, including New York City and Los Angeles, starting on April 1.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Back When I Was Yellow

I went to the University of Michigan in 1971 at the tender age of sixteen. But I was way too busy waitressing and marching in anti-war demonstrations to study. So I bolted the Big U after three non-productive semesters, and I got a job driving a cab. I was eighteen, and my parents were now truly horrified. I think I was, too.
A year later, I owned my own taxi, just to prove I could. The rest of my life has been spent crawling up the mountain of my shame by my fingernails.

I bought a used Plymouth Fury with 56,000 miles on it, painted it yellow, and joined Ann Arbor Yellow Cab Company.  Within two months, I had to teach myself how to work on it because the repair bills were staggering.  I taught myself tuneups in my friend Cowboy Bill’s gas station, using library books on car maintenance.
I did a brake job at the curb in front of my house, by drawing a picture in my sketchbook of every part I took out, so I would put it all back together correctly.

My cab-driving outfit was bib overalls and a ski hat, or long hippie skirts down to the ground with army boots.  You could see the salt stains along the bottom edge of the skirt in the winter.  I didn’t shave my legs. I smoked cigars. I was so cool. I used to keep a bottle of wine under the seat, and if I liked the person in the back seat, I’d offer them a slug.

The cab drivers were an uncertain lot, shall I say. Oh, there was the occasional Ph.D. candidate, like David Wilson, who got in trouble for practicing his saxophone on the cab stand in front of the old U Hospital. There were also a couple of more-or-less professionals who considered cab driving a craft. There was Lester, Cab #1, who had a Lincoln with suicide doors, and who spent most days off the Yellow Cab grid, running a long list of private clients on errands. There was another guy, who today—forty years later—drives a city bus. Not to alarm you. And there were several college graduates who went on to buy the company. That was ridiculous. They’re all gone.
About once a year I’d have someone famous in the back seat. Like the time I picked up Jason Robards at the back door of the Power Center.

The rest of the cabbies were transient reprobates like me. Our hero was a guy who turned the tables on a would-be robber. Think De Niro in Taxi Driver. When the guy in his back seat pulled out a knife, our Colleague pulled out a giant Maglite flashlight from under his seat and gave his assailant a helluva thumping with it. He then rolled him in the gutter and took $250 from his pockets.

About once a year I’d have someone famous in the back seat. Like the time I picked up Jason Robards at the back door of the Power Center, where he’d just finished a performance in A Moon for the Misbegotten with Colleen Dewhurst.

He wanted to go to the old theatre on South U next to the Brown Jug, to see The Hound of the Baskervilles. I was so excited I could barely drive. “I just saw you in Tora! Tora! Tora! last night!" I’m pretty sure I shouted at him. He looked pained. "That‘s one I’d like to forget," he said. The meter ran a dollar twenty, and he gave me ten bucks. Jason Robards!

But most of the time it was drug addicts and drunks. I carried one guy into his house over my shoulder after he’d been slashed in a bottle fight. I propped him on the toilet, cleaned him up with alcohol, and put him to bed. A driver began stalking me. Another woman driver was murdered. I was robbed at gunpoint. After five years, it was clearly time to move on. But not before I wrote a training manual for new cab drivers, was elected president of the Yellow Cab Board, and completely redesigned the taxi stand system in Ann Arbor.
You know, the typical things one does.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: In his first State of the City address on Wednesday, Detroit’s new mayor, Mike Duggan, announced plans to tackle the city’s high car insurance rates by creating a first of its kind city-run auto insurance plan called D-Insurance. "We're going to keep going until we get people an affordable car insurance option," the mayor said in his speech.

If you live in the city of Detroit, you pay the highest rates in the country, according to one study by Nerdwallet.com, an online consumer comparison site. Using the profile of a twenty-six-year-old male with no accident history on his 2012 Toyota Camry, NerdWallet calculated auto insurance rates in the 125 largest U.S. cities. Detroit’s average premium was $10,723.22 yearly, well over $6,000 more than the next highest city, New Orleans.
When he moved from a nearby suburb into the city to run for office, Mayor Duggan's own premiums doubled, from $3,000 to $6,000, as a result of his new zip code.

When he moved from a nearby suburb into the city in order to run for office, Mayor Duggan experienced the phenomenon himself, stating during Wednesday’s address that his premiums doubled, from $3,000 to $6,000, as a result of his new zip code. "What's the single biggest barrier to driving a car?" he asked during the speech. "Insurance," came a chorus of replies. Indeed, more than half of Detroit car owners are reportedly driving uninsured.

The mayor’s idea is a bold one. According to Robert Detlefsen, vice-president of public policy at the National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies, Detroit will be navigating uncharted auto coverage territory. “We know of no other major municipality that has ever attempted to institute an insurance program of this sort,” said Detlefsen.

Unfortunately, Detroiters seeking insurance relief will have to wait for a required feasibility study to be conducted jointly by the Detroit City Council and the mayor’s office before the dream of D-Insurance can be attempted. Mayor Duggan says the Detroit city charter permits it, and a team has already been assembled, according to the mayor’s office. Residents, he said, should expect to see progress on the study by the summer.

Since he took office in January, access to safe and affordable transportation as a means to increase citizens’ employment opportunities has been a top priority for Mayor Duggan. His administration has initiated safety camera installations on the city’s DDOT buses, totaling fifty this month with the goal of outfitting 300 buses by the fall. He complained in the speech about the public transportation system, calling Detroit's buses "the oldest fleet in America" and saying extending hours on buses and replacing the aging fleet are high priorities. In fact, the mayor said, the Obama administration is helping cut red tape to get fifty new buses delivered to Detroit by fall. A program to install lower-maintenance LED streetlights on the city’s east and west sides has also begun.

These improvements are undoubtedly welcome by Detroit’s commuters, but in a city built around the automobile, one has to imagine that significantly lowering the cost of owning a car by providing affordable insurance would be better news still.

metaDescription: 2014 Cadillac CTS AWD 2.0T Luxury: Does this car belong in your driveway? Read our review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Price: $53,925 (base price of this model), $56,875 as tested (prices include destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 272 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Driver Awareness package, including side blind zone alert
Option I can’t live without: Navigation system ($905)
Notable standard features on this model: Brembo performance brakes, Cadillac User Experience (CUE) with 8.0-inch touchscreen display, Bluetooth connectivity, heated steering wheel, remote start
Notable options on this model: Eighteen-inch painted fifteen-spoke wheels ($1,550), navigation system with surround sound ($905), Majestic Plum Metallic paint ($495)
You might also be considering: BMW 5 Series, Lexus GS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

It’s all new. It is Motor Trend's Car of the Year for 2014. And it’s absolutely, undeniably a Cadillac to look at. Its only problem may be that last part. We tried out the 2014 Cadillac CTS in its top Luxury trim but with its 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, rather than the 3.6-liter V-6 or the even sportier twin-turbo Vsport version. Call it the everyday CTS, the one that a younger or less wealthy buyer might go for when seeking luxury more than performance.

Because luxury is a state of mind, and you can get into that state of mind quite easily when stepping into the car. I visualized myself pushing my mink coat aside to strap in. But the floatiness and even flabbiness of old Cadillacs is no more. This feels like a completely modern sedan.
On the other hand, it's not for someone who is that much less wealthy. Witness the as-tested price of $56,875.
Cadillac went straight at the mid-size luxury cars from BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Audi, and, as the New York Times commented, "the German lessons are paying off."

Cadillac went straight at the mid-size luxury cars from BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Audi, and Lexus with this sedan and, as the New York Times commented in a January story on the CTS, “The German lessons are paying off.” The use of aluminum cut weight (and made the CTS come in about 200 pounds lighter than the BMW 528i, for example). Technology abounds, including standard Brembo front brakes, a sport suspension, a rearview camera, forward collision alert, lane departure warning, and side blind zone and rear cross-traffic alerts. It also has General Motors' annoying but useful Safety Alert Seat, which vibrates when you are in danger of leaving your lane or getting into a crash.

The elephant in the passenger compartment might be the Cadillac Cue telematics system. I didn't personally have any trouble with it, but I have heard and read enough complaints that I'd advise any prospective buyer to play with it a lot before closing a sale, to make sure it works for you. "Cue" stands for Cadillac User Experience. It has an eight-inch touchscreen information display and, on the one we drove, navigation (we had the optional navigation system/uplevel surround sound package, priced at $905). Cadillac uses terms such as "intuitive" and "smartphone- and tablet-influenced controls" to describe the system, but really, it's complex. Of course, to an owner who spent some time with it, there might be a whole different report card than for someone like me who just got in for a short time. But all the choices on the screen can be distracting, and I only worked on it while securely parked.

Since it is winter, I appreciated that the model we drove had all-wheel drive. The seats were supportive without being squashy; the ride was the same. The CTS was sure-footed, comfortable, and so assertive to drive that every stereotype about a Cadillac's living-room-sofa ride feel went straight out of my head.

Having said that, it could have been even better. The midrange CTS we got to drive did not have some of the features you could get by going for the Vsport version. The rear-wheel-drive Vsport has a twin-turbo V-6 that makes 420 horsepower, mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. It also has Magnetic Ride Control and an electronic limited-slip differential to make this sporty sedan even sportier, and automatic park assist to make parallel parking a twenty-first-century experience. For those looking for the maximum performance out of this new Cadillac, the Vsport seems like the one to go for, and its price ($59,995, including destination) is not so much higher than the four-cylinder version to put it out of contention.

The Verdict:

So, should you buy this car? It’s like what your mother told you about true love, or the critics told you about art: you’ll know it when you see it. If the look and feel of a Cadillac CTS does it for you, there’s no point in worrying about whether a BMW or Mercedes will impress more people in the parking lot. You can buy this somewhat flashier, very American car and know you've made the right choice. It's just as good as it looks, or, depending on your taste, even better. The 2.0-liter Luxury model with AWD, shown here, will be just right for most people, if they're looking for a Cadillac as a modern luxury sedan more than as a sports car. But try the Vsport before you decide, since the prices are so close between it and the four-cylinder CTS.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The CTS is the brash American in the mid-size luxury segment, but it should not be overlooked. In fact I think it stands out from its peers for its unique grille and aggressive stance. The interior is lush and sophisticated, and the materials can stand up to the German and Japanese contenders. With the plethora of engines and trim levels that are available, there is an option for most any driver. That being said, it still does not have the refined powertrains that the Mercedes E-Class and Audi A6 deliver.

At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I met Ford's newest vice-president of design, Moray Callum, in the late 1980s when he worked as a design consultant to Ghia, a design studio in Turin, Italy, owned by Ford. His very illustrious career there included working on the sweet 1989 Ghia Via concept and the exquisite Aston Martin Lagonda Vignale.

He took a real job at Ford in 1995, and his career there included a stint running Mazda global design when it was still part of the bulging Ford portfolio of car companies. His tenure in Japan influenced the 2005 Miata, the Mazda 3, the 2006 Mazda 5, and the 2007 CX-7 and CX-9, a whole row of extremely successful designs.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/E9krJQiZil0?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It was a big shocker when Ford's worldwide design boss, J Mays, "retired" last fall, and Moray was given the top spot. He remains his affable self, with a Scottish brogue so thick, you'll have to pay extra attention as he walks us around the new Mustang.
Oh, and yes, Jaguar's equally talented design chief, Ian Callum, is Moray's brother. When they get to talking to each other, no one understands them.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: Anyone who drives with a big dog in the back seat will want to give Nissan a pat on the head for inventing the Smart Rearview Mirror. The dog, too, will probably want to give it a happy lick. Here’s how driving with that dog goes now: "Sit down!” I say urgently to the dog who, although safely ensconced in the back of the car, is completely blocking the (already made too small by aerodynamic car designs) view out the back. I want to keep my eye on the neighborhood boys as they race past on bikes, but the dog has his own worries. “Huh, huh, huh?” he says, concerned by the urgency in my voice but struggling with that canine inability to sit still while the ground moves under him. He looms closer, now completely blocking my view.

Here's where Nissan's invention would save the day. With the flick of a switch, what looks like a normal rearview mirror instantly transforms into an LCD screen that shows everything, with no obstructions. How? It shows a feed from a high-resolution camera that's embedded in the back of the car, just above the rear window.

The Smart rearview mirror increases visibility even when the dog stays home, since it bypasses the glass of the rear mirror, which can fog up, get dirty, or be covered in ice or snow. And in some low-visibility conditions, the camera gets a better view than the mirror can, because it does a bit of image processing to reduce glare and enhance crispness. This subtitled video from Nissan shows how easily it works.
<iframe width="500" height="281" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/2yxHAj79kh8" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Nissan will officially introduce the Smart Rearview Mirror at the Geneva Auto Show this week. After that, it will be used in the company's Nismo racing car for the 24 Hours of Le Mans and will be a dealer-installed option on Japan-market Nissans this spring. It won't start reaching buyers elsewhere in the world until 2015. We can't wait.

title: Apple CarPlay
subTitle: iOS in the car is here. Hang up & drive, but with seamless ability to work that iPhone while you do.

pageElements.text: If you’re among those who rail against the distracting telematics in modern cars, look out. Apple has just announced CarPlay, which ties the company’s iPhone in to the automobile in ways only dreamed of in the recent past. Apple claims it will cut down on distraction, and let’s hope that’s true. The new setup will be an update to iOS 7 that will work with all the iPhone 5 family.
It will make its official debut this week at the Geneva Auto Show.

Yes, this is the "iOS in the Car" that people have been talking about for more than a year. The Google version for Android phones is reportedly almost here, too, and many tech blogs are breathlessly reporting that it will be called Projected Mode.

But the big news is that it's actually about to roll out on production cars you can buy. CarPlay will be introduced at the Geneva show this week in Ferrari, Volvo, and Mercedes-Benz cars first: Ferrari on the new California T convertible and the FF, Volvo on the all-new XC90 (photo below), and Mercedes on the C-Class (right). Many global auto companies will also have it “down the road,” Apple says, including BMW, Ford, General Motors, Honda, Hyundai, Nissan, Subaru, and Toyota, among others.

In participating vehicles, you simply connect your iPhone to the car’s interface, and you’ll be able to use Siri through the steering wheel’s voice control to ask questions, listen to messages and respond, and of course to make phone calls. It also works with Maps to give Siri-voiced turn-by-turn directions or to look at the route on your car’s screen.
Beyond the merely productive, you can also use CarPlay to gain access to all your iTunes stuff, including iTunes radio, podcasts, and music, and to Spotify and iHeart Radio apps.

In short, this is nothing you can’t already configure in your car, but not as seamlessly as this. Now, you will be making your iPhone part of the car, able to use it easily for everything you’d normally do with the addictive handheld.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: There's an important talk you probably haven't yet had, but should, with your young teenager.

Insurance agent Nathan Lamb cautions that parents should start thinking about, and budgeting for, teenage drivers when they turn fourteen, not sixteen. The jump is substantial, particularly if one buys into the American fantasy of a new car for Sweet Sixteen. It’s a lovely present, if you want to give yourself the companion gift of a huge premium increase at the same time.

Have a discussion with your teenager about all of the components that go into auto insurance, including the importance of a clean credit history.  You might need to explain credit scores.  Auto insurance provides a nice example of the relationship of credit history to other facets of adult life.  Remind them that good credit demonstrates responsibility; it also speaks to your character in your ability to pay your insurance premiums.  Good credit factors into lower premiums. Conversely, a bad credit score has real financial implications.
Here are a few choices you and your teenager need to make about how she or he will fit into your insurance plans.
For example, if I were I to add my sixteen-year-old to my policy with the Fiat 500 as my only car, the total cost of my insurance would increase 65 percent.

1. Add your teen to your own policy? Benefit: You can benefit from multi-vehicle discounts, if your insurer offers them, and the policy is based on your credit history and age, not just your teen's. Although you will note the vehicle your teen will use as his or her primary vehicle, like you, he or she is covered as an occasional driver on other cars as well. Downside: Your premium will go up for a few years, now that you’ve added a young and inexperienced driver. The number, of course, depends on the coverage you chose, but in my case, for example, were I to add my sixteen-year-old to my policy with the Fiat 500 as my only car, the total cost of my insurance would increase 65 percent. The increase takes into account the higher risk of an accident and the related claims associated with teenage drivers.

2. Get your teen his or her own policy? Benefit: Your own insurance rates won't be affected, and you won't be on the hook for any damage your teenager causes on your policy. Downside: It is more expensive to get a separate policy for each of you, and your teen's policy won't benefit from your own history and rates. Nathan cautions that this really is a last resort, one that occurs when the teen has had too many accidents or moving violations. The teen will be placed with a higher-risk insurer, which means much higher premiums.

3. Get your teen his or her own car? Nathan's advice: keep the old family car for the teen and give yourself the new one. It costs far less to insure a teen for a clunker than a shiny new Mustang. I’ll add that, two years ago, when I started talking to my Honda salesman about replacing my 2002 Odyssey, he advised me not to sell it or trade it in but to save it for my daughter, who was at that point fourteen. His argument: “You don’t want to be insuring a teenager on a new vehicle!”

Nathan echoed my salesman’s advice.  Again, in my case, were we to keep the ’02 Odyssey in addition to the Fiat and list Sarah’s primary vehicle as the Odyssey, my insurance will go up 57 percent, less than if I insured her on the Fiat alone.  Why?  I would keep the multi-car discount, and the resale value of an ‘02 Odyssey is far less than that of a '13 Fiat.

4. Establish responsibility. Since you are establishing parameters for your driving teen (who is responsible for paying for gas or routine maintenance), set your teen straight on accidents as well. Discuss how expensive they are, who pays for them, and how auto insurance works. If you are getting your teen his or her own car, you might consider limited collision. If your teen is in a wreck because of poor choices, the onus on fixing or replacing the car falls on him or her. Depending on the make and model year, you could be talking a couple of hundred dollars for a ding up to many thousands of dollars for major work. How you work this with your teen falls to parenting style. I asked Nathan what he was doing with his own upcoming teenage driver. He smiled and said, “She’ll be driving my old 2007 Camry. And if she wrecks it, she’ll be walking until she can afford to buy her own car. It’s a one-shot deal in our house.” That’s my kind of parenting as well, but every parent has to find his or her comfort zone. Determine that zone before an incident so your teen understands his or her responsibility.
5. Finally, don’t let your teen feel too entitled. A car is not a right; it is a privilege. That’s a good lesson to learn even at sixteen.

title: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 5 Tips
subTitle: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
promoTeaserSmall: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
promoTeaser: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
metaKeywords: shopping for a Certified Pre-Owned Car
metaDescription: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 5 Tips. Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: If you've shopped for a car in the past several years, you've surely heard about Certified Pre-Owned cars. Starting as a way to market higher-end used cars, the Certified Pre-Owned designation has now become commonplace at car dealerships. A Certified Pre-Owned (CPO) car is generally a car with a clean history, few past users, of relatively recent vintage, and with less than about 80,000 miles on the odometer. It undergoes an extensive pre-sale inspection, and problems are fixed before it's offered for sale. What's not to like? Of course, all of this means that your average CPO car is sold at a premium, but for the peace of mind you get, it is often well worth the cost.
If you are interested in a used-car purchase, here are five things to know about CPO.

1. Used cars aren't just for those who can’t afford new anymore. CPOs are increasingly popular among premium brands. For example, CPO sales of Audis have just set a seventh straight monthly record, with 3,161 certified used Audis sold in January 2014, compared with 2,843 one year earlier. Brands such as Mercedes-Benz, Jaguar, and Cadillac all have firmly established CPO programs, and even Porsche sold more than 800 CPOs in January 2014. If you want a high-end car but don't want to pay a high-end price, a Certified Pre-Owned car might be the ticket for you.

2. Don’t think of Certified Pre-Owned as simply a marketing gimmick. CPO sales were up fifteen percent last year, and the Manheim Used Car Market Report projects they’ll double by 2019 or even sooner. In January alone, more than 166,000 were sold in the U.S. market, while new-car sales dropped three percent. Clearly the concept is finding buyers, and with so many people leasing cars, dealers find themselves with an increasing quantity of reasonably “young” vehicles with one owner that are good candidates for a CPO sale. You could get a great deal on a low-mileage used car by taking advantage of that.

3. Understand all the benefits of a Certified Pre-Owned program. A benefit of CPO programs is that the car you're looking at will come with an extensive inspection report (more than 150 points are checked out under most CPO programs), and you’ll get a Carfax (or similar) report on the vehicle’s history. Read them!

You can often finance a CPO purchase at or close to the same low interest rates you'd get on a new-car purchase. Other perks: the power to take a car back within a specified time limit if you're not happy with it, and sometimes, a free loaner vehicle if your CPO purchase comes in for repairs at the dealership. And find out details about the roadside assistance that is usually offered. So much better than trusting someone you met on Craigslist.

4. Know that all CPO programs aren't alike. You need to understand where the Certified Pre-Owned designation is coming from. There are CPO programs that are run through the manufacturer, but dealerships sometimes offer their own, which are not as desirable: If the CPO program is through the manufacturer, not just the local dealership, any warranty repairs you do need can be performed anywhere around the country. That's a strong argument in favor of the automaker's program.

There are also CPO programs run by other entities. The Motor Trend Certified program, from our brother publication Motor Trend, is one. It partners with a limited number of dealerships around the country, offers Carfax reports for vehicle history, and throws in such goodies as key replacement and paint-shop blemish removal and six months' mechanical repair coverage. There are also CPO programs through the Enterprise car rental company, the National Independent Automobile Dealers Association (NIADA), and others.

5. Know the warranty details and potential hidden costs. A Certified Pre-Owned car often comes with two kinds of warranties: the powertrain limited warranty that the car had as new, which is continued for the new owner; and a warranty on problems that come up elsewhere on the car, which may or may not cost extra. The "certified" in the Certified Pre-Owned title can mean different things in different programs.

For example, a CPO from Ford comes with a twelve-month, 12,000-mile comprehensive warranty on a long list of components—the kind that older cars might tend to need replaced, such as the alternator, ball joints, air conditioning compressor, and power door locks. All good news! However, there’s a $100 warranty deductible for each visit to the shop.  For Toyota, the deductible on similar warranty coverage is $50; for Mercedes-Benz, it’s $0.

Dealerships and other CPO providers may also offer an extended warranty that you have to buy separately, which could be a substantial extra cost. Make sure you understand the terms, including the deductible, for repairs under the warranty, and whether any of the warranties are transferable should you sell the CPO car down the road.

contributors.bio:
My return to the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee during the Reagan era for a second bachelor’s degree accomplished two things: I made writing for a car magazine a career goal, and I met my future wife, though it took Donna two decades to come around to the latter idea. Over that quarter-century, I went on to write general assignment stories for the Milwaukee Sentinel, became a cop reporter, then schools reporter and film critic for the Quad-City Times, where I also covered Cary Grant’s death in Davenport, Iowa, and then I worked for the San Diego Business Journal, where I became an expert on the arcane America’s Cup Deed of Gift. When I moved to Washington, D.C., where I wrote about the Clinton health care reform plan and other Capitol Hill issues for an inside-the-beltway newsletter publisher, I thought I had found my true calling. Matt DeLorenzo convinced me otherwise, and I moved to Detroit in 1996 to work for AutoWeek. Four years later, Jack Keebler lured me to Motor Trend, where I wrote news and rumors about future cars, voted in a dozen (each) Car of the Year and Sport/Utility of the Year competitions, and blogged as the Motor City Blogman. Detroit is to the global auto industry what Washington is to national politics. It’s easily more fascinating and as frustrating to cover as a journalist. The commute is far more interesting.

My years at Motor Trend, working side-by-side with Technical Director Frank Markus, have been enormously fulfilling. I’ve become fully immersed in the nuts and bolts of cars, and the industry. You have to keep a love for cars and driving in perspective. For me, Donna, our two collies, and my family back in Wisconsin come first. I can be nearly as passionate about politics, movies and art, and the Green Bay Packers, of which I’m a shareholder. My favorite sport is still Formula 1, though.

Automobile is about living with cars, both the good ones and the bad ones, but most importantly, the most interesting ones. With autonomous cars on the near horizon, we face the greatest threat to our enthusiasm since the malaise and oil embargoes of the ‘70s, the era when I earned my driver’s license. With Jean, Joe and their crew, Automobile already has the best, most interesting writers to explain why you should put down that mobile phone and grab the steering wheel. I’m thrilled to become part of this team and I look forward to helping place the cars and the way we drive them in context.

pageElements.text: From the land of Swiss army knives and overpriced watches comes the 84th International Salon de l’Auto, every car fan's favorite show. The PalExpo here is neutral ground for cars, too, with no one nation dominating the compact, easy-to-walk dual halls, though a “bilingual” stand more often has French and German, not English, spoken first.

From the show stand's spokesmodels, you can usually tell the given automaker’s provenance. The Italian stands, Fiat, Alfa Romeo, Lancia, Maserati, and Ferrari, have unabashedly sexy spokesmodels in slinky black garb. The French are more elegant and, well, uniquely French. One model at the Peugeot stand even wore, somewhat stereotypically, a black beret as part of an art display for the new 108 supermini hatchback. At the Mini stand nearby, male and female stand personnel wore black derby hats, recalling Stanley Kubrick’s A Clockwork Orange as much as Old Blighty.

Would that Mini’s new product matched that film’s (or book’s) edginess; along with the new Audi TT in the adjacent hall, the Mini Clubman concept proved how hard it is to remain avant garde twelve or fifteen years after your original breakthrough. Like, say, a W Hotel, sometimes a renovation is simply a renovation.
Enter, then, the French. They provided two cars designed for quotidian use that truly make some breakthroughs. Here's a quick tour.

Small Family Car with Personality: Citroen C4 Cactus

Citroen showed a tarted-up “off road” all-wheel-drive version of its new wagonette, named the C4 Cactus Adventure. But the standard, production C4 Cactus would have been enough.

Based on the C4 line of four-cylinder compacts, the Cactus features a fresh and modern interior with good materials and padded door armrests, and Air Bump door panels: outer door panels are covered with soft, rubberized material to absorb impacts and door dings. The front passenger’s airbag drops from the headliner, freeing up the dashboard for a deep top-hinged glovebox. With a tasty choice of colors and trim options, buyers can get the Air Bump in colors contrasting or matching the paint.

Small Commuter Car with Personality: Renault Twingo

Mercedes-Benz, which in the 1990s teamed up with Swatch on the Smart project, has been trying to make the tiny city cars viable for nearly two decades. Now that Benz has teamed up with Nissan-Renault, the Smart formula is starting to click. Enter the third-generation Renault Twingo, which uses a version of the next Smart Fortwo/Forfour’s rear-engine/rear-wheel-drive platform. A choice of a 1.0-liter three-cylinder or optional 0.9-liter turbocharged three-cylinder hides under the cargo floor cover in back.

The rear seat on this four-door hatchback is tight, but there’s ample room in front. The Twingo is just 141.3 inches long on a 98-inch wheelbase, which is just 1.7 inches longer than the Fiat 500 two-door hatchback, although the wheelbase has 7.7 inches on the Italian model. As Automobile Magazine design editor Robert Cumberford put it, the third Twingo isn’t as groundbreaking as the first-generation car (which to be fair, cribbed on the Honda City Japanese domestic model of the early 1980s), but it’s far less boring and stupid than the second-generation car. The Twingo, for you Francophiles who know what it is, is back. Unfortunately, there’s no indication that Mercedes-Smart will sell anything like it in North America.

The Wagon Master is Back: Volvo Estate Concept

But is it still the safety master? Volvo showed its third concept to preview its next generation of cars, which retain front-wheel-drive layouts but with rear-wheel-drive proportions. The Estate Concept is a two-door wagon version of the Coupe Concept that stole the show at Frankfurt last September. It is designed to recall the 1800 ES two-door wagon of the 1960s, although if you picture it with four doors instead, you’ve got a pretty good idea of what Volvo’s next large wagon will look like.

The concept is full of Scandinavian design, including orange seatbelts for the two-plus-two seats, matching orange woven wool carpeting by Swedish designer Kasthall, an Orrefors/Kosta Boda crystal shift knob, and the Swedish game of kubb under the load floor, which is a transparent panel with the rules for the game printed on it. The disappointment with this car is that Volvo stuck a large tablet in the center of the dash, replacing most control knobs with touchscreen controls. Modern? Perhaps. Safe? I don’t think so.

Schreyer’s Fuel Cell Crossover: Hyundai Intrado

Bright star designer Peter Schreyer was promoted from head of Kia design to head of Hyundai and Kia design last year, and one of his first efforts is the Hyundai Intrado concept. It’s a bit wild, even for Schreyer, what with the fins protruding from the lower rear body. Orange is the new black at Geneva this year: many cars here use the color for paint, but the Intrado has a deep orange interior. Power is by a clean, compact fuel cell powerplant under the hood.

Never Has One Car Done So Much for So Few: Mercedes-Benz S-Class Coupe

Mercedes-Benz S-Class sedans don’t sell to many people beyond the one percent. Large luxury two-door coupes are far more rare than that. The new Mercedes-Benz S-Class Coupe is the brand’s most handsome car in years, even though few will see it in their garages. The lines are clean and sleek, and with its low roofline, the big coupe looks lithe parked between a couple of new S-Class sedans.

Premium Populism: BMW 2-Series Active Tourer/4-Series Gran Coupe

BMW unveiled its not-for-U.S. 2-series Active Tourer and failed to impress with this premium multipurpose vehicle, a kind of mini-minivan with no sporting pretensions beyond an optional M badge trim level. The new vehicle is based on BMW’s 1-series front-wheel-drive models, which share components with the Mini brand. It probably should be called a 1-series or maybe even a Mini. The BMW 4-series Gran Coupe is a more convincing Ultimate Driving Machine. The four-door hatchback matches the 6-series Gran Coupe's sleekness with the 5-series GT’s hatchback versatility. This one matters to you because BMW will bring it to the U.S.

Now with Less Quirkiness: Mini Clubman Concept

The Mini Clubman Concept ditches the first-generation Clubman’s rear suicide half-doors for four conventional doors while retaining the old Clubman’s barn-door rear hatch. Still, it looks too much like the kind of conventional compact wagon sold in the U.S. in the 1960s that are still common in Europe.

Style Leader Redux, Redux: Audi TT

The inherent problem with designing such a stunning breakthrough as the original Audi TT is, What do you do for an encore? And for a third? The third-generation Audi TT is a quite handsome car, and no doubt it will be a rewarding drive. Its lines are sharper and cleaner than the second generation’s, but most casual observers will have to look twice before figuring out which model it is.

Subcompact Zoom Zoom: Mazda Hazumi Concept

Mazda put the Zoom Zoom in its Hazumi concept, which previews the second-generation, 2015 Mazda 2. The new model is appreciably bigger than the first Mazda 2, which launched in North America for the 2011 model year, and gets the large grille and general design of the bigger Mazda 3 and Mazda 6 four-door models. The Hazumi also previews Mazda’s new 1.5-liter turbo-diesel four, powering the front wheels through a six-speed automatic transmission. The engine has not yet been confirmed for the U.S. market.

title: 2014 Buick Regal over Ice
subTitle: To Montreal and beyond in the new all-wheel-drive version of the classic Buick.
promoTeaserSmall: To Montreal and beyond in the new all-wheel-drive version of the classic Buick.
promoTeaser: To Montreal and beyond in the new all-wheel-drive version of the classic Buick.
metaDescription: 2014 Buick Regal over Ice: To Montreal and beyond in the new all-wheel-drive version of the classic Buick.  Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text:
2014 Buick Regal GS AWD

Price: $40,195 base price (including destination); $44,550 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 259 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Notable standard features on this model: Brembo front brakes, front and rear parking assist, traction and stability control, Bose premium audio with navigation, Buick IntelliLink infotainment system with Bluetooth connectivity and 8.0-inch driver information display, heated front seats
You might also be considering: Acura TSX, Audi A4, Lincoln MKZ, Volvo S60

My adventure with the Buick Regal AWD sedan started out brilliantly. I arrived in Montreal a night early, because New York City was on Polar Vortex alert. What I didn’t know was that Montreal was already in the midst of it. Our group spent the first night at the Montreal-Trudeau Airport's Marriott Hotel overlooking the landing strip, which is one of my favorite visual vistas.

The plan was to start out early the next morning driving to northern Québec for an overnight stay at the Fairmont Le Château Montebello, billed as the largest log cabin in the world. Our ultimate destination was the ice track at Circuit ICAR (International Center of Advanced Racing), where we would put the Regal’s prowess to the test.

Let me first explain that the reason we were on this snowy trip was to test out the Buick Regal’s new all-wheel-drive system. For 2014, the Regal, known as the athlete of the Buick sedan family, has added a turbocharged engine and all-wheel drive (the AWD models are priced starting at about $2,000 higher than the front-wheel-drive versions). In other words, the GM division has amped up the equation for driving enthusiasts. And Buick wanted to show us just what this car could do.

As I said, the conditions were less than perfect. It was snowy, icy, slippery, overcast, and bleak. I took the wheel first and have to admit that I was a wee bit unhinged by the weather. Dirt and slush kept spitting up from the highway making it hard to see clearly. Thankfully, my driving partner, Nik Miles, a Fox Morning News reporter, is my favorite type of navigator. He kept repeating directions to me. Instead of assuming that I’d remember that in twenty kilometers or so I should take Exit 35, he’d give me up-to-the-moment details. After a half-hour of getting used to the elements, I was in the groove. The car felt confident and grounded, and so did I.

Our first stop was Centre de Pêche Sportive, a small ice-fishing village with colorful wooden huts set up on the ice as a respite from the cold and wind. A group of us cocooned within a warm hut about the size of a large walk-in closet. It was blowing freezing winds outside, so we watched the fisherman through foggy windows while snacking on local cheeses and sugary homemade doughnuts. We were given the opportunity to catch and release (they cast for walleye, pike, whitefish, lake trout, or perch), but nothing was happening.

It was my first time visiting an ice village, so I did some research. Canadians have been gouging holes in ice for centuries. Ice fishing is practiced all over Québec, as soon as the layer of ice covering their rivers and lakes is thick enough to bore through…and drive cars on. The huts—some of which are equipped with conveniences including stoves —are moved to the shores during the summer.

After the “fishing” or snacking, Nik took the wheel and drove over a gray landscape of flat snowy roads to our next destination, the ice bridge, which is simply an iced-over ferry crossing. This was playtime, just to whet our appetites for the track. I took a few spins, handed the wheel to Nik, and got out of the car (so I wouldn’t get nauseous). We all had a laugh when Nik ended up getting our car embedded in a snowbank. A group of guys pushed him out, and we were good to go on the last leg of our trip.

We arrived at Le Château Montebello around noon. The strapping red cedar structure is built around a rotunda with a six-sided stone fireplace that rises more than sixty-six feet to the roof. Its rafters are crafted from sixty-foot logs, and two upper balconies circle the space. The spacious chateau has 211 guest rooms, including fourteen suites, in four wings, with additional wings for the dining room and ballroom.

The hotel's amenities include indoor and outdoor pools, a spa and fitness center, tennis courts, an eighteen-hole golf course, and more than sixteen miles of cross-country ski trails. We were offered the choice of cross-country skiing, dog sledding, ice skating, or snowshoeing.

Once we had wolfed our way through a three-course lunch, I decided to go for the dog sledding. A different mode of transportation indeed! No heated seats or shocks in this two-person sled; a blanket was our cozy covering from the elements. A team of gorgeous huskies ferried us through the silent woods on a bumpy, breathtaking, and stunningly quiet ride. I felt slightly heady from the whole experience.
Once back to earth, however, on the way back to the Château, I took a giant slide on the ice and landed flat on my rear end.

The next day was our turn to test the Regal on Circuit ICAR. We tried everything from schussing in and out of cones (autocross) to braking on black ice and driving around a circular ice skidpad track with traction/stability  both engaged and disengaged.
When driving on ice, you can drift or basically slide backward or sideways. The experience is exhilarating! The Buick Regal was tight, bright, and responsive.

When driving on ice, you can drift or basically slide backward or sideways. If you know what you’re doing and have a trainer, as we did, it’s a wonderful way of seeing how the vehicle can lose and gain control under different conditions. The experience is exhilarating! The Buick Regal was tight, bright, and responsive. Exactly what the automaker had promised.
We finished our track time by lunch, and I was back in New York City in time for dinner.
A brilliant beginning, middle, and end to the Buick Regal adventure.
A short history of the hotel:

In the late 1920s, Harold M. Saddlemire, a Swiss-American entrepreneur, acquired a portion of land along the Ottawa River. His dream was to create a private wilderness retreat for business and political leaders. The original project, "Lucerne-in-Québec," came to be known as the Seigniory Club. Despite the 1929 stock market crash, work on the planned wilderness retreat began on schedule in early 1930.

The project continued, most likely because the presidents of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the National Bank of Canada, the Bank of Montreal and the Royal Bank of Canada and the Premier of Québec, were all club directors. Construction and woodworking teams toiled around the clock using electric lighting at night. At the time, the church did not approve of working on the Sabbath. Perhaps to counteract this, the local curé was dispatched on an all-expenses paid trip to Rome for two months while the work continued.

3,500 laborers completed the job in four months and the club opened on July 1, 1930. Over the years, the resort has welcomed guests including Crown Prince Akihito of Japan, Harry S. Truman, Princess Juliana of the Netherlands, Bing Crosby, Perry Como, Bette Davis, and Joan Crawford.
To note: The Fairmont properties in the Québec province have installed electric vehicle charging stations in partnership with Hydro-Québec’s Electric Circuit.

title: Martina Loves Her 2004 Toyota Prius
subTitle: Life as an early adopter has been beautiful for a Hollywood makeup artist.
promoTeaserSmall: Life as an early adopter has been beautiful for a Hollywood makeup artist.
promoTeaser: Life as an early adopter has been beautiful for a Hollywood makeup artist.
metaTitle: Martina Loves Her 2004 Toyota Prius - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Martina Loves Her 2004 Toyota Prius: Life as an early adopter has been beautiful for a Hollywood makeup artist. Read her story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pageElements.text: I am helping Martina Kohl unload a handsome vanity from her car; somehow she has managed to fit the unwieldy piece of furniture into her beloved silver Toyota Prius. We lift the Art Deco table and mirror that she has purchased from a bankruptcy sale of the estate of Dr. Arnold Klein, the controversial dermatologist of the late Michael Jackson, and carry it into her home in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles.

Austria-born Martina is a prominent Hollywood makeup artist (but no, she never worked on Michael Jackson). She has performed her movie magic on faces belonging to Oscar winners John Travolta, Vanessa Redgrave, Ralph Fiennes, and Glenn Close. She’s also responsible for numerous temporary transfer tattoos on the FX TV series Sons of Anarchy.

Martina’s 2004 Toyota Prius hatchback, while tattoo free, was from the first batch of gasoline-electric hybrids that looked like Prii as we know them today, attractive and spacious.  When Martina first heard about the new model, she immediately ordered one.  She says, “I wanted something better for the environment and to make a difference.” Other Angelenos felt the same way, and there were waiting lists at all the Toyota dealers in the vicinity, some dealerships even insisting that prospective buyers place a $1,000 deposit to be entered onto their lists.  And pay and wait she did.  Martina requested the car in black, but while blues and reds cropped up, no one seemed to have a black Prius for her. So finally, after four months, she heard about a silver one at the Toyota dealer in the nearby city of West Covina and said she’d take it.
When she first drove the 2004 Toyota Prius, she’d notice people waving and signaling from nearby vehicles. "It was such a sensation then," Martina remembers.

When she first drove the Prius, she’d notice people waving and signaling from nearby vehicles.  She remembers: “There would be a car next to me pulling up, and I’d wonder, Why are they looking at me?  And they would point, and I would think maybe they wanted to get in the lane in front of me.  What do they want?  And they’d signal for me to roll my window down.  How strange!  Then they’d call, ‘How is your car?’  I realized I had something really special.  It was such a sensation then!”

Other drivers would have had good reason to suffer from Prius envy! For four years, the City of Los Angeles allowed hybrids free meter parking, and until 2011, the State of California even granted Martina’s car the privilege of traveling in carpool lanes with a single occupant, a benefit it still bestows on certain clean alternative-fuel vehicles.

As a makeup artist, Martina must transport herself not just to the studios but from location to location all over Southern California. Even though she is adamant that she purchased the car for environmental reasons rather than economical ones, she has definitely saved large sums of money on fuel in the decade since purchasing her Prius.
The standard mid-size car would have gulped roughly $11,700 worth of gas in ten years;  Martina’s Prius has sipped around $6,300 of fuel from the pump.

To find out just how much good she has done for the environment and her pocketbook, I contacted Toyota product specialist Maurice Durand.  He told me that with a standard car getting around 25 mpg and the 2004 Prius averaging 46 mpg, Martina’s car would have required roughly 1,650 fewer gallons of gas, having accumulated 90,000 miles over ten years.  Put into dollar figures, employing a conservative median price of  $3.25 per gallon, Martina has saved herself close to $5,400. The standard mid-size car would have gulped roughly $11,700 worth of gas in ten years;  Martina’s Prius has sipped around $6,300 of fuel from the pump.
And she reports that the car has been absolutely reliable, with no mechanical problems in the ten years she’s owned it.

While Martina says her vehicle is quiet, comfortable, and fun to drive, she finds herself doing something she had never done with previous cars, her last one being a Mercedes 300E. She says, “When driving, I now always look at my screen. Where am I with my mileage? What am I getting? You always watch the battery.”

Martina’s silver Prius, assembled in Japan, features a 1.5-liter engine that makes 76 horsepower and a continuously variable automatic transmission. The 2004 model garnered great results on safety tests—four or five stars on NHTSA crash tests—and although it takes ten seconds to accelerate from 0 to 60 mph, it comes with excellent regenerative braking and four-wheel ABS. Its four-door body seats five, and Martina’s vehicle has all-electric air conditioning, a six-speaker stereo, a navigation system, cruise control, power steering, remote keyless entry, a rear wiper, and the aforementioned energy monitor. Her car has front, front side, and side head curtain airbags. The Prius came with a 36,000-mile three year bumper-to-bumper warranty, with the hybrid component guaranteed for eight years or 100,000 miles. There is plenty of legroom, and the back seats fold down, so Martina can carry all sorts of objects, including the tools of her profession and an Art Deco vanity.

Martina has been a makeup artist for the good-looking passengers in a number of automobile commercials, including ads for Audi, Citroën, Dodge, Jaguar, Mini Cooper, Renault, Volkswagen, and Toyota (although not for a Toyota Prius).

Martina doesn’t always apply cosmetics to render people more attractive. Her latest picture, Low Down, just nominated for the Grand Jury Prize at the 2014 Sundance Film Festival, is a study of drug-addled and destitute denizens of the 1960s and 1970s jazz world. Martina needed to take such appealing and normally healthy-looking actors as Lena Headey, Elle Fanning, Peter Dinklage, John Hawkes, and Taryn Manning and create wan, mottled, and bumpy complexions.
But the silver complexion and healthy body of her 2004 Prius are holding up very well.

metaDescription: What I'm Driving:  Greetings from sunny Southern California, where I am shooting ten episodes of a new reality show. And look what I get to drive! Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Greetings from sunny Southern California! I moved to Seal Beach for six weeks, and not a moment too soon. In fact, it was quite a few moments later than I would have appreciated. I effected my escape from the Great White North two days after the thundersnow (three inches in an hour accompanied by thunder to rival a military exercise) and two days before Polar Vortex, Part Three, came down from the North Pole. Goodbye -35 degrees; goodbye, ice storm; goodbye, crumbled roadways.

I am working on a reality show from the talented Bunim-Murray team who bring us Top Chef and the Project Runway franchise, among many other of the genre so near and dear to Americans. This show is called Motor City Masters, and the ten-episode season will run on Turner’s truTV cable channel beginning in June. Motor City Masters is sponsored by Chevrolet, which provides cars as the basis for design challenges. The framework of the show is meant to do what my favorite Bunim-Murray productions do: focus attention on an area of interest that fascinates me; bring in talented, imaginative contestants with skills that I do not possess; add in knowledgeable judges and an interesting host; and then make crazy TV out it all by creating challenges that can be absurd, surreal, impossible, and so compelling that you can’t take your eyes off them.

image.altText: what i drove in la last weekend

pageElements.text: Of course there is weeping, wailing, and gnashing of teeth, or it wouldn’t be that special kind of real we know of as “reality.” I am loving it. To my left on most episodes, the host is actor Brooke Burns, a firecracker who made serious fame as a Baywatch girl and pinup favorite of the lad mags like Maxim. She is so much more than that, you should know. She is wickedly funny, nutty, can talk like a Munchkin without using nitrous oxide, and also happens to possess muscular arms, thighs, and calves that are the circumference of my ankles. A thinking man’s hottie. To my right is car designer Harald Belker, living proof that Germans can be laugh riots. Apparently, they have to be from Dusseldorf. He worked at Porsche and Mercedes before following in Syd Mead’s footsteps to Hollywood, working on cars for the first Transformers movie and cars for Minority Report, Ironman, Batman, and more. Here's a look at my dressing room.

Brooke is close to six feet tall in her cruel shoes, I am six feet tall, and Harald is a solid 6”7,” making me look like a delicate flower. The three of us are thick as thieves, and driven like a northeast wind.
I have a month to go, and I'm trying like hell not to ruin my driving record.  I’m holding out for one killer late-night blast down an empty Long Beach Freeway.

image.altText: what i drove in la last weekend

pageElements.text: At the end of the thus far long, long days of filming, I walk to my parking spot, where a spanking yellow Chevrolet Corvette Stingray is waiting—the perks of being the editor of a national car magazine and a judge on a show sponsored by Chevy. It is still as rare as hen’s teeth out in the real world. I’m not the only one excited about it. I was pumping gas, and a guy came over to ask me about my “Lamborghini.” Tough guys cruising Long Beach the other night slid next to me on the Pacific Coast Highway, where I waited for a light, and gave me the nod. A mom in a Buick Enclave stopped me as I entered my apartment to say her daughters were going crazy for my car.

Me, too. The brilliant nav system and pretty decent (but occasionally flawed) voice-activated Bluetooth phone are about all I’ve used in my freeway commute. Not that there are a lot of cars (there are, in fact, a lot of cars), or that I was driving in the middle of the torrential downpour that began this week’s horrendous nationwide snowstorm. It’s that I have a month to go, and I'm trying like hell not to ruin my driving record. I’m holding out for one killer late-night blast down an empty Long Beach Freeway.
More on the Corvette—and Motor City Masters—as my month unrolls before me.

title: Best and Worst from Geneva
subTitle: Hits, misses, and a revelation about how the 1% think, from Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
promoTeaserSmall: Hits, misses, and a revelation about how the 1% think, from Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
promoTeaser: Hits, misses, and a revelation about how the 1% think, from Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
metaTitle: Best and Worst from Geneva - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Best and Worst from Geneva: Hits, misses, and a revelation about how the 1% think, from Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Vanity would have me believe you’re reading this because you’re a devoted fan of my writing. In that case, you may want to know that I also edit the magazine’s Ignition section, read lots of Kurt Vonnegut, and would eat sushi at every meal if it were socially acceptable. Reality tells me you just want to know how I landed this amazing job. Fine. Based on my experience, here’s some advice.

1) Major in journalism. Most of us here aren’t racecar drivers -- we’re writers and reporters. It probably helps if you’ve attended journalism school, as I did at the University of Maryland, or worked for some periodical. That said, deputy editor Joe DeMatio now claims he was more intrigued by my second degree in Jewish studies, even though he’s never once asked me to write about the exploits of Simon bar Kochba.
2) Know how to operate a manual transmission. Seems obvious, but I actually did not upon being hired. I taught myself during my first month on the job by visiting six Ann Arbor dealerships to test drive stick-shift economy cars. My sincere apologies to whoever ended up buying that Ford Focus.
3) Learn everything you can about cars. I grew up pouring over car magazines and memorizing zero-to-sixty times as if they were catechism. People have been asking me for car-buying advice since before I could drive.
4) Realize you actually know nothing about cars. A brief conversation with design editor Robert Cumberford, editor-in-chief Jean Jennings, or any other of the veterans here leaves you humbled and astounded by their wealth of automotive knowledge. It’s truly one of the best parts of working here.
5) Be persistent. I wrote to Automobile’s editors. And called. And wrote them some more.
6) Be lucky. I really have no idea why then deputy editor Joe DeMatio answered my unsolicited voicemail. I hadn’t even pronounced his name correctly (it’s De-MAY-shee-oh, not De-MAH-tee-oh). But he did, and here I am, driving cars and writing about them for my devoted fans.

pageElements.text:
Hit: Mazda 2

The Hazumi concept, which will be the Mazda 2 just as soon as it grows real door handles and mirrors, is yet another handsome execution of the Kodo design language. Like the 3 and 6, it looks more like a rear-wheel-drive European car than a front-wheel-drive Japanese car. That’ll be a huge advantage for the new 2 here in Europe, where the B-segment is more significant than any other.

For the U.S. market, the most significant change in the 2 will be its point of assembly. The car will be built at Mazda's new factory in Mexico, which has recently started churning out North American Mazda 3s. That should insulate the brand from sharp currency changes.

Miss: BMW 2-Series Active Tourer

Unlike many of my colleagues, I’m not prejudiced against front-wheel-drive cars, even from sporty brands. I recognize that BMW needs the profits and sales volumes that only front-wheel-drive cars can earn so that it can subsidize ambitious investments like Project i and playthings like the M3.

That said, I am having a lot of trouble warming up to this front-wheel-drive car. The cab-forward proportions and tall roofline scream “dumpy utility vehicle.” Perhaps BMW designers should spend some time studying the Mazda Hazumi concept, which looks more like a BMW than this vehicle. The name adds insult to injury, muddying the already confusing split between the brand’s odd-numbered sedans and even numbered coupes/four-door coupes.

Hit: Infiniti Q50 Eau Rouge

Infiniti got a lot of attention by stuffing the GT-R’s 3.8-liter twin-turbo V-6 between the front fenders of the Q50. Now comes the inevitable question: will it reach production? Infiniti CEO Johan de Nysschen indicates that the will is certainly there.
“Look, if we were run as a dictatorship, we’d be building it now,” he says.

It’s finding a way that could be very difficult. The biggest challenge may be finding a transmission that can handle 443 pound-feet of torque (the GT-R’s rear-mounted transaxle would be a tough fit in the Q50). Infiniti's de Nysschen adds that he doesn’t want to “run out…and buy an expensive transmission,” such as the seven-speed automatic that partner Mercedes-Benz employs in the V-12-powered S65 AMG. Then the engine would need to be extensively retuned to work with a different transmission.
“That's why it has not been done before: It's not easy," he says.
Still, there’s a compelling case for Infiniti, which has struggled for two decades to establish itself as a first-class luxury brand, to go ahead with the ambitious project.

Hit: Obscenely Expensive Tchotchkes

What separates the Geneva Motor Show from most others is the presence of real, live rich people. Every brand makes sure to offer this clientele something absurdly expensive to take home, even if they decide not to put down a deposit on a Gumpert Explosion. Can I interest you in a 10,000 Euro scale model of a Bugatti Atlantic? Or, perhaps, Porsche swim trunks for 131 Swiss francs ($148)?

Revelation: Luxury Is Excess (Or Is It the Other Way Around?)

Silly as all these extravagances seem to us regular folks, they provide important insight into what real luxury is. No one needs a luxury car, certainly not when your average Kia or Volkswagen comes loaded with premium features. The key to getting people to spend more on a car is not some special paint color or a branded infotainment system but rather, the sense that the car is a pure reward.

title: 2015 Nissan Juke at Geneva
subTitle: Refreshed crossover is just as quirky as ever, now with the ability to personalize with added color.
