pageElements.text: Where do you stand on the appearance of Nissan’s quirky crossover, the Juke? We trod that ground earlier this year, trying out the “mutt ugly” looks of the Juke on Ray the Stray, who begged to differ.

If Ray liked the old Juke, imagine what he’ll say about this updated version, which made its debut last week at the Geneva Motor Show. U.S.-market Juke details aren’t out yet, but we can surmise from this Euro Juke that it will be highly tempting for those of you who want something truly different from the average. It goes on sale in Europe in the summer.

You’ll be able to find this in the parking lot, all right! Nissan has given the little crossover a new Rogue/Qashqai-style V-shaped grille, LED headlamps integrated into the daytime running lamps, and Xenon lower headlamps, plus a redesigned lower fascia. The taillamps are boomerang-shaped LED lights, and the lower rear fascia is new, too.

Once you’re inside, you’ll appreciate the the NissanConnect telematics, the Around View monitor with its four cameras so you can park anywhere with ease, and the (optional) sunroof that opens, sliding up and back over the top of the vehicle so it doesn't cut into headroom inside.

There are personalization packages available with contrasting colors for the mirrors, side sills, door handles, and roof-mounted spoiler.  For the inside, personalization packs let you change colors on the center console and door trim, making it red, white, black, or yellow. A set of optional eighteen-inch wheels are available with five-spoke inserts that match the personalization color you select.

The Juke's Safety Shield package offers up-to-the-minute safety features including lane departure and blind spot warning, as well as moving object detection to make you aware (though visual and sound cues) of the presence of bicyclists, pedestrians, or other possible collision dangers.
On a more prosaic level, there’s more than 40 percent increased space for luggage and gear (up to 12.5 cubic feet on the two-wheel-drive version).

title: Crash Test Live
subTitle: Ever want to see a car smashed into a barrier, with a dummy at the wheel? Us, too! Ford invited us.
promoTeaserSmall: Ever want to see a car smashed into a barrier, with a dummy at the wheel? Us, too! Ford invited us.
promoTeaser: Ever want to see a car smashed into a barrier, with a dummy at the wheel? Us, too! Ford invited us.
metaDescription: Crash Test Live: Ever want to see a car smashed into a barrier, with a dummy at the wheel? Us, too--and Ford invited us.

pageElements.text:
Photos by Molly Jean

Cross another one off the bucket list: I got to see a real live crash test. Call me weird, but I have kind of always wanted to see a brand-new car smacked into a wall with a crash test dummy seated behind the wheel, and Ford invited me to do just that. It was partly in celebration of the automaker’s 20,000th (!) live crash test, dating back to 1954, and partly to celebrate a 50 percent increase in the computer power Ford is dedicating to the study of crash data.

It was fascinating to meet some crash test dummies up close, although it was extremely jarring (and loud) to watch a 2014 Ford Explorer smacked head-on into a rigid barrier at 30 mph. But it was also very informative, and here are five questions I got answered while having the experience.

1. Do they really have to wreck actual vehicles?

Yes! That’s the best way to get accurate and useful data that ensures that worldwide safety standards are met. But Ford does about 10,000 computer simulations, like the one shown in the video clip below, for every live crash. The computer simulates tests of roof strength and safety systems as well as front, side, and rear impact crashes. Each simulation measures two million elements, which is up from 500,000 only five years ago. Simulations also let the automaker check out various vehicle designs to see how they work out for safety.

2. How many crash tests do they do at Ford?

Worldwide, Ford has crashed more than 31,000 cars. The company has a team of more than 500 engineers dedicated to safety, and there are crash test labs in Germany, Australia, and Brazil as well as the one in Dearborn, Michigan, where the Explorer shown here met its fate. At Ford’s Crash Barrier Building, they crash two or three cars a day—up to 800 a year.

The types of tests include the one we saw, a perpendicular front impact into a rigid barrier at 30 mph, but also overlap, offset, and side impact tests, including vehicle side impacts into a rigid pole.

3. How do the engineers gather information—other than from looking at the smashed-up front end?

The Ford team can download all the test data from a crashed vehicle within thirty minutes from impact—a much better use of modern computer speeds than Angry Birds, don’t you think? Each crashed car has a plethora of switches, accelerometers, and high-speed digital video cameras on board to give up to thirty views of a single test, which will be slowed down for analysis. In fact, we were shown a Science Fair in Hell table covered with a tangle of intimidating-looking data devices of the type they use.

Up to 300 data channels from “data acquisition electronics” are carried on the test vehicle; they measure acceleration, force, and displacement. Obviously, all of them are “sophisticated, crash-hardened devices,” in the words of test operations engineering supervisor Jerome Ng, so the equipment can be reused on future tests. In fact, they’re packed to be able to survive shocks up to 100 G in force.
There was an unmistakable feeling of geek camaraderie in the building: smart people breaking up perfectly good new vehicles in quest of knowledge.

4. What do they learn from the dummies, beyond checking to see if their heads were knocked off?

The dummies are not just department-store mannequins, which is obvious, but did you realize that even their clothing and shoes meet specific test standards? They are stuffed with instrumentation from head to toe—with up to 100 instruments inside a single dummy, including sensors and accelerometers—and tested and certified for consistency before they ever ride inside a crash-test vehicle. Ford has a fleet of more than 100 crash test dummies, ranging from a three-year-old to a 95th percentile adult male.

5. What are all the markings on the dummies and cars?

The one I immediately wondered about was the artistic splatter-paint finish on the Explorer. Ng explained that the shiny surface of a brand-new Ford Explorer would make it hard to see body deformation, dings, or other damage in a crash test—thus the mottled, matte-finish paint job. The markings on the crash vehicle were more obvious: identifying numbers on the sides, tire pressures on the wheel wells, and painted-on markings as points of reference when pre- and post-crash changes to the vehicle are being checked. And then, on the dummies, there’s paint in areas where the dummy might make contact with a surface, so it’s easy to see what smacked into what.

images.caption: Senior editor Molly Jean (second from right) with Ford's crash test dummy family.
Something tells me this car and this handsome dummy face are going to go through some changes.
Goodbye, 2014 Ford Explorer! Photos by Molly Jean.
Jerome Ng, supervisor of full data testing, stands where the Explorer will soon be making impact.
Markings and swirly paint job help Ford figure out exactly what's happening to the vehicle body on impact.
That's not just a ribcage: it's a plethora of safety measurement equipment.
Here is a bunch of Ford's data-gathering equipment.
The poignant post-crash raised hand position of the driver dummy will no doubt be measured and quantified by Ford's team.

pageElements.text: My little outing to the Crash Barrier Building was good fun, but it was also immensely reassuring to see the graphic evidence that automakers are this focused on safety. Of course they are not doing it out of missionary zeal but because they have standards they are required to meet—what Ford’s global auto safety director, Steve Kenner, called “the global regulatory environment.” But there was also an unmistakable feeling of geek camaraderie in the building: smart people breaking up perfectly good new vehicles in quest of knowledge. Now that I’ve crossed that crash test off my bucket list, I have a new daydream, one in which I hear one of my kids tell me, “I want to smash up brand-new cars for a living.”

title: The Women of Mustang
subTitle: Don't think a pony car is a women's car? Oh, how sadly wrong you are.
promoTeaserSmall: Don't think a pony car is a women's car? Oh, how sadly wrong you are.
promoTeaser: Don't think a pony car is a women's car? Oh, how sadly wrong you are.
metaDescription: The Women of Mustang: Don't think a pony car is a women's car? Oh, how sadly wrong you are. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: In honor of National Women’s History Month, today only (Wednesday, March 12), Ford is inviting you to submit questions for the women of the current Mustang team via Twitter. Here’s the link.

It was a Mad Men world back when the first Ford Mustang came out, fifty years ago. Even without the visual evidence of the mid-1960s ads you see here, you could just imagine the macho imagery of advertising for the first pony car, and you’d be absolutely right. "A car to make weak men strong and strong men invincible!"

So it’s especially funny that the very first 1964-1/2 Mustang was purchased by…Gail Wise, a woman from Chicago. Not just a woman, but an elementary school teacher. Then in her early twenties, she traded in her mom's Chevy, putting down the $3,419 two days before its official on-sale date and becoming the first owner of a production Mustang. (And she’s still got the car, a convertible in Skylight Blue with Rally Pac instrumentation and the 260-cubic-inch V-8, now restored.)
It’s not surprising that Ford didn’t make a lot of noise about that fact at the time.
But they made almost a million Mustangs in the first model year, and we’re betting there were a lot more young guys than female school teachers in the buying demographic.

Guys like my dad, Frank Brown, who bought a white ’65 coupe when I was in elementary school myself and he was in his mid-thirties. He couldn’t resist the Mustang’s charms—but then, neither could Mary Jean Wesche, editor of the Mustang Club of America’s Mustang Times. She says she “absolutely fell in love with the car” the minute she spotted it on display at the 1964 World’s Fair. Mary Jean has been a Mustang lifer ever since

In the 1980s, perhaps the woman most associated with the Mustang was Lyn St. James, who raced them. “I’m a product of the muscle car era,” she says, but she pronounces the modern Mustangs “still hot.”

Over the years, the Mustang has been a quintessential hot American car. It may be about to turn fifty, but Ford is to be commended for changing with the times and making an utterly modern new 2015 Mustang that people of any gender can lust after.
Ford is to be commended for changing with the times and making an utterly modern new 2015 Mustang that people of any gender can lust after.

With all of that in mind, Ford can be forgiven for a little woodenness in the way it is pursuing the female demographic. For example, there’s the commemorative nail polish from OPI, a subsidiary of COTY, in Race Red—launching internationally in July. OPI’s co-founder, Suzi Weiss-Fischmann, made the statement that “For women, cars and nail lacquer offer a way to express personality.”

But we’ll let Mustang vehicle line director Marcy Fisher—or Mustang vehicle integration supervisor Michele Lubin Henney—or chief color and materials designer Susan Lampinen—or U.S. Mustang brand manager Melanie Banker “express personality” instead, OK? These women, posing with the 2015 Mustang at the top of this page, understand the athleticism and performance that a Mustang is all about. They’re integral parts of the team bringing it to market. And they’re only the latest in a fifty-year history in which women have been engineers, designers, executives—and customers—of the Ford Mustang.
Kind of makes you want to paint your nails Race Red and hit the gas, doesn’t it?

images.caption: "Sweetheart of the Supermarket Set," eh? Ford's marketing efforts toward women have improved since then.
Desmond (left) and Wolfgang (right) found their Y chromosomes after buying a Mustang. These are actually smart and funny ads for their time.
Mustang team is anchored by Marcy Fisher, Michele Lubin Henney, Susan Lampinen, and Melanie Banker.
Race Red nail polish: okay, joking aside, this is pretty cool.
Ford is working hard to target women for its new Mustang.
The 2015 Ford Mustang: it's still got it.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: For the second time in the past three years, GCH Irish's Robert Garcia De Padua was accepted at the prestigious Westminster Kennel Club dog show. Not to beat a dead horse (although I am still irked), but it would have been three for three if husband Tim hadn't gone cheap with mailing the entry last year and used FedEx instead of the USPS, which delivered our critical entry form one day too late.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/6GTqXS7pxIY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Okay, let's be brutally honest. I used to believe that entering Westminster is a total waste of time and money if you are not a breeder. But I've come to believe that this isn't a breeders' show: it's a show for professional dog handlers.

If there is doubt, watch Westminster on television and listen to the color commentator. After explaining that the judging is all about the dog and its perfection of form and personality (or lack thereof), he never fails to carry on most of the telecast about the handlers—where they've worked, how many times they've won best in show and on which dogs.

It makes perfect sense. In the byzantine world of showing dogs, the basic training ground for becoming a (paid) judge is to working up through the ranks as a professional handler. Perhaps not all, but certainly a majority of dog show judges have been handlers. And it's not uncommon to find someone judging a dog being handled by a former employee.

Despite knowing it is so, despite seeing it and experiencing it for Bob's five years on the show circuit, despite knowing that it will be like watching Russian figure skating judges at work, we still go to Westminster because it's still Westminster and we think Bob's perfect in every way. The phrase used in the dog show world to describe the myopic attitude is "kennel blind."
Bob the Reluctant Show Dog showed in Auburn, Indiana, last weekend, so people could go to a dog show and then go on to the fabulous Auburn-Cord-Duesenberg Museum.

Bob is the second highest-ranked Grand Champion Chesapeake Bay retriever in the state of Michigan. He is currently 106 points away from the 400 points he needs to earn the ultimate Gold Grand Champion status.
Hope you enjoy our own like "Best in Show" documentary.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: January of one of the worst winters in decades, and the unthinkable happens: a Saturday morning phone call, a death in the family, and we need to drive to Washington, D.C., immediately.

Three children and I, a week's worth of luggage, and the dog were not all going to fit in the Fiat 500, and the ’02 Odyssey needed servicing that couldn’t happen on such short notice, so we decided to rent another minivan for the drive.

At the counter, I blithely declined the insurance Hertz was offering, having recently sorted out my auto insurance, and my Hertz agent was not pushy, given the bereavement situation.  Yet, on the return leg, as I was driving on the Ohio Turnpike in some of the worst conditions I have ever experienced—a highway covered in snow, whiteout visibility, and the side of the road littered with cars and semis having hit ice and one another—I wondered, with a slight pit in my stomach, about the “loss of use” policy I had heard an agent hawking to a young couple next to me at the Hertz counter. My first phone call on my return was to my agent, Nathan Lamb, to talk about insurance and car rentals.  Here are five questions I had answered.

1. What is covered by your own insurance when you drive someone else’s car or a rental car?

If you have comprehensive coverage, your insurance policy extends to any car you are driving: your personal vehicle, your friend’s pickup truck, or the cute little convertible you chose to rent on your weekend getaway. Damage to your friend’s pickup would be covered by his policy; your policy covers you for your liability while driving his car. The cute convertible? You will have the same coverage for the rental convertible that your policy provides for your own car. It's a good idea to check your car insurance policy to make sure before you rent.

2. What about “loss of use” coverage?

“Loss of use” extends above and beyond most people’s insurance. While your personal policy will provide you the same coverage for an accident in a rental car that it would for your own vehicle, it does not cover the losses the rental car agency experiences by having one of the cars in their fleet out of service. They can’t rent out a car that is in the shop, hence “loss of use.” “Loss of use” policies offered by the rental car agency protect you against the daily charge, which varies by vehicle, that rental agencies charge to recoup their losses while the rental vehicle is out of commission. That charge can be as much as $100 per day. The rate you would pay for “loss of use insurance” is calculated by the number of days for which you rent the vehicle. If it’s $8 a day, and you are looking to rent the car for ten days, you are adding $80 onto your rental bill. That might seem a little steep, but Nathan pointed out that this winter many body shops have two-to-three-week wait. We had a foot of snow while we were in the Washington area, and Virginia drivers are not known for their winter driving skills. What if the person sliding through that stop sign had actually hit me? It may have been a small dent, but the body shop could have taken fifteen days to get to it. Suddenly, I could have been looking at $1,500 to the rental car agency for “loss of use,” even though the accident wouldn’t have been my fault. $80 seems like a bargain compared with the $1,500 I could have been out. Nathan’s recommendation: always get the “loss of use” insurance.

3. How old do I have to be to rent a car?

We recently did an article about millennials renting vehicles to test them out for lifestyle fit. Note that those drivers were in the twenty-five-to-thirty-four-year-old age range. Many agencies do not rent to drivers under twenty-five, a policy that gave me fits two decades ago as my driving record was spotless compared to my “responsible” friends a couple of years ahead of me. If the agencies do rent to younger drivers or allow the second driver to be younger, most require the driver to be at least twenty-one, and the price for those in the under-twenty-five bracket is higher than for those twenty-five and above. There are some benefits to getting older.

4. Who can drive the rental vehicle?

Typically, any driver who is not a spouse or a domestic partner should be listed on the rental contract. That said, rental companies often require verification of licenses for all drivers, including spouses or domestic partners. Moreover, some companies charge an additional fee for additional drivers, but that varies by company and state law. Additional drivers must meet the minimum age requirements. There go my sixteen-year-old daughter’s dreams of getting in some highway driving in the rental car when we do the East Coast college tour in April.

5. Are bereavement rates a decent savings?

I was actually at a hockey tournament in Downriver Detroit when I received that phone call, so my dear and savvy friend Simone took care of arranging the rental car details for me. She discovered that many of the national rental agencies offer bereavement fares. You have to be a direct relation and be prepared to have the name of the deceased and the hospital or coroner’s information. It may be the last information you want to think about at times like this, but the savings are substantial.

We made it back safely from our unexpected January journey east.  Indeed, the Dodge Caravan was akin to driving a tank, and, as much as I love my Fiat, I’m glad we weren’t driving her during the whiteout on I-90. Next time I rent a car, I’ll think of the multitude of accidents we saw that day, and when the agent asks me about insurance, I’ll say “yes” to “loss of use” and drive off the lot comforted by the fact that I’m fully covered.

Want even more detail? The Insurance Information Institute offers this video explaining the types of coverage you'll be offered at the rental counter.

)

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. pageElements.text: When you sit in the driver’s seat of the all-new 2015 Audi A3, as I just did, you could easily miss how tech-laden this car is. There aren’t a lot of dials or screens. In fact, the look is spare and minimal. Turn on the engine, and a screen pops up offering route guidance. Still, nothing here screams pencil protector and nerdy glasses. But the technology is there, integrated into the car in a way that’s probably a bit of a historical moment in car design. There is a good reason this car was launched officially in Silicon Valley, heart of technology, and just a stone’s throw from Google, which was a partner in the development of this car.
A reasonably informed nerd might assume the machine being made here is a slick gaming tablet rather than a sweet ride: Nvidia, Google, ATT, and Qualcomm were in on it.

Take a look at the tech companies Audi partnered with on the A3. A reasonably informed nerd might assume the machine being made here is a slick gaming tablet rather than a sweet ride: Nvidia, Google, AT&T, and Qualcomm were in on it. The technology is baked quietly into the vehicle, not riveted on after the fact. But you will know it’s there when you use it.
As a tech geek, I love to see this much technology in my ride. So let me introduce you to technologies that make this car worthy of a Silicon Valley launch.

From Qualcomm: Gobi 4G/LTE Modem

Got a smartphone? There is a good chance, then, that you hold one of Qualcomm’s products in your hand every day. This company makes the Snapdragon processors and modems that power some of the most powerful smartphones on the market. The A3 has the newest Gobi 4G/LTE modem.

Your next question is probably, “Why?” Does my car need to connect to the Internet if I have a smartphone? Yes, it does, for reasons that make this car future proof: Want to connect your laptop, tablet, and whatever else you or your family uses to access the information superhighway while you fly down the tarmac superhighway?

This modem creates a fast Wi-Fi hotspot in the car and lets passengers connect up to eight devices. But that’s not the only reason. When a car can connect to the Internet to update its own software and maps, it won’t ask you to plug in a USB dongle or take it to the dealer to do that. And you won’t ever have to suffer outdated maps or technology. The car can do small, frequent updates the same way your phone does.

So, as the Internet of things evolves, your connected car can update itself to keep up, connecting to your house, your phone, other cars, parking structures, and the rest of the world. Connected! It’s what computers—be they desktop, laptop, tablet, phone, toaster, or sexy sedan—like to be.

From AT&T: The Data Connection

AT&T is providing the data connection to that Gobi modem, making the A3 the first car on the streets to have a 4G/LTE connection. (There are other cars following quickly, including all cars with OnStar.) And that means that after a six-month free trial period, when you will no-doubt become completely dependent on having data in the car, you’ll have to buy your car a data plan. Audi and AT&T will offer two options: a 5GB six-month plan for $99 or a 30GB thirty-month plan for $499.

From Nvidia: The Graphics Processor

Ask any teenager what the difference is between your perfectly adequate work computer and the one he or she covets for playing high-end graphical games. The answer is likely to be “an Nvidia graphics processor.” These little microchips handle high-speed, ultra-rich displays without choking or making you wait. That means the A3’s in-dash display will deliver detailed, intricate graphics that can keep up with the apps and services you will want to display there.

From Google: The Mapping

This machine is connected, has a data feed, and is capable of high-speed graphics processing? That makes Google Maps Street View and Google Earth possible right in that pop-up display. Because isn’t that where you want to keep your maps? In the car? Yes. You are driving a computer.

pageElements.text: On this Pi day (3/14), you can be sure that math teachers around the country are celebrating the day by serving pie (fruit or pizza variety) to their students and playing pie-related games. It's not just an excuse to have treats. These hard-working public servants know their game theory: make math fun, interesting, and an "in" thing, and more kids will want to go further in the subject.

Two auto companies are going to a deeper level to make mathematics interesting to students: Toyota has a professional development program for teachers to help them be better at bringing future technologists along, and Nissan has invited high-school girls to a science and technology event called DigiGirlz.
On this Pi day, it's a perfect time to appreciate the many new opportunities that students are getting, thanks to involved automakers.

We at Jean Knows Cars are all in favor of the more DigiGirlz, the better, because it's a science-and-math-dominated world out there, and women need to have a central place in it. Here are some inspiring details about these two initiatives, to savor while enjoying a slice of, well, you know.

Nissan DigiGirlz

On March 2, Nissan invited 100 high-school girls to its Nashville, Tennessee, headquarters for an event (shown here) that was co-sponsored with Microsoft and the area's Middle Tennessee State University. The event was intended to entice the students toward careers in the STEM fields (science, technology, engineering, and math). The students got to rub elbows with members of Nissan's Women's Business Synergy Team and other members of the automaker's staff.

This is part of a larger diversity initiative by Microsoft, which runs two-day technology workshops around the country and in India, Bulgaria, and Egypt for female students interested in STEM studies. Microsoft's aim is "to dispel stereotypes of the high-tech industry," but there's no doubt that a program like this could be the extra push girls need to continue their technological educations.

Toyota's STEAM Initiative

This one is close to my heart, because Toyota is involved in a new kindergarten through eighth grade STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics) magnet school, to open next year right here in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Also, as we speak, two of my children's teachers from middle school are in a group visiting Singapore on a study tour sponsored by Toyota Motor Sales. This is the fifteenth year that Toyota's STEAM program, previously called the Toyota International Teacher Program, has sent teachers to other countries to expand their knowledge about science and technology education.

Toyota has also sent teachers to Japan, the Galapagos Islands, Costa Rica, and South Africa to expand their horizons about teaching on math, science, and environmental topics. The automaker says it's motivated by "the critical need to invest in the professional development of STEAM educators in order to develop a pipeline of students that will meet the workplace demands of tomorrow." (I already thought my kids' technology teacher Mr. Pachera and math teacher Mrs. Newing were awesome, but this focused study trip can only help.)

Toyota's Technical Center is located here in Ann Arbor, with 800 engineers and technicians among the 1,250 employees—and a projected 30 percent increase in the need for qualified employees in the coming few years. If you want to see future technology superstars in their incubation phase, check out the balloon cars built by fifth-grade girls in this video from Ann Arbor's Lakewood Elementary, learning about Newton's second law with a little help from visiting Toyota engineers.

On this Pi day, it's a perfect time to appreciate the many new opportunities that students are getting, thanks to involved automakers, to become full participants in the technological future.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. title: How Much Do Rearview Cameras Help?
subTitle: Are they effective in preventing accidents? Insurance Institute for Highway Safety checked it out.
promoTitle: How Much Do Rearview Cameras Help?
promoTeaserSmall: Are they effective in preventing accidents? Insurance Institute for Highway Safety checked it out.
promoTeaser: Are they effective in preventing accidents? Insurance Institute for Highway Safety checked it out.
metaTitle: How Much Do Rearview Cameras Help? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A recent IIHS study on the effectiveness of backup cameras illustrates that the technology does help reduce the risk of rear pedestrian collision. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Rearview cameras are widely regarded as one of the more essential safety features and technologies on new vehicles. Research suggests that rearview cameras do decrease the risk of backup collisions, and the National Highway Traffic Safety Transportation (NHTSA) added the technology to its list of recommended features in its safety ratings last September. Yet when the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) tested whether rearview cameras help drivers avoid "backover" crashes into pedestrians, the results were less than conclusive.

According to the new list, backover accidents kill 292 people and injure 18,000 every year, even though backup cameras and parking sensors have become available on mainstream cars. Unsurprisingly, the elderly and young children are the most frequent victims of the accidents, which usually take place in parking lots or driveways. Large SUVs and pickups tend to have the worst blind spots and, as a result, are more likely to be involved in this type of incident.

The IIHS study involved 111 volunteers, who unknowingly participated in the rearview camera exercise. The volunteers thought they were testing the infotainment systems, but when asked to back out of a spot to return to the lot entrance, a child-sized foam crash dummy was placed behind the vehicle. It may sound cruel for an unwitting volunteer to discover he or she just killed a foam child, but it’s all in the name of science.

While stationary, the dummy was struck 56 percent of the time when drivers relied on the rear camera alone. The combination of a rearview camera and parking sensors was, oddly enough, slightly less effective, because the sensors often activate too late to let drivers brake in time before a collision. With just parking sensors, only one in sixteen drivers avoided hitting the dummy. Every single driver without the aid of technology ran into the dummy. In cases where the dummy was in motion, drivers were four times less likely to hit it than when it was stationary.
Shown here: 2014 Toyota Corolla

Rearview camera view in a 2013 Honda Accord.
2013 Mercedes-Benz C-Class shows this view from the rearview camera.
Volkswagen rearview camera placement.
2012 Ford Explorer with rearview camera screen.
Rearview camera in a 2013 Nissan Altima.
Rearview camera's screen in a 2013 Nissan Altima.
2014 Toyota Corolla LE Eco's screen.

pageElements.text: “Having an available rearview video system on a vehicle model should not justify design choices that restrict direct visibility around the vehicle," the Institute said.

The IIHS says backup cameras reduce blind zones by an average of about 90 percent, but even when the technology is used in accordance with rearview mirrors, side mirrors, and rear glances, it isn’t perfect. Blind zones near the bumpers remain problematic, and the cameras are not reliably effective in varied lighting conditions like shade.
Shown here: 2013 Nissan Altima

The IIHS study shows that rearview cameras are definitely effective in reducing the risk of backup pedestrian collisions but that there is still progress to be made. Even more important, it shows that designers still have a responsibility to provide good visibility because the technology is still imperfect. “Having an available rearview video system on a vehicle model should not justify design choices that restrict direct visibility around the vehicle," the Institute said in a statement last July.

Should Rearview Cameras Be the Law? October 14, 2013

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: For Google, the quest for a driverless car started ten years ago—in 2004—in the Mojave Desert with the DARPA Grand Challenge. The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) offered a cash prize for anyone who could create an autonomous vehicle. That first year, things did not go well. Not a single car that entered the race meant to test the mettle of those early efforts made it through the challenge.

But Google—always up for a project that involves solving big problems—kept at it. And on the ten-year anniversary of what was then little more than a fun science project for the data company, I thought it would be fun to find out how that crazy science project is going. So, even though the Google car people aren’t talking to press, I annoyed everyone I could with questions about the Google car during a recent visit to the Google campus in Mountain View.

Building an autonomous car is a big problem to solve, even for a company that loves big problems. But it’s certainly a worthy one: 1.2 million people are killed in car accidents annually, and 93 percent of accidents are caused by human error. But teaching a car to recognize every possible thing—person, bicycle, tree, raccoon, whatever—it might encounter on the road and what to do in all possible scenarios required some serious science. The car needs a detailed up-to-the-minute map of every road, sensors (laser, radar, GPS) that tell can tell it accurately where it is and what’s near it, high-resolution cameras and algorithms that enable it to understand and react to objects and creatures, an enormous amount of data, and a processor capable of analyzing all of that information quickly enough to make split-second decisions. Much of that technology barely existed in 2004. But a lot has changed, very quickly, since then, as anyone who has ever used Google Maps on a smartphone will tell you. Google has most of the data it needs now and the processing power to analyze it.
In 2012, Google co-founder Sergey Brin said autonomous cars could be safe for operation in five years.

So two years ago, at Google's headquarters, California Governor Jerry Brown signed SB 1298, which established guidelines to allow autonomous vehicles to be tested and operated in California. At the signing ceremony, Google co-founder Sergey Brin said autonomous cars could be safe for operation in five years. Google hasn’t said anything since, neither publicly nor when I was pelting them with questions this week, to contradict that prediction or change that timeframe.

In fact, there are about two dozen self-driving cars on the streets of San Francisco every day. Most are probably on their way to or from the Googleplex in Mountain View. And Google cars have logged more than 500,000 miles in self-driving mode. The company started buying Toyotas and Priuses a few years ago and retrofitting them with sensors and Google’s autonomous driving software.

These days, the Google autonomous cars you see on the road is more likely to be a Lexus RX450h, though, with a Google employee behind the wheel who has been trained on the car and is helping it gain more driving experience, which in the case of the car means recognizing real-world objects and deciding how to react. At any time, the driver can take over control of the car.
The Google cars have never had a single accident while in autonomous driving mode. The few fender benders the cars have been in occurred when humans were in control.

But since so much of the heavy lifting in data collection has been done and sensors and processors have come a long way, the cars are now pretty good at driving. And everything one car learns can be passed on to all the others with a simple software upload. So that means it’s possible for a brand-new car to have the collective experience of fifty years of driving. And even these Lexus prototypes are safer than most human drivers who tend to be easily distracted, drunk, or young, and, even when experienced and sober, don’t have unwavering focus, a map of every street, and a 360-degree view of their surroundings uploaded to their brains. The Google cars have never had a single accident while in autonomous driving mode. The few fender benders the cars have been in occurred when humans were in control.

But just because smart, self-driving, capable cars are on the street doesn’t mean you will be able to buy one anytime soon. “At Google[x], we try hundreds of projects and then move forward with a few that we think are viable and going to have a huge impact on the world,” Katelin Jabbari, a Google spokesperson I cornered,  admitted. “The self-driving car project is certainly one of those. The team has made a lot of progress, and we continue to refine the technology."

Google[x] refers to ideas that are (mostly) in the pure research stage at Google. These are huge problems that, if solved, change the lives of lots of people for which Google is seeking radical solutions. Moonshots, they like to call them. Google Glass is another of these. In the spirit of academia, these projects do not have an expected outcome, a business development plan, or any of the business-side attributes of a product in development...yet.

So the autonomous car is a viable Google[x]project. But it’s still a science project. Nonetheless, this is clearly a science project that’s come a long way in ten years—and one that holds enormous promise for saving lives, giving people back the time they spend commuting, and reducing parking problems (a self-driving car can go do something else rather than sit in a parking space.) Will the Google self-driving car change the world as thoroughly as Google search did? That remains to be seen. But it is certainly a big problem that is well on its way to being solved. And the company is busy thinking about ways to make it a reality.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Molly Says: No! Let's Raise the Driving Age

The mere suggestion of raising the age requirement for a driver’s license seems like a ludicrous suggestion. Parents and adolescents alike anticipate the freedom that a driver’s license represents. But is the cost too high? Should we take a step back and look at how the majority of the world does it, and make the age a tad older?

When I think back to my high-school years, mixed in with almost every memory is a car. Cars defined my teen years, and I feel like a traitor even suggesting that the age be raised. But I cannot ignore that, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, teen drivers' crash rates are three times higher per mile driven than those of drivers aged twenty years and older. As a parent (that's me with my daughter, Elle), that statistic is staggering. Am I alone in wondering if shifting the age higher means saving lives? Perhaps it is worth giving teenagers another reason to think adults are unreasonable?

As teenagers move toward independence, their frontal lobes are still developing. In fact, research suggests that it continues to develop into the twenties and even thirties. Functions such as planning, reasoning, judgment, impulse control, and memory are all controlled by this portion of the brain. Coincidentally, those are  the exact traits that are most important in driving.
I know many of my peers would acknowledge that we made dangerous decisions almost every day of the week when we were young drivers.

Any parent will attest to the volatility of the teenager. When I ride with my daughter, I tend to overreact, but she can be downright irrational at times. Add unsupervised driving to the equation of a developing brain. Now add loud music, a few friends, and a healthy helping of peer pressure, and it stands to reason that the accident rate is higher for this segment.

In car accidents involving teens ages sixteen to nineteen, alcohol is involved 23 percent of the time. And the time when teenagers are the most likely to experiment with drugs and alcohol is exactly the same time they are awarded a driver's license. I know many of my peers would acknowledge that we made dangerous decisions almost every day of the week when we were young drivers. Even when we lost several of our classmates it didn’t stop our risky driving. Obviously, it is against the law for members of this age group to drink, but a significant portion of teens do. Again, remember the developing impulse control, reasoning, and judgment. Once you mix in alcohol, even good kids make bad choices. If the driving age is moved by just a year or two it may allow the maturity to keep the two separate.

My formative years of driving were in the dark ages, and by that I mean before mobile phones and the complicated infotainment options available today. I was plenty distracted by friends and an eight-track player, but it is nearly impossible for teens today to ignore the impulse to constantly check their social networks and adjust their music. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), “For drivers fifteen to nineteen years old involved in fatal crashes, 21 percent of the distracted drivers were distracted by the use of cell phones.”

There are plenty of campaigns that stress no texting, but they gloss over the dangers with other smartphone functions such as apps that control stereos. My daughter promises that she will not be lured by her phone, but I question whether she will be able to keep that promise. I know that I am not setting a good example of resisting the urge to use the phone while driving. I lamely explain that I have years of experience behind the wheel. Not only does that argument not hold water, but I am sure that it goes in one ear and out the other. I do believe that more time behind the wheel in a supervised setting will provide her a better understanding of the importance of giving driving her full attention.

I am conflicted about raising the age, but if I were starting from scratch in creating a system to develop great drivers I would start with a year of supervised driving time, followed by a comprehensive written test, and a rigorous road test. The young Molly is officially appalled by the adult that I have become, and she would peel out of the driveway and flip me off—below where I could see of course.

Laura Says: Yes! Start Driver Education Young

I am not trying to run against the tide of safety and progress when I say this, but I think driver education should start as young as possible, and I think the current age of fourteen years and nine months (in Michigan) is just about right.
You only have the kids at home, under your influence, until they're out of high school, and they're really only listening to you until about tenth grade.

I might be in the best position of anyone I know to weigh in on teen drivers. I have three teenagers, and I myself didn't learn to drive until age twenty-two. So there are two things I know: First, you only have the kids at home, under your influence, until they're out of high school, and they're really only listening to you until about tenth grade. And second, if you don't learn a skill with your peers, it's hard to pick it up on your own later.  So let me address those, one at a time.

The best argument for driver education starting young is that your child is still listening to you at that age. His or her friends are still listening to their parents at that age. (Here's me with my fourteen-year-old, Sam. He and his friends are sassy, but they're still children, and we can still tell them what to do.) A parent can easily and naturally take the lead in answering questions, setting examples, and participating in the driving education experience. Try that with an eighteen-year-old who is about to leave for college, and see where you get. (I have two of those right now, too. They don't want my advice on anything.)
A parent can naturally take the lead in answering questions, setting examples, and participating in the driving education experience. Try that with an eighteen-year-old.

Also, if your child takes driver education when the "other kids" are doing it, basically in the ninth-to-tenth-grade window, it becomes a shared experience. There is peer encouragement and, yes, peer pressure to get through the curriculum successfully and get that license.

Let me hasten to add that I am in favor of graduated driver's license programs, which have been rolled out all over the United States, including in my home state of Michigan. This allows students to get driving privileges gradually over a period of time, not all at once. That's good, because I agree with Molly that there are dangers involved in just handing over the keys to a sixteen-year-old. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety feels strongly that the older teenagers are when they start driving, the fewer accidents they will get in. If you want your eyes opened, spend some time on the IIHS's risk calculator for teen drivers. You can dial in your state and see how many fewer accidents there'd be with more supervised driving hours, a longer time between permit and license, and other scenarios.

I don't disagree with the premise that people take fewer and fewer risks as they get older. But I think the problem of inexperienced drivers is less easily fixed than just making everybody wait until they're older.

Or are you talking about making people go through the whole driver education scenario only when they're adults? That's how a lot of European countries do it. Until there's mass transit everywhere in the U.S., it's not practical to set that up here.

So, yes, graduated driver's license laws, which require teens to spend a long time practicing with an adult co-driver and to take a second segment of driver education before the test, are a good way to drag out the process so kids have as much practice time as possible before they're allowed to go solo. But when should they start the process? Young, when parents and teachers can still have an influence.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Every time I see a blimp flying high overhead, I smile.  (And I often do, because I live in a town where it visits during college football games.) It seems unreal, just floating in the blue sky, or even better, humming in the night flashing messages seemingly sent from heaven. It offers the ultimate bird's-eye view. A blimp is better than a hot air balloon because you don’t need to rely on fickle winds, and better than a plane because you can hover for hours.

So that's why I was thrilled that I drew the golden ticket that invited me to see Goodyear’s spanking new blimp. I was allowed to get up close and examine the airship, but unfortunately I would not be leaving the ground. It is scheduled to begin test flights this week, with a goal of being ready for actual duty by midsummer.

The new blimp is the first complete remake of the classic dirigible since 1972. The current fleet's design actually dates back all the way to 1919. So it was about time for a change, and I suspected I would be seeing something completely different.
When the door slid open to reveal the moored blimp, it seemed like we were entering a whale’s aquarium. It was downright majestic.

The huge hangar sits alone on a rural road near Akron, Ohio. It is perched alongside Wingfoot Lake—yep, named after Goodyear’s logo. When the door slid open to reveal the moored blimp, it seemed like we were entering a whale’s aquarium. It was downright majestic, and we could walk right up to it.

At 246 feet long, the New Goodyear Blimp is just eighteen yards shorter than an American football field. It's also fifty-four feet longer than the blimp it replaces. The new paint scheme features tapered yellow arcs that stretch from tail to fin, and only the visually impaired will miss the enormous Goodyear logo.
Will people notice the difference? Absolutely. Both inside and outside, this is a whole different dirigible.

The blimp we have been seeing for years has no internal framework. Its balloon-like body, called its "envelope," is made of Dacron and Neoprene, and it has two engines that are mounted directly on the gondola where the driver and passengers ride. Those engines can make it very, very loud inside the gondola: up to 110 decibels.

By contrast, the new blimp is actually a zeppelin, because it has a framework inside the envelope. (But don't think, "Oh, the humanity"; the fuel is helium, not highly flammable hydrogen as in the Hindenburg.) The framework is made up of aluminum and carbon fiber trusses. The envelope is polyurethane, polyester, and Tedlar film from Dupont. It has three engines, which are attached to the envelope instead of the gondola, and as a result, the noise level in the gondola is way down to 64 decibels.
The New Goodyear Blimp is also faster and more maneuverable, and it can hold up to twelve passengers plus two crew members, compared with a total of seven in the current blimp.

Global communications chief Paul Fitzhenry called the introduction of the New Goodyear Blimp "the beginning of a new era for our airship program." Among the benefits he outlined are "enhanced aerial television coverage capabilities, increased flight range to cover more events, and an unparalleled passenger experience.”
 
Assembly of the new helium-filled airship began a year ago. Goodyear and Germany’s ZLT Zeppelin Luftschifftechnik worked together to build the new semi-rigid dirigible. The tailfins and gondola were built in Germany and assembled in the Goodyear hangar.

But the big news for the pilots is an upgrade from the manual flight system that has been in use since 1925 to modern computer-controlled avionics. Chief pilot Greg Poppenhouse described how the flight crew has been going to Germany for the past year. He has personally logged more than 200 hours in a Zeppelin airship and is eager to get the new blimp up in the air.

More news: There's a joystick. The electronic controls work in conjunction with an on-board computer to regulate engine thrust, up-and-down movement, and right-and-left movement. Tailfin operation will be controlled by the joystick device. These advancements, Goodyear explained, will result in more precise operation of the airship while in flight, on landing, and on takeoff.

pageElements.text: As soon as permission was granted, I beelined for the gondola and sat right down in one of the twelve seats for passengers, imagining myself looking down over the Big House in Ann Arbor, even though I was definitely in Ohio State territory. The first thing you notice when entering the cabin is an actual restroom, but unlike any I have seen in the sky this one has a window. Previous blimps have a camp-style toilet that is in a closet, nice to have anything when a game goes into extra innings.
The gondola's huge wraparound windows and the open cockpit must make for a party atmosphere wherever the blimp may be cruising.

The interior has been designed to remind you of the company that has made your flight possible. A Goodyear Wingfoot is embroidered on the blue leather seats, a double yellow line down the aisle is a gentle reminder of the road where Goodyear tires roll, and a giant Goodyear logo is sewn into the headliner. The placement of the engines directly on the exterior of the envelope makes the ride much quieter, and passengers no longer need to wear headphones to hear communication from the host. The gondola's huge wraparound windows and the open cockpit must make for a party atmosphere wherever the blimp may be cruising.

The new blimp's top speed of 73 mph is slower than I drove on the highway on my way to Ohio, but that's 23 mph faster than the current fleet. It will significantly reduce the time it takes the pilots to reach their destinations and give the blimp greater range to cover more events. And the configuration for cameras will also allow more passengers during live coverage.

I was not lucky enough to fly in the blimp, but you have a chance to. Goodyear is asking the public to help pick a name for the new blimp. U.S. entrants over age eighteen can enter the contest to supply a name for the new blimp. Contest information is on the Facebook page, too. One name will be chosen from the entries, and the contest winner will get to join the Goodyear Blimp for a day of airship activities. In addition, nine runner-up winners will each receive a set of Goodyear tires. The contest will close on Friday, April 4.

I myself have a new affection for the blimp. I am voraciously reading about the history of blimps and zeppelins and looking forward to seeing the blimp floating over my house. You can become a blimpophile, too, by devouring the Blimp website.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I'm very sad to learn that the esteemed Gruppo Bertone styling house, which created some incredibly important cars in its 102-year history, is in bankruptcy court and could soon be closing its doors. This would be a tragic loss, and so unfortunate that Bertone has not been able to secure a corporate angel like Volkswagen, which bought Italdesign.

There was some hope recently when Lilli Bertone, widow of the founder's son, Nuccio, was able to revive the company and put American designer Mike Robinson in charge. His car, the Pandion, a wild exercise with crazy 90-degree doors that were 11.8 feet high when opened, was proudly displayed along the ocean side of the lawn as part of Alfa Romeo's 100th-year celebration at the Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance in 2010. It was always surrounded by a mass of people. Unfortunately, it wasn't enough to put Bertone back in the game.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/GdKJEGieopY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The end of Bertone would leave Pininfarina, founded in 1930, as the last of the great Turin coachbuilders still in existence. Its own troubles accelerated when it lost CEO Andrea Pininfarina, a bright star, so personable and smart and worldly, in a Vespa accident in 2008. His father, Sergio, continued to run the company, but his own death in 2012 leaves that firm's future in serious doubt.

Read my reminiscence of meeting Nuccio Bertone in 1981 in this recent story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I had a throwaway 2004 Kia Rio, a car that I purchased for a family member in 2008 (and wrote about in a column in Automobile Magazine). Today's Kia Rio is a great little car. Ten years ago, the Rio, for a throwaway car, was pretty damn good, but as it approached its next timing belt replacement called for by maintenance, it was gliding on its path down to where everything that needed to be repaired cost $500. So, rather than be $500ed to death, I went into buy-a-used-car mode and decided I'd donate the old Kia to charity, which I eventually did (as you see from the photo). But first, I had to deal with the dealers to replace it.

It began with looking at newspaper ads, and it ended with a trip to two good car dealerships in Ann Arbor. One turned out to be not so good; the other one, a dealership where we had previously made videos on the car-buying comfort zone and relationship building, was everything I thought it should be and would be, and it was even more than that.

I suppose anyone can have a bad experience, so I’d like to tell you exactly what made it bad. First, it was the phone calls. No matter what I said or didn't say to him, the salesman incessantly called me to the point of annoyance. Then, the car wasn’t ready when they said it would be. The paperwork they gave me was Experian’s version of Carfax, which looked on the up and up, so I decided to take the used car for a quick ride around the parking lot, and the noise it made was horrendous. It was abominable. The salesman kept pointing out all the extra features on it. I, of course, said I didn’t give a shit about the features; I cared that the car was in good shape and was going to run.

In the meantime, I got three email messages (and no phone calls) from our friend at Dunning Toyota, Beth Bashert. Each email message had a link to complete information on each of the cars that met my requirements. From that, I could quickly pick three hot prospects. One of them was a super nice prospect, but it took me three days to get there, and that car had flown out the door by then. But she had a couple of new things to show me.

It was a snowy evening. Beth had Carfax reports waiting for me. The cars that I looked at were super clean, and she gave me a sheaf of papers to go with them, including the checklist that her dealership goes through when a used car comes in and the service papers that detailed every single thing they did to the car in response to the checklist. I narrowed it down to a Saturn: a one-owner car, ten years old, with 70,000 miles on it, which is way below the average. There was not a dent, scratch, bubble...nothing wrong with the car.

I took it for a drive, and it was like brand-new inside. In the drive, the steering was absolutely tight, the brakes were perfect, and there wasn’t a rattle or a squeak in this car. Beth said her short list of cars for me were all nameplates that she hadn’t experienced any problems with. She said that’s the best you can do, and I agree: that’s about as honest as you can be.

The paperwork was done immediately. We negotiated a tiny bit from the price, which she didn’t want to do as it had just arrived, and she immediately suggested she could get me a super-good deal from the University of Michigan Credit Union, which she did. All the negotiating was done and handled within thirty minutes.
There’s a point where you say, Is the deal fair? Is the car good? It was just like I had bought a new car; that was the quality of the experience.

Of course, you’re not me, and of course the people at Dunning Toyota knew exactly who I am. On the other hand, the price was good, the mileage was good, the car was good, and it was all fair. There’s a point where you say, Is the deal fair? Is the car good? When I came to get the car, it was inside so it could be under lights to look at it; it was clean, it was filled with gas, and all the paperwork and title were ready. When the plate arrived, they put it on. It was just like I had bought a new car; that was the quality of the experience.

The people at the other dealership knew exactly who I was, too, and yet here was my experience there: The car wasn’t ready. When I asked them to see all the paperwork on the mechanics of the car, they were gone for ten minutes and came back and said, “Jeez, I guess this one slipped through the cracks, and nothing was ever done.” It’s beyond crazy, since the guy called me more than five times, set up the appointment, said he’d bring the car over from the other lot to the main dealership and have it ready for me, and if he’s not there, so-and-so will be there, it’s all handled. He did tell me there was a little miss in the engine because it had been steam cleaned, and he didn’t want me to see it until they’d serviced it, and then said it was all set. All set? It was a complete rattletrap.

I started by going in not really happy with the salesperson but giving him the benefit of the doubt. Then I had to endure his try to talk to me about all the hot options on this ten-year-old car, when I had told him clearly I just needed a car that was clean and running well. He wasn’t listening to me, the car was not ready, and then he gave me the non-Carfax thing that said the car was priced “below its value” and “sale priced” without giving me the information I really needed. It was easy to get up and walk out. He gave me no other options.
It was like they’d just swept it out and stuck it on the lot. I was not worth their while. The car was not worth their while.

It was such a bad experience from beginning to end. First, being harangued by this dealer at home, at work, and on my cell phone, although I told him I was traveling and busy. Then, having a car presented to me that hadn’t even gone through any checkpoints. It was like they’d just swept it out and stuck it on the lot. I was not worth their while, and the car was not worth their while. If they knew who I was, imagine your experience.

The truth is, people who buy used cars deserve just as much respect as people who buy new cars. As Skip LeFauve, the first head of Saturn, once said to me, “I would argue that people who are spending under $15,000 deserve even more help from a salesperson and more respect and courtesy, because they’re spending a greater proportion of their income.” Isn’t that an amazing thought?

And that’s how I was treated by Beth Bashert. It was worth her while; the car was worthy; and I was worth it because to her, as you know, if you treat somebody right, you have them for the rest of your life. I’ve sung her praises to people before I even bought a car from her, just from talking to her about the process. I’ll say it one more time, I love car dealers. Let me rephrase that: I love good car dealers.
