contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Have you ever wished there was a way to compare, book, and pay for auto mechanic services online or from your phone? Software entrepreneur Rob Infantino had that very wish when he was presented with an outrageous estimate at his local dealer. He walked out and then had to face the arduous task of making individual calls to a variety of shops in search of high-quality service at a more reasonable price. “There’s got to be a better way,” thought Infantino, and he set out to create Openbay, an online marketplace for auto repair.

Launched last October, Openbay has quickly grown from a local Boston enterprise with 400 auto service providers to a national database of 220,000 providers and counting. The free service, which you can find at Openbay.com, has a clean, uncluttered look and is delightfully devoid of any advertising because it charges a ten percent fee to the service provider/garage, which is built into the final invoice for each repair.
Openbay is very simple to use. It has a dashboard to access all your account activities and even offers the ability to sign into your account via Facebook.
Rating and reviewing the service you receive is encouraged, in order to strengthen the local community of users and providers.

The first step is to establish your account, during which time you list your vehicles, enter billing information, and complete a few other profile details. When you need a repair, select Request Service for a particular car and state preferences: for instance, you not only enter that you need a wheel alignment but also use a dropdown menu to say how soon you want the repair. Additionally, you can select what kind of amenities you desire from a list that includes loaner car, early dropoff, shuttle service, wait on site, even Wi-Fi. If you don’t exactly know what is wrong with your car, you can submit a Custom Service Request or select General Diagnosis and provide a detailed description in the Notes box.

Once you submit your request. Openbay will contact providers on your behalf. You’ll receive a list of nearby mechanics, who will respond to you with offers. You can compare their prices, locations, and amenities as well as user ratings and reviews before booking your service appointment. When the repair is complete, you pay via Openbay, which will then keep a record of services received.  Provider offers are valid for six months, but Openbay will check in with you at thirty days to request a decision. You can withdraw or modify a request at any time.

What if you take your car in and the mechanic says you need additional repairs? Infantino recommends asking the mechanic to demonstrate to you exactly why the additional repair is needed. That service provider will have to resubmit the new price to you via Openbay, and you will then have the option to accept it or not. You can also submit a request for the newly proposed repair via Openbay for comparison to decide if you are comfortable with the price you are being quoted for those additional repairs.

Rating and reviewing the service you receive is encouraged, in order to strengthen the local community of users and providers. Infantino also points out that Openbay provides a maintenance schedule based on the make, model, and mileage of your vehicle. There are also financial incentives: for every dollar you spend on the site, you earn Openbay Rewards that can be applied to your next repair cost.

“We’ve had repeat customers who’ve brought all the cars in their household, and sometimes they’re getting free services.” said Infantino, “It’s cool for the consumers.”

Openbay began in Boston and started its spread via major metro markets, including Atlanta. At present the company has providers in forty-four states, but there may be times when services are not yet available in your area. Infantino stresses to keep trying: the network is adding new providers every day.  It is also being built systematically as the company works to create a density of service providers over the coming year.
So, next time you hear a mysterious clunk, whine, or rattle coming from your car,  consider signing on to Openbay.com. They may just help you find the right mechanic for the job.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: Red-and-white polka dot bandana? Check. Red socks? Check. Black boots? Check.  Blue denim coveralls?  Not an item in my closet…yet.

This is not my usual attire. I'm an art historian, a group known for our fondness for black. It is, however, the outfit needed for the next attempt to set the Guinness World Record for “The Most Rosie the Riveters in One Place.”  If you were ever to put a “save the date” on your calendar, March 29, 2014, 2:00 p.m. at Hangar 1, Willow Run Airport, in Ypsilanti, Michigan, might be it. On that day, more than 250 women of all ages are expected to assemble in Rosie uniforms to set that world record.

The event serves a dual purpose: to honor the “Rosies,” the women who played such a significant role in the manufacturing movement for the World War II war effort, and to raise funds for the Save the Bomber Plant campaign. The campaign seeks to save part of the original Willow Run Bomber Plant and convert the space to house the Yankee Air Museum.
The timing is crucial, as the campaign has only until May 1 to raise the funds to prevent the total demolition of the plant that produced 8,600 B-24s during World War II.

Jane Vass, the "head Tribute Rosie," had coordinated an effort to break the “Rosie record” on a cold and damp October day last fall, and the “Rosie” turnout was close enough to the record to prompt support for this new attempt in the spring.  The timing is crucial, as the campaign has only until May 1 to raise the necessary funds to prevent the total demolition of the plant that produced 8,600 B-24 Liberator bombers during the war.

This being a Guinness World Record attempt, the rules are quite strict: no high heels, no colored shoes, no T-shirts, no denim shirts (only solid dark blue fabric), and the shirt must be long-sleeved and rolled up. The red bandana must have large-size white polka dots. There will be chairs provided for "elderly" Rosies, while under-eighteen Rosies must have a parent or guardian with them. Arrival is requested by 2:00 p.m. for check-in. Get all the details here and RSVP to the organizers here.

We just hit an all-time record for snowfall and cold this winter. Who knows what the weather will bring on March 29? The real Rosies on that factory floor, however, were tenacious women, and the weather would not have stopped them.  Snow, rain, or shine, all women are invited to join the effort as Tribute Rosies to help break a different kind of record.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text:
Women in the Winner’s Circle: The Traveling Exhibit
NASCAR Hall of Fame, 400 E. Martin Luther King Blvd., Charlotte, N.C.
Through June 8
Details: www.nascarhall.com

Move over, Danica Patrick. There are plenty of other fast women who’ve been racing their way into history books over the past century. Now they are getting their due through Women in the Winner’s Circle—a traveling exhibit that has just kicked off at the NASCAR Hall of Fame in Charlotte, North Carolina, and will run through June.

For example: Long before Patrick became a household name, there was Camille du Gast, a French tobogganer, balloonist, and expert riflewoman, who turned her attention to auto racing in 1901, only to be banned after two races when her native country prevented women from participating in the fledgling sport, citing “feminine nervousness.”

Then there was Dorothy Levitt, the “Fastest Girl on Earth,” who, almost 100 years ago, broke the ladies' land speed record when she got her De Dion-Bouton up to 90.88 mph. In addition to teaching the queen of England how to drive, the fur-wearing Brit is credited with inspiring the rearview mirror.
In addition to teaching the queen of England how to drive, fur-wearing Brit Dorothy Levitt is credited with inspiring the rearview mirror.

The list of female racers, and their colorful stories, spans decades, starting with early twentieth-century "pioneers" and continuing to “trailblazers” of the 1940s to 1970s, such as Louise Smith, Pat Moss-Carlsson, and Janet Guthrie.

Smith started driving at the age of four and was as well known for surviving horrific crashes as she was for becoming one of the first women to compete in the NASCAR precursor Grand National series in the 1950s.

Moss-Carlsson started driving at the age of seven, when her future racing legend (and brother) Stirling Moss taught her how to drive the family’s Jeep. Despite being a petite 5'4", Moss-Carlsson went on to win Europe’s grueling Liège-Rome-Liège Rally in 1960 driving an Austin-Healey; its brake and accelerator pedals were strapped with blocks of wood so she could reach them.

The daughter of a pilot, Guthrie began flying at age fifteen, sky diving at sixteen, and racing at twenty-two. The first woman to pass the Indianapolis 500 rookie test in 1976, the first woman to compete in a NASCAR Winston Cup in 1977, the first woman to earn a starting spot in the Daytona 500, and the first woman to start at the Indy 500, she was also among the Mercury 13—the thirteen women who tried out to become U.S. astronauts in the 1960s.

The Women in the Winner’s Circle exhibit is a joint production of the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Michigan, and the Women in the Winner’s Circle Foundation founded by racing driver Lyn St. James. She was the first woman to win Rookie of the Year at the Indy 500 in 1992 and is featured as one of the “modern racers” of the 1980s and 1990s in a show that also highlights present and future female racers, such as drag-racing star Erica Enders-Stevens.



Helping to bring the women’s stories to life are racing cars, helmets, racing suits, and trophies, as well as awards and photos of the many women who’ve put pedal to metal to help make motorsports more gender neutral.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

title: 2014 Kia Cadenza
subTitle: Who'd have expected? A smooth, capacious full-size sedan from Korea. Should you buy it?
promoTeaserSmall: Who'd have expected? A smooth, capacious full-size sedan from Korea. Should you buy it?
promoTeaser: Who'd have expected? A smooth, capacious full-size sedan from Korea. Should you buy it?
metaDescription: 2014 Kia Cadenza: A smooth, capacious full-size sedan from Korea. Who'd have thought? Should you buy it?

pageElements.text:
Price: $35,900 base price (including destination), $41,950 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 293 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Eight-inch screen with navigation and rearview camera display
Option I can’t live without: Heated everything: steering wheel, both front seats (which is a standard feature), and both outboard rear seats
Notable standard features on this model: Dual-zone climate control with auto filtration; Infinity surround sound audio; Bluetooth connectivity; SiriusXM radio (three months free); paddle shifters; heated power-folding mirrors; rain-sensing wipers; leather-trimmed seats, steering wheel, and shift knob
Notable options on this model: Technology package ($3,000) includes “smart” cruise control, blind spot detection, lane departure warning, electronic parking brake, hydrophobic windows in front door, nineteen-inch alloy wheels; Luxury package ($3,000) includes panoramic dual sunroof, ventilated driver’s seat, power telescoping steering wheel, and power rear window sunshade
You might also be considering: Buick LaCrosse, Chevrolet Impala, Chrysler 300, Lexus ES350, Toyota Avalon

How do you feel about a luxury sedan with the name “Kia” on the grille? If you are prejudiced against the Korean brand because you think it only makes cheap econocars, you are several years out of date. This is an ambitious automaker with every intention of making its name synonymous not only with value but with quality.

How do I know this? Because I drove this full-size Cadenza on a 640-mile round trip last weekend, and I was thoroughly impressed. From physical comfort, aesthetics, and driving enjoyment points of view, this car is a keeper.

There’s something really pleasant about getting into a big car that has more than enough room, especially when it’s as cleanly attractive as this one. There’s a kind of unpretentiousness that rightly goes along with that Kia badge—and Kia gets major points from me for not trying to make this car gaudy in an attempt to justify the $41,950 as-tested price.

A cadenza, as you may or may not know, is moment in a classical concerto performance when the orchestra sits quietly while the violinist, cellist or other soloist gets to play a virtuosic passage. It may be an odd name for a car that isn’t exactly a virtuoso, but it’s better than the name it has in the Korea market, K7. It’s the biggest Kia for now, but the seriously luxurious 2015 Kia K900 sedan is coming soon, priced starting just over $60,000. (Not sure why they didn't name it something equally majestic, such as the Glissando, or the Oratorio.)

But back to the Cadenza. I open the trunk: It’s almost too big, in terms of being a large, uncontoured flat space. In fact, I opened it to put my computer bag inside, then decided it was just going to roll around in there, and instead I loaded it in the back seat. I would have liked some kind of trunk organizer or separator, and if I bought this car, I’d get one. But if you were going on a road trip, you could probably fit most or all of your gear in this trunk and leave the passenger compartment for the passengers—always a bonus. Trunk volume: 15.9 cubic feet, about on par for its class, but humongous for those who are used to mid-size or smaller cars.

There are almost too many driver-coddling features on the Cadenza to name. It starts with the side mirrors, which close up against the car’s body when you park, then reopen when you unlock the car. These have light bars that light up and sparkle as you open the door and climb in. The seats adjust to a neutral position when you shut off the ignition, and they regain the settings you’ve chosen as soon as you get back in. The seats are easily positionable, including lumbar support for the driver (not the front passenger, however). And everything is heated: four seating positions, plus the steering wheel. This can not possibly be overrated when the temperature outdoors is in the single digits.

The UVO telematics were easy to use, clear, and easy to adjust—virtually no learning curve to pair my iPhone, change the radio station, or adjust the climate control. The dual sunroofs filled the interior of the car with light, most welcome at the end of a long winter, and the off-white leather upholstery added to the clean, clear feeling inside. No shiny fake wood; no bright colors; nothing extraneous. There’s even an analog clock in the center stack.

Those of you who are short, like me, might share this minor annoyance: when the driver’s seat is far enough forward for a 5’3” driver, the sun shade can’t be moved over to the driver’s-side window. (Well, it can, but not without a wrestling match.) The shade is usefully long, but so long that it doesn’t fit past the bulbous front-leaning headrest. This mattered to me when heading south on I-69 as the long-overdue sun came pounding up over the horizon at dawn.
But if that’s the worst thing to say about driving the Cadenza, that says something about how pleasant the experience really was.

That fuel economy of 19 mpg in town and 28 mpg on the highway is not stellar—but you would not expect stellar from a large sedan with a V-6 making almost 300 horsepower. Its fuel economy is the same as that of the Acura TSX, some BMW 5- and 7-series sedans, the Cadillac CTS AWD, the Lexus IS350, and the Lincoln MKS and MKZ, among others.


As for the driving experience, I knew I was driving a large four-door sedan the whole time, but it was completely smooth, energetic, and comfortable, handling both freeway and surface-road driving with full competence. No complaints.

But let’s talk about technology, and you will understand why I say the Cadenza is an old-man car in the best possible meaning of the term. With the Technology package (a $3,000 option), you get “smart” cruise control, blind spot detection, and lane departure warning. The blind spot detection lights up a red symbol on the side mirrors when another vehicle is near yours—which can quickly become a can’t-live-without feature once you are used to it. The lane departure warning feature is enabled with a switch to the left of the steering wheel. Choose it, and it will make an annoying “beepbeepbeep” when you even think about getting up on the center line or close to the edge of the road. The biggest magic, though, is found in the “smart” cruise control. I set it to 71—the cops in Indiana are ruthless—and enjoyed the way it showed an image of my car on the dash in front of me, then added an image of the car in front of me whenever there was one anywhere in range. Then, as soon as I got any closer than the computer’s idea of safe following distance, the car overrode the cruise control and slowed me down—all the way to 60 mph, at which time I overrode it myself by accelerating and passing the sedate Subaru that was, in my mind, plenty far ahead of me the whole time. For those of you who like to speed up on slower cars and pass them—just about everybody—you might call this frustrating. But put these three safety features together, and you are not going to be in any danger of rear-ending anybody, straying out of your lane, or missing a car, bicyclist, or motorcyclist in your blind spot. Even the heated steering wheel shepherds you along, since it's only heated in the center where your hands are supposed to be, not at the top or bottom.
Do you see why I’d love to see my eighty-five-year-old father signing a deal to buy one of these? Or my twenty-one-year-old college student son?

Or, really, even myself. Yeah, I’d turn off the active safety features, especially the lane keeping, some of the time. But it was actually nice to have the car’s “help” with my driving since I was behind the wheel for ten straight hours on a pretty boring stretch of highway.

pageElements.text:
The Verdict:

The Kia Cadenza is in the same price range as the Chevrolet Impala, the Toyota Avalon, and the Chrysler 300, yet it feels a good deal more luxurious. It's not a groundbreaking car, but it is one that will give you a full range of safety technologies, creature comforts, and electronic gadgetry, all in an understated way, without leaving you feeling like you're driving a spaceship. There is only one thing that might give you pause: that three-letter word Kia on the front. And if this automaker keeps it up, it will soon become a badge of honor.

Peanut Gallery:

Scott Allen: My mom has a late-1990s Buick sedan, and this car felt more like that than any other car I can think of, although in a very modern way. It really has a classic American-car vibe to it. Although it doesn't look that huge when parked, and it's not, it feels very big once you're inside. That's a good thing, whether you're sitting in the front seat or in the back. Anyone who, like my mom, is comfortable with a traditional American-style sedan will feel at home in the Cadenza. One thing I didn't like was the heated steering wheel. I do appreciate the heating, but the top and bottom of the wheel were ice cold while the sides were burning hot. That's a minor point, though.

Molly Jean: This is a sedan that is worthy of a road trip. There is so much trunk space that you can leave your sport-ute at home. The cabin is nicely styled, with a minimalist feeling even though it is stuffed with high-tech features. Best of all, it delivers a luxurious ride for the passengers, and the driver will be plenty happy with the V-6. This car would be a perfect daily driver to remove some of the grind of commuting.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Fans of the film 2001: A Space Odyssey will be no doubt simultaneously excited and worried about some recent developments in automobile intelligence. In that 1968 vision of the future, HAL 9000, a sentient computer, controlled the ship’s navigation and mechanics. HAL was also a keen observer of his human colleagues. But when HAL got paranoid and turned into a control freak, things didn’t end well for the astronauts.

Today, quite a bit later than predicted by that film, car manufacturers are finally on a quest for a car with a computer intelligence that’s smart enough to handle driving duties. Some of the technologies developed to that end, such as lane assist and predictive cruise control, are already emerging in cars. But automakers and researchers are still busy developing sensors and technologies that let cars “see” the world around them, anticipate traffic, control the car’s speed and direction, and communicate with other cars on the road.

image.altText: Sensor To See Where Driver Is Looking.Volvo

pageElements.text: At some point, even the best self-driving car has to hand control back to the driver. To do that, it needs to know its driver (just as HAL knew his astronauts) well enough to be able to answer the questions, “Is this human driver awake? Alert? Coherent enough to control of this vehicle?”

Knowing that much about humans will require sensors inside the car to observe the driver that are able to accurately interpret his or her behavior, so it can decide between handing over the controls or pulling off the road and calling for help.
Beyond vague predictions that a fully autonomous car will be “safe” by 2017, it is difficult to pin down the date when you might encounter a car that “gets" you.

Because of the difficulty of interpreting human behavior, this part of the self-driving-car package is a bit of a sticking point in the R&D world of autonomous driving. Manufacturers are working out technologies that watch the driver, determine what he’s paying attention to, and get his attention back on the driving. Delphi showed a technology at the 2014 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas that can see where the driver is looking. And when it sees a driver look away from the road for too long, it flashes a light on the dash or rumbles the steering wheel to get his or her attention back on driving. Volvo has developed a similar technology.

But researchers in Switzerland, at the École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne's Signal Processing 5 Laboratory (LTS5), are collaborating with PSA Peugeot Citroën to take this people-watching technology one step further. They have developed an emotion detector that analyzes not only where the driver is looking but also interprets facial expressions to see how the driver is feeling. Groggy? Angry? Irritated? These emotions can affect how a person drives and could lead the car to decide things might go better if it takes—or keeps—control away from a tired or even road-raging human.

Knowing how the driver is feeling, though, is just one aspect of teaching a machine to understand its driver. The Swiss research project is also working on a fatigue detector that measures how frequently a driver's eyes close and on a machine that can read lips for use in voice recognition. Volvo is testing a sensor installed in the dashboard with small infrared-light LEDs to determine where the driver is looking and how far open his or her eyes are, and to monitor the position and angle of his or her head. It's all in the service of adjusting safety technology to work best for that driver at that time.
But, beyond vague predictions that a fully autonomous car will be “safe” by 2017, it is difficult to pin down the date when you might encounter a car that “gets" you.

But the potential for improved safety from cars that know what their driver is feeling is promising, which is why Volvo says of its research, “This technology is one of the many initiatives bringing Volvo Cars closer to its goal for 2020: that no one shall be killed or seriously injured in a new Volvo.”

But anyone who watched 2001: A Space Odyssey might look at these developments slightly differently. In that movie (spoiler alert), HAL took control of the Discovery One spaceship and murdered most of the crew, after reading the lips of the astronauts who were planning to disconnect him. You'd be excused if you feel a chill of concern about getting into a machine smart enough to read your lips and take over the driving if it decides you aren’t handling your emotions well enough.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: I know the awkward feeling of arriving at an event wearing the same dress as another attendee and, to make matters worse, she indeed is wearing it better. No need to fear the awkward entrance in a 2014 Mini. You can choose from a whole new selection of Mini branded accessories for the outside and inside of your car starting in mid-April.

If you were thinking there were already plenty of aftermarket choices for the Mini Cooper, you weren't wrong, but fashion must continue to move forward. There are four new design lines for both exterior and interior details: Vivid Green. Speedwell Blue, John Cooper Works Pro, and Essential Black. These will complement the previously available roof and side graphics, interior and exterior mirror caps, floor mats, side-indicator surrounds, and a plethora of other unique choices.

Also new for 2014 are coordinated key caps that feature an integrated Near Field Communication chip for data exchange between the key and your smartphone. Once it's synced,  you can control stereo volume and launch apps via the key.

To clarify, the four design lines are not really packages (although Mini calls them Character Packages), but rather a motif that is applied to various accessories that you can then buy à la carte. Speedwell Blue is by far my favorite: it has a fabulous light blue plaid that screams retro British.
Nickelodeon fans may gravitate toward Vivid Green, since it sports a slime green dot pattern on a black background.
The John Cooper Works Pro design will attract the racing enthusiast with its black, red, and gray motif.
And for those who are celebrating black as the new black, I recommend Essential Black.
There are also two new finishes: Gold Jack, which adds a gold tone to the classic Union Jack, and Big Bang, which looks like cartoon bubbles rather than anything celestial.

Don’t forget the wheels as an opportunity to show your flair. You can choose eighteen-inch forged aluminum rims in cross-spoke design, or seventeen-inch light alloy wheels in a multi-spoke design, available in Bright Silver metallic or Liquid Black.
But why stop at silver or black? You can bedazzle your light alloy wheel hubcaps in Chili Red, Bright Orange, Apple Green, or Bright Yellow.

The current fashion trend of mixing clashing patterns, when applied to a brand-new 2014 Mini Cooper, is certain to garner attention. I myself would go all the way with Speedwell Blue and call it a day.

pageElements.text: Emma Gilmour grew up in one of New Zealand’s smaller cities, Dunedin, where her mechanic father drove his Porsche “quite quickly. I just grew up with fast cars and didn’t know any differently,” said Gilmour, who inherited her dad’s need for speed.

The fastest female rally driver in the world, Gilmour added another first to her résumé today. She will be the first female to compete in Global Rallycross, joining Hyundai and Rhys Millen Racing for the 2014 season, which kicks off in May.

For the past week, Gilmour has been in Southern California, testing out the 600-horsepower Hyundai/RMR Veloster Turbo she’ll use to accelerate to more than 100 mph on the straights and drift around corners during the series. Global Rallycross will be Gilmour’s first race in America. Since 2002, she has competed in the New Zealand Rally Championship, placing second overall in 2010, 2011, and 2012 in an entirely male field. She has also raced in Europe and placed second in the International Asia Pacific Series in 2009.

“There aren’t that many females doing what we do in the rally world,” Gilmour said during a telephone interview Monday, her New Zealand accent loud and clear. “There’s less of us that want to do it to start with. There’s no reason we can’t do it, but fewer females seem to start in the sport.”

Gilmour started in the sport at age nineteen as a navigator for her cousin and older sister. In New Zealand, rally drivers are paired with navigators to help them negotiate blind turns since the races are run on closed public roads. She moved in to the driver’s seat at twenty-two and was quickly recognized as having a flair for the sport, which helped her realize she could race professionally, not just as a hobby.
Now age thirty-four, Gilmour has known she would be part of the Rhys Millen Racing team since last December.

“It was a really big secret to keep,” said Gilmour, who knew Millen because he is also from New Zealand. They met through the motorsport event run by Millen’s father in their home country, the Leadfoot Festival.

“In New Zealand we’re very lucky because lots of people do motorsports. It’s quite accessible to do even at the club level relatively cheaply,” said Gilmour, noting that New Zealand has spawned three Formula 1 racing drivers—as well as Millen, a Pikes Peak International Hill Climb champion, rallycross driver, and Formula D world champion.
Rhys Millen Racing wanted a woman for the two-driver team to reflect the Veloster’s relatively even buyership between men and women.

Gilmour said she was in the running for the Hyundai/RMR team with at least one other female rally racer; Hyundai and Rhys Millen Racing wanted a woman for the two-driver team to reflect the Veloster’s relatively even buyership between men and women, she said.

Gilmour’s most recent rally car was a modified Suzuki Swift Sport. She has also raced a Ford Fiesta, Mitsubishi Evo 3, Evo 6, and Subaru WRX, but the Veloster, she said, is the most powerful car she’s ever driven.

Gilmour describes her racing style as smooth, aggressive, and committed: smooth because she tries to keep the tires as balanced as possible, aggressive in that her reactions are quick and decisive, and committed in the sense of rally racing on her home turf.

“In New Zealand, we drive on closed public roads. We’re driving blind, so when our navigator tells us about the corner, whatever they say is what you do. You have to be fully committed going over the crest and doing 160 kilometers [100 miles] per hour.”

Gilmour’s first competitive sport was equestrian. She competed at the national level until “I got to the point where my ambition didn’t match my ability or my bravery, so I reluctantly gave it up,” said Gilmour, who missed competition and decided to apply her skills to stage rallying.
Some of the skills she learned riding horses are directly applicable to rally car racing, she said.

“You understand the balance of the car through the seat. There’s obviously coordination with the hands,” she said. “In horse riding, if you’re approaching with speed and you see the horse is striding wrong and it’s pretty ugly, you still have to go for it. It’s the same in rally driving. You come in a corner and you’ve locked the brakes and your speed is too high, but you’ve still got to give it a go.”
Gilmour will be giving it a go in Global Rallycross beginning May 17 in Barbados.

pageElements.text: As the mother of an eleven-year-old boy who has become increasingly obsessed with video games, I was getting worried. Like most parents, I want to raise a son with character and a sense of responsibility—not a kid who’s prone to escape down the rabbit hole of the Internet. So I did something that disrupted my son’s couch-borne comfort. In an attempt to recapture the sense of adventure he had before discovering Minecraft, I bought him a dirt bike for his birthday.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: My gift wasn’t exactly out of the blue. I’ve been riding motorcycles for twenty-two years. For as long as my kid can remember, he’s seen me on a bike. Last year, we took the first steps toward dirt biking as a family when my son and I went to Dirt Bike School together, and in February, I sealed the deal. Not only did I buy my son his very first motorbike, I followed it up by purchasing one for myself.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: It’s been a month, and so far, we’ve been on two dirt bike adventures together, both of which have been filled with beginner’s folly, but our trips have also had the desired effect. They’re allowing us to spend more quality time together and experience situations that are helping me impart crucial life lessons about resilience, nature, community—the list goes on and on.
So, fellow parents. If you’re at all like me and looking for a radical solution to get your kids motivated to participate in life and on two wheels, I have the following advice:

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: 1. Go to dirt bike school. Yes, a formal school exists. One of twenty-three different safety programs run by the Motorcycle Safety Foundation, Dirt Bike School is available nationally to children as young as six. If your child has the hang of a pedal bike and is coordinated enough that replacing his bicycle’s hand grip with a throttle isn’t likely to end with an ambulance, Dirt Bike School is a great way to learn the basics of how to properly mount the bike and turn it on, then operate the clutch, throttle, and brakes and, finally, to ride. Prices for the one-day course vary by location, but when I took it with my son in Southern California, it cost $400 for the two of us in a semi-private lesson.
No one is going to ride your child’s bike for him. If he can’t handle falling down and will whine about getting back up and riding out, dirt biking isn’t right for him.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: 2. Know your kid. Does your kid want to do this? I mean, does he really, really want to? If you have a kid who’s a quitter or who doesn’t like to try new things or be outdoors or has genuine fears about falling down, dirt biking probably isn’t the right sport. No one is going to ride your child’s bike for him. If he can’t handle falling down and will whine about getting back up and riding out, dirt biking isn’t the right activity.

3. Assess your finances. There are a lot less expensive sports to get involved with. Basketball, gymnastics, swimming—the cost of participation in more traditional sports at the amateur level is a fraction of the cost of dirt biking. First, there are the bikes, which will cost a minimum of $800 per motorcycle, if used, and exponentially more if purchased new. I bought two new bikes this winter, the sum total of which came to about $11,000.

Then there’s the issue of the vehicle needed to get the bikes to the dirt, which, in my case, was $6,000 for a used Ford F-150. My daily driver is an all-electric Nissan Leaf that can’t travel the distance needed to get to an off-road vehicle area—or tow, for that matter. If you don’t have a truck but do have a vehicle that can tow, you’ll need a trailer. That will cost a minimum of $1,000, unless you want one that’s juryrigged from plywood, in which case you can get one for $200 on Craigslist.
Yes, there are special dirt bike socks, and they’re worth every penny. Hell hath no fury like a mom with chafed shins.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: Finally, there’s all the gear. Dirt biking is even more gear intensive than street biking. Embracing the mantra “expect the best, prepare for the worst” will set you back another $500 per person—at least—between the helmet, goggles, chest protector, knee pads, elbow pads, gloves, boots, jersey, pants and, uh, socks. Yes, there are special dirt bike socks, and they’re worth every penny. Hell hath no fury like a mom with chafed shins.

4. Determine the best bike for the job. It used to be that children’s dirt bikes were snorting, torquey two-strokes that could only be brought to life with a kick start. These days, most modern dirt bikes for children are more user-friendly four-strokes, but they’re still carbureted, rather than fuel injected. Some even have electric, or push-button, starts like modern street bikes.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: 5. Figure out your own level of resolve. Do you know enough about motorcycles, mechanically, to get yourself out of a pinch? Do you know how to read a map? While your kid is getting accustomed to the new reality of being out in the middle of nowhere on a new kind of bike (one with a motor), it’s inevitable that you, dear parent, will be the one in charge of the bike’s operation. Rest assured, there will be wipeouts that flood the carburetor and rocks that embed themselves in the drive chain preventing the back wheel from spinning. It’s on you to know your stuff mechanically to be able to get yourself out of these oh-so-common messes when the nearest civilization is miles away.

Knowing that my boy was going to be starting and stopping his bike a lot, I opted to buy a brand-new 2014 Honda CRF125FE with an electric start, so he wouldn’t get tired from constantly kick starting.  Dirt biking over sandy, rocky trails is exhausting enough. I purchased a dual sport model capable of riding in the dirt as well as on the street for myself, because I wanted the versatility of also using the bike for commuting. These on- and off-road capable bikes are available in displacements as large as 1,200, but I opted for a 2014 Honda CRF250L because it’s large enough to travel on the freeway and light enough that I can pick it up on my own. In the dirt, it isn’t a matter of “if” you’re going to dump it but “when” and “how.”

promoTeaser: 5 things to think about when you think about replacing your tires.
metaDescription: 5 Rules of Tire Shopping: Things to think about when you think about replacing your tires. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: On the list of fun shopping excursions, buying new tires rates pretty low. Yet, every year our trusty tires transport an average of three tons of vehicle upward of 20,000 miles, making those four rubber circles key players in our personal safety. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reports, “More than 11,000 tow-away crashes occur every year related to tire issues.” It can be tempting to let those aging tires roll on a few more months, but if yours are showing signs of wear, it’s time to go shopping. You can narrow down your search using online tools like Tire Rack's Tire Decision Guide. Here are five things to think about when shopping for new tires.

1. Know when it's time for a change. Keep an eye out for worn tread (if you see the threadlike wear indicators emerging on a tread, it’s definitely time for a change). You can use a penny or a quarter to do the time-honored tread depth check. Look for bulges in the sidewalls, but also pay attention to how the car drives. New road noise, the car pulling to one side, or a vibration in the steering wheel could all be signs that your tires are past their prime. Tiffane Thompson, a Michelin spokesperson, recommends rotating your tires about every 6,000 miles. That’s also the ideal time to have your service person give them a thorough inspection.

2. Know your type. There are many variations on the tire theme beginning with three basic categories. All-season tires, the little black dress of the tire world, are suited to a variety of driver demands. Built for longevity, they go from dry to wet to snow, all while keeping the ride quiet and the handing sufficient in most conditions. Winter tires have a unique tread that notches or bites into the snow and ice for better traction, but on clear roads, grip can suffer. Performance tires are designed for drivers who toss their cars through the corners expecting superior grip and handling in wet or dry conditions. The downside to racy performance is a softer tread that will wear more quickly and a ride you might feel in your backside.

3. Consider your climate. Thompson says all season tires will likely do the job year round for those of us in sections of the country with moderately cold seasons and snowfall. For dwellers in the great white north where severe winters and consistently frigid temps are the norm, she urges, “There is no substitute for winter tire usage for safe mobility.” If serious rainfall is your main weather challenge, seek out tires with a tread designed to maximize water evacuation for a reliable wet grip.

4. Make lifestyle choices. If you are focused on efficiency and reducing carbon emissions in other areas of your life, you might consider eco-friendly tires. They are constructed for low rolling resistance to boost fuel economy and sustainable manufacturing, putting less CO2 into the atmosphere. Some of the brand names are Michelin HydroEdge with Green X, Continental ProContact with EcoPlus Technology, Goodyear Assurance Fuel Max, and Kumho eco Solus HM KR22. Originally created for use on hybrid and other "green" vehicles, they are increasingly available for a range of vehicles.

5. Take the long view. No matter what tires you chose remember to ask detailed questions about the warranty. How many miles does it cover, and what, such as improper maintenance, could potentially void it? Some tire stores and manufacturers offer road hazard warranties, generally at extra cost, which may appeal to you for peace of mind. Thompson stresses the importance of maintenance as well. “To prolong tire life, try to avoid hard stops and starts…keep your car in alignment, and maintain proper tire pressure.”
So evaluate your driving needs, grab your wallet and go shopping for best quality tire you can afford.  Your most precious cargo is riding on this purchase.

Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Price: $33,425 base price (including destination), $41,075 as tested (including destination)
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 241 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed Steptronic automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/33 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: The turbocharged four-cylinder engine
Option I can’t live without: The entire Ultimate package ($6,150), especially the moonroof and the power front seats
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth connectivity, halogen fog lights, roof rails, leather-wrapped steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Cold weather package ($700) includes heated steering wheel and front seats, retractable headlight washers; Ultimate package ($6,150) includes Homelink, keyless entry and ignition, rearview camera, panoramic moonroof, auto-dimming rearview mirror and exterior mirrors, power front seats with lumbar support, front and rear parking assist, navigation, SiriusXM satellite radio and traffic with one-year free subscription, BMW Online, BMW Apps
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Ford Escape, Mini Cooper Countryman, Volkswagen Tiguan

America is smitten with sport-utility vehicles of every size. The Lilliputian BMW X1 was introduced to the U.S. market in 2013 and sold a respectable 26,000 vehicles in its first year. Although it shares a platform with the previous-generation 3-series wagon, BMW calls it a sports activity vehicle (SAV). Some would argue that it is actually a tall sedan with a smidge of extra ground clearance.

Semantics aside, this new niche of ultra-small luxury-utility vehicles is about to get a lot more competitive come 2015, when the Mercedes-Benz GLA, Audi Q3, Lexus NX, and Infiniti Q30 will all be vying for leadership in this segment.

I recently spent time in the 2014 BMW X1 xDrive 28i. The x in xDrive denotes all-wheel drive. As the 1 designation indicates, this BMW is indeed small. To give you an idea of scale, it is slightly larger than the Mini Cooper Countryman and slightly smaller than the Buick Encore. Although it does seat five, I recommend that, for long road trips at least, two of the passengers should be the type of humans who are not tall enough to ride the big roller coasters. And if you do ferry five for vacation, you may want to consider taking advantage of the roof rails to add extra storage.
The hybrid car/SUV look will attract the design-conscious buyer who is averse to bulky SUVs but can appreciate a hatch design.

The X1 is good-looking from every angle. It is especially stunning in this Midnight Blue metallic, which showcases the character lines that give the X1 its BMWness. The hybrid car/SUV look will attract the design-conscious buyer who is averse to bulky SUVs but can appreciate a hatch design. For those who pine for the kidney-bean grille in a sport-utility but want to keep below $40,000, this may be for you. That's especially true if your nest is empty or your birds are still young. Urban buyers will love the smaller footprint that will allow them to squeeze into tight parking spots.

The X1 is available in three variants. The xDrive 28i and the rear-wheel-drive sDrive 28i both have a 241-horsepower turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine with an eight-speed transmission. The xDrive 35i has a 300-hp turbocharged 3.0-liter inline six-cylinder engine with a six-speed transmission. The smaller engine has a manual mode to up the fun quotient, but there is no true manual transmission offered—which, to many BMW aficionados, is a deal breaker. Living in Michigan, I lean toward the all-wheel drive, but for a good portion of the country it is unnecessary since this vehicle will most likely not be leaving the pavement.

If you are new to BMW, you will need a moment to adjust to the Steptronic transmission. There are three modes; sport, manual, and standard. But for me the odd part is the shifter itself. To select Park, you push a button on the top of the shifter, and to disengage you need to push a button on the left of the shifter. Then you can move between Drive, Reverse, and Neutral. Pushing the shifter to the right at any speed selects sport mode—best used for times when you want a burst of speed. But for the most fun driving, pushing the shifter to the left will put you in the manual mode.

All the variants come standard with Auto Start Stop, which switches off the engine when the vehicle stops temporarily and thus helps fuel economy. Keep in mind that if you opt for the larger, more powerful engine, your mpg will drop from 22 city/33 highway to 18 city/27 highway, and the mileage isn’t impressive in either case.

Once inside the cabin, it is a cozy fit. The additional headroom is welcome and reminds you that you are indeed in a sport-utility vehicle. But since the X1 sits lower than most, the driver’s position is very carlike. BMW has added a removable cupholder—that protrudes rudely into the front passenger's already tight quarters—for cupholder-crazed Americans. We promptly removed it and stored it in the glove compartment. As I mentioned before, the rear seat will be most comfortable for junior passengers, but they will be happy that the seats do recline. But the X1 truly shines when you fold the seats down and treat the cargo area like a true hatch.

The 2014 BMW X1 comes standard with automatic climate control, rain-sensing windshield wipers, an eight-speaker stereo, Bluetooth, HD radio, a USB port, and BMW’s iDrive infotainment system. The interior materials seem more utilitarian than luxurious. Even the infotainment seems a little behind the curve, especially if you don’t add on a package that offers satellite and navigation.

Our X1 had the cold weather package for $700. It included a heated steering wheel and front seats, as well as lovely headlight washers. Most Americans don’t appreciate the beauty of this option, but I do—especially during the sloppy spring we are experiencing this year.

We also opted to go all out and upgrade to the Ultimate package for a whopping $6,150. That is a lot of cheddar, but that cheese buys amenities that most luxury buyers demand, such as keyless entry, a rearview camera, power front seats, a navigation system, voice command, satellite radio, real-time traffic, and a panoramic moonroof, to name a few. The entry fee is worth the price just for the additional light the moonroof adds to the cabin.
The X1 handles very much like its BMW sedan/coupe kin, with enhanced visibility provided by the added height.

If you prefer a more carlike sport-utility vehicle, the X1 is here to please. The X1 handles very much like its BMW sedan/coupe kin, with enhanced visibility provided by the added height. It delivers plenty of power and can provide the punch for easy highway passing, although I did feel a slight lag. The turbo is a bit loud, and it pinged a bit rather than growled when the turbo is spooling up. The steering is tight and responsive and will feel like home to the BMW faithful.

The Verdict:

Once we tweaked our X1, it priced out at $41,075 for the pint-size sport-ute. That is a hefty price tag for a vehicle that doesn’t feel all that luxurious. And if you need a gas sipper, this nugget should fall off your list as well. If you are looking for the ultimate driving machine, you will need to look elsewhere, but first-time BMW owners may be dazzled by the Bimmer roundel. And for those who seek a hot hatch, it is worth a test drive. But I think I would wait a year and take a spin in all the new luxury contenders before I plunk down my hard-earned cash for the X1.

Peanut Gallery:

Scott Allen: My only complaints are minor quality-of-life things. I don't like that the radio stays on even after you get out of the car, until you lock the door from the outside. I thought the cupholder was in the way in the passenger's seat, but I guess they knew that, because it's nice you can remove it. As I said, very minor. I appreciated how easily I could see around the car with no blind spots. When it comes to driving, there is nothing wrong there!

Laura Sky Brown: In my youth, I once spent a few weeks living in a convent (only as a visitor!). My room was a tiny "cell" on the same corridor as the nuns. It had only a plain desk, chair, and narrow single bed that all fit tightly against the walls, and there was only one simple religious painting for decoration. Everything, in short, was set up to provide minimal distraction and maximum focus on the work of religious life.

I mention this because the interior of the BMW X1 is as plain as a nun's cell. Simple black leather and hard black plastic; stiff, narrow seats; nothing to distract you from the driving experience. You might say to yourself, "Why should I get excited about sitting in this unadorned, uninteresting, not really all that comfortable passenger cell?" And then you accelerate to pass, and it all begins to make sense.

Molly pointed out that people buy this car because of the snob value of the BMW badge. I know they do, and in a bit of reverse snobbery, I would hesitate before owning one myself for that reason. But dig a little deeper, and you remember the reason the badge has that kind of clout: it's all about the driving experience. If you want luxury touches and soft surfaces, there are lots of other crossovers and small SUVs to shop for instead.

contributors.bio:
My return to the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee during the Reagan era for a second bachelor’s degree accomplished two things: I made writing for a car magazine a career goal, and I met my future wife, though it took Donna two decades to come around to the latter idea. Over that quarter-century, I went on to write general assignment stories for the Milwaukee Sentinel, became a cop reporter, then schools reporter and film critic for the Quad-City Times, where I also covered Cary Grant’s death in Davenport, Iowa, and then I worked for the San Diego Business Journal, where I became an expert on the arcane America’s Cup Deed of Gift. When I moved to Washington, D.C., where I wrote about the Clinton health care reform plan and other Capitol Hill issues for an inside-the-beltway newsletter publisher, I thought I had found my true calling. Matt DeLorenzo convinced me otherwise, and I moved to Detroit in 1996 to work for AutoWeek. Four years later, Jack Keebler lured me to Motor Trend, where I wrote news and rumors about future cars, voted in a dozen (each) Car of the Year and Sport/Utility of the Year competitions, and blogged as the Motor City Blogman. Detroit is to the global auto industry what Washington is to national politics. It’s easily more fascinating and as frustrating to cover as a journalist. The commute is far more interesting.

My years at Motor Trend, working side-by-side with Technical Director Frank Markus, have been enormously fulfilling. I’ve become fully immersed in the nuts and bolts of cars, and the industry. You have to keep a love for cars and driving in perspective. For me, Donna, our two collies, and my family back in Wisconsin come first. I can be nearly as passionate about politics, movies and art, and the Green Bay Packers, of which I’m a shareholder. My favorite sport is still Formula 1, though.

Automobile is about living with cars, both the good ones and the bad ones, but most importantly, the most interesting ones. With autonomous cars on the near horizon, we face the greatest threat to our enthusiasm since the malaise and oil embargoes of the ‘70s, the era when I earned my driver’s license. With Jean, Joe and their crew, Automobile already has the best, most interesting writers to explain why you should put down that mobile phone and grab the steering wheel. I’m thrilled to become part of this team and I look forward to helping place the cars and the way we drive them in context.

pageElements.text: You may remember “Mister K” and his “dogs love trucks” commercials for the Nissan Frontier pickup some sixteen years ago. Proving that Nissan loves dogs, its North American public relations department has teamed up with a Detroit organization that delivers dog food and advocates for better treatment of pets in the city’s neediest neighborhoods.

Dog Aide Community Awareness delivers food to dog owners who can’t afford it. When they deliver the food, the group’s co-founders, Jen and Beth, or their volunteers offer free spaying and neutering services and help set up routine veterinary care and rescue outreach. It's all part of an effort to improve living conditions for the pets.

Although the organization has been around for a couple of years, the issue of pet well-being has made headlines, with news reports estimating as many as 50,000 loose dogs roaming the city of Detroit. The actual number is much lower than that: anywhere from 7,500 dogs to a low-five-figure number, according to more rational estimates.

In March, Nissan North America’s public relations department invited auto journalists to ride along with Jen and Beth as they delivered bags of Blue Buffalo natural  dog food to needy families in Detroit. My wife, Donna, and I joined Jen and Beth and visited seven households, delivering high-quality Blue Buffalo natural dog food and checking up on the pets. A man who lives across the street from a park where many unwanted pets are dropped off offered to volunteer himself.

Dog Aide is doing good work. It partners with other volunteer groups to do the kind of work the bankrupt city’s animal control department can’t perform. Nissan has also partnered with The Devoted Barn, which rehabilitates a variety of neglected animals and shares the animals with at-risk youth in Southeast Detroit.
Here's that old Nissan ad, just for fun.

As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program. pageElements.text: We've been thinking for a while about ways to keep our dogs safe while riding in cars.  Restraining your dog in the car not only keeps him safe in the event of a collision but also prevents him from being the furry distraction that may cause a crash.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Y6p9-A2zRNo?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It was exciting last fall when the Center for Pet Safety, sponsored by Subaru, did formal safety testing of several dog harnesses on the market. The only one to emerge with the Top Performer label was the Clickit Three-Point Dog Harness, by Sleepypod. And that's the harness we're testing in this video. (See the complete Center for Pet Safety test results here.)

The harness costs $89.99, comes in three colors (orange, red, and black), and is available from Sleepypod's website. It comes with three adjustable components: the Y-shaped vest that your dog wears and two tethers that secure the dog to your car’s LATCH child safety restraint anchors.

An important reminder: Measuring your dog per Sleepypod's online size guide is essential. We tried to fit the harness on Molly's ten-pound Bizee and found that even size XS hung way down off her scrawny frame, before discovering the harnesses are designed for dogs who weigh eighteen pounds and up.

For really small dogs (like Bizee), Sleepypod's Air carrier ($159.99, in a range of colors), like the one shown in the video, will strap into the car; it also fits under an airline seat. Sleepypod also makes the pet bed for which the company is named, which zips open on top, straps into the car, and looks adorable. It would also work well for a cat. These come in even more designer colors, including Dark Chocolate and Blossom Pink, and cost $179.99.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.
