title: My Stolen Car
subTitle: My parents bought me a car off Craigslist. Here's what happened next. Don't let it happen to you.
promoTeaserSmall: My parents bought me a car off Craigslist. Here's what happened next. Don't let it happen to you.
promoTeaser: My parents bought me a car off Craigslist. Here's what happened next. Don't let it happen to you.
metaKeywords: buying a car from an individual
metaDescription: My Stolen Car: My parents bought me a car off Craigslist. Here's what happened next. Don't let it happen to you. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: On January 3, 2014, the night of my twenty-second birthday, I was sold a lie. I'm a philosophy major, so I overanalyze just about everything and everyone I come across. Like most, though, I allow my desires to blind my judgment. Especially when the object of my desire is as shiny as a new car.

The 1998 Bonneville I was driving, before the 2004 Jeep Liberty featured in this story, was in shambles.  Both rear struts were broken, making the ride to Wayne State University in Detroit pretty bumpy. I'm a waitress and an undergraduate student, so money is spent on necessities and vices, leaving little room for repairs and new cars. My mother and her husband saved me on this one.

I found a Jeep listed on Craigslist. It was listed for sale by a guy who said his name was Scott Tooth. On the night of my birthday, my mother’s husband and I met him in a parking lot to look at the Jeep. It was a public parking lot that he had selected, and he only let me test drive inside the parking lot, not out on the street. He looked me in the eyes, smiled, wished me a happy birthday, admired my mother’s accent, and so on, all after explaining the story of the car.

According to him: "My sister just wants to get rid of it. She just got a job and moved to Chicago, so she doesn't need it. She's giving me some money to sell it.  It’s a great car. My dad is a mechanic so it's in good shape. I don't want to take it on any main roads because the tags are expired." Everything seemed to make sense, but I wasn't thinking because I wanted that Jeep more than anything at that moment.

He took my deposit, $100, and we purchased the car the next day. Cash.  I was in love with the car and the feeling of security. I had never before been the owner of a nice car, nor the owner of a reliable one.

I drove my new Jeep to the Secretary of State office two days in a row to register the vehicle. Because of weather, both days it was closed, as was my university. I work four to five days a week, and I'm going to school four days a week. My hours and those of the SOS branches are not compatible. In that way, two months went by.
Eventually, on March 5, a class was canceled, I had time, and I went to go make my car legal. After waiting an hour and a half, I was told I had a fake title and a stolen car in my possession.
I puked. Then I drove to the police station and gave up the car that had never been mine.

I cried because I learned that I was driving someone else's car that had been taken at gunpoint. I cried because I lost my only asset. I cried because the money used to buy the car wasn't mine. I cried over the lack of humanity. I felt guilty and sad.
But anger was the dominant emotion. The following three nights, I dreamed of murdering the boy who sold me the Jeep.
Dramatic? Maybe. But I was sold a stolen car by a person who was clearly lacking empathy, and I could not help struggling with questions of morality and existence.
Lying is a two-way street. There is the liar and the believer. Beware of those who do not smile with their eyes.
Lying is a two-way street. There is the liar and the believer. Beware of those who do not smile with their eyes.
To Scott Tooth and the men that took the car at gunpoint: I promise that I will not be the victim the next time we meet.  I hope guilt eats you alive, if it ever finds you.

Upon walking through the first set of Waterford Police Department doors, I was buzzed in to the station where I would have to leave the Jeep. I said to the police officer, "It seems I've bought a stolen car." I told him the story of my encounter at the Secretary of State while he checked details regarding the Jeep. He guessed right away that I had found the car via Craigslist. The two officers guiding us through the process were of good humor. They teased and joked, giving a light touch to the stiff situation to the point where I almost enjoyed it. They could not find any details of the man who had sold me the Jeep. They had us fill out an incident report, asked us questions, and sent the case to a detective, who later answered some questions that the police could not.

The legal owner of the Jeep was a man who had been in the hospital at the time of the jacking. His roommate had been using the Jeep, which had no insurance.  Since the car had been bought on a bank loan and stolen while uninsured, the car technically belongs to the bank, the detective explained.  I have no contact with the legal owner, nor do I have contact with the bank that has the lien on the car.  The investigation is still ongoing, but I have been promised answers once they surface.

My friend Caylan and her husband, expecting parents, were selling one of their cars, a Chevrolet Blazer (the one I'm in at the top of this page). They gave me a wonderful deal on the car and had it to me before spring break ran its course, allowing me to continue my semester without interruption.

So, are you thinking of buying a car from Craigslist? Before any money changes hands, call in the VIN to your local police station. Another suggestion: meet the seller at a Secretary of State branch, not in some random parking lot.

title: Tour through Texas by (GMC) Terrain
subTitle: How to plan a great road trip using only apps and online resources. Look what I found on day 1!

metaDescription: Tour through Texas: I relied on apps and online resources to plan a 1,300-mile road trip. Here's day 1: Crossing Texas. Read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
If you read A Teenager's First Road Trip last week, you know that I'm a high school junior and I was just given the privilege of being put in charge of planning a cross-country road trip with my mom. We're on that trip now, and here's how it's going:

Before beginning the 1,300-mile drive from Austin, Texas, to Ann Arbor, Michigan, my mom and I first spent the weekend in Austin with my aunt and uncle. We had picked up a brand-new 2014 GMC Terrain for our cushy ride. It proved to blend in well with all the other sport-utility vehicles and trucks in this trendy Texas town. As my aunt and uncle showed us their town, I paid attention to the differences in Texas driving from what I have experienced back home.

First of all, the traffic lights here are horizontal, rather than vertical. To me, this seemed outrageous and slightly mind-boggling. The next strange thing was the yield lane for turning right. Instead of having to stop at the light there is a separate lane to the far right where drivers slow down and then yield as they merge into traffic. In Michigan, you can turn right on red but you need to make a complete stop first. It seemed like this Texas turn worked to keep traffic moving.

The drivers in Texas are very courteous and actually follow the speed limit. I was shocked that people would not tailgate you on the highway to intimidate you to get out of their way. But the big surprise was the terrible traffic—apparently, Austin is ranked in the top five worst cities in the U.S. for traffic. To make the situation worse, there is road construction everywhere. Seriously, the entire time we drove around the city we could see signs of construction. The roads are in perfect condition, unlike the potholed streets that I have been learning to drive on at home.

These subtle differences are slightly unsettling. Add that to the fact that the entire route is brand-new to us, and we would need to follow the on-board navigator the entire time. I realized that it was important to pay extra special attention to road signs since we would not be familiar with the laws of the road in all of the states we would be driving through. But since I am riding shotgun for this trip, I can help my mom read signs and navigate through tricky situations.
The Terrain's center console was so deep that I was able to store our candy, chargers, camera, and even a small emergency kit inside with plenty of room left over.

The night before we left Austin, I organized the Terrain's cabin so that everything we needed was at our fingertips. The center console was so deep that I was able to store our candy, chargers, camera, and even a small emergency kit inside with plenty of room left over. I easily paired our phones via Bluetooth, which would let me be the DJ for the trip. My final job before we went to bed was to put the address for our first stop—Inner Space Cavern—into the navigation system. I was able to do it without having to look at the manual, which I bet few owners ever crack open.

Georgetown, Texas, and the Inner Space Cavern

This is the shortest day of our six-day adventure. The final destination was a room I booked through Airbnb in Dallas, but we first stopped to take a tour of the Inner Space Cavern in Georgetown just north of Austin. I found this attraction, as well as our other stops, on Roadtrippers.com.

What is the Inner Space Cavern? you ask. In 1963, the Texas Highway Department was drilling core samples to determine if the ground was stable enough to support a highway overpass over I-35. While they were drilling one of the test holes, the bit suddenly fell twenty-six feet, and that's how the cavern was discovered. The gift shop and ticket office looked like they were straight out of the Sixties, but once underground I was impressed. The tour guide was funny and informative. The tour took us on a one-mile loop, and at the very bottom we were more than seventy feet underground, and it was close to eighty degrees. Definitely worth the time and the $19.95-per-person fee. There is also a three-to-four-hour wild tour where you crawl through tiny spaces with only a light on a hard hat—no thank you.

As we continued on toward Dallas, we noticed how much Texans love their flag. We Michiganders may be smitten with the mitten, but the lone-star state has a love affair with the star. It is embossed on their new overpass stanchions, and it does look impressive. In fact, all of the Texas roads so far have been smooth and in near-perfect condition.

We made a quick stop at a rest area, and it not only had a playground but a storm shelter, which could be very helpful since we were driving through Tornado Alley. My mom had reminded me the night before we left to check the weather so that we wouldn’t have any surprises along the way.

As we drove toward Dallas, the speed limit was 75 mph, which allowed us to make great progress without breaking the law. Apparently there are also roads in Texas where the speed limit is as high as 85. My mom complained that the A-pillar was blocking her view, as she pointed out to me the part of the car where the roof attaches to the hood. I agreed that it did create a blind spot.

We listened to music via Pandora on my phone, played a whodunit game, and talked about college and my dream of getting a car of my own. The nav took us right to the door of the room we reserved through airbnb. It was located in a neighborhood that was slightly sketchy, and I realized that I should have explored the neighborhood with Google Earth. If I had, I probably would have passed on this spot. The neighborhood made me nervous, but since I was with my mom, I was okay. It was actually a cabin in the back yard of an art gallery that was super cute and artsy. We met the owner, Wanda, and she told us she had lived in the neighborhood for four years. Her calm demeanor put us at ease. But we did pull the car up into the empty yard next to the house to reduce the chance of bringing attention to the shiny new GMC.

A Perfect Little Park in Dallas

Once we unloaded our gear into our little cabin, we scheduled a ride through the Uber app to take us to Klyde Warren Park. It is a 5.2-acre park that is actually built over the highway. If I lived in Dallas, I think I would love to hang out in this park. It had an outside reading room that supplied books and magazines to read while in the park. There were games available such as ping-pong, foosball, and croquet, and there was even a putting green. It also had areas for dogs, fountains to play in, and a play area for kids. Shockingly, there were not many people in the park. After a few appetizers in an ultra-trendy restaurant called Savor, we took the Uber ride back to our cabin in the city and dead-bolted the door and hit the hay. In the morning, we're on our way to Hot Springs, Arkansas. More later!

pageElements.text:
Jean Knows Cars shares a building (not to mention an editor in chief) with Automobile Magazine, and, in addition to the mental stimulation of working together, we enjoy our proximity to the luscious test fleet of cars that are always close by. Automobile Magazine is temporarily without a motor gopher on staff: the person whose job it is to keep those cars clean inside and out. So they took advantage of a bright spring day to make the cleaning into a group event. I took advantage of having thirteen of them all in one place at one time and asked them for their favorite car-care tips. And here they are.

Photos by Scott Allen
Jen Misaros (Managing Editor, Digital Platforms) (vacuuming): I swear I just sucked up toenails. Gross.
My tip is, if the inside of a vehicle is really dirty, use a leaf blower. Open the doors on both sides, and blow it out. It saves you tons of time.

Rusty Blackwell (Copy Editor): Use a separate sponge to wash the wheels from the one you use to wash the painted surfaces. Wheels have all kinds of crap, brake dust, dirt, that you don't want scratching your paint. At home, when I buy a new sponge, the old one gets demoted to wheel washing.

Avoid washing a car in full sun, or you'll get water marks. And certainly never wax in full sunlight. The wax will bake on and won't come off as easily. And don't wash a car on a dirt driveway—you'll soon have mud that'll splash up and get the lower parts of the car all dirty.
Amy Skogstrom (Managing Editor): I have a chamois mitten that I use at home instead of a sponge. It gives me better control.

Joseph Capparella (Associate Web Editor): I use Q-Tips to clean out the smaller nooks and crannies in a car. I went a little crazy with the cleaning when my dad gave me his old Honda Fit. He hadn't treated it that carefully and I spent half a day getting it perfect.

Joseph DeMatio (Deputy Editor): My poor man's carpet cleaning system is to remove the paper filter from a Shop-Vac, clean all the dirt out of it, and then soak the carpeting and vacuum up the water using the Shop-Vac.
Eric Weiner (Associate Web Editor): I use a stiff-haired brush right alongside a vacuum to gather loose stuff in the carpet and vents and vacuum it up immediately.
Jake Holmes (Associate Web Editor): Pull the rubber liners out of cup holders and cubbies and clean them separately. The soap and water will pool up when you try to wash them in place.

Another simple thing I do is to clean the windshield wipers. Run a towel over the wiper blade itself, and you'll see a trail of dirt come off. Then wipe away at the glass where the wiper rests when it's stationary. That will keep the wipers working better for longer, and it reduces streaking or juddering.
Sandon Voelker (Videographer): If it's kind of cold out, fill your bucket with warm water. You'll function better when your hands aren't numb.

Thomas Hang (Graphic Designer): A lot of people tend to throw things into the back seat and leave them there. Clear out the back every day. It's a good habit to get into. I keep my car cleaned out as I go, and I rarely have to do a major cleaning.

Chris Nelson (Road Test Editor): Preventive is the way to go. The reality is that your car will only get dirty if you let it. Of course, if I kept to that at home, I wouldn't have to spend Sundays cleaning out my condo. If you keep it clean, it's easier to see when it gets trashed and takes only a small amount of time to clean.

David Zenlea (Associate Editor): Don't fill the bucket up all the way. That just wastes water and dilutes the soap. Instead, fill about halfway. If the car is really big and/or really dirty, consider emptying and refilling the bucket partway through.

When you rinse off the soap, consider removing the hose nozzle. The straight stream of water removes the soap much more effectively and without as much overspray. It's then easier to dry (it's exactly the same as when you rinse dishes in the sink).
Jackie Guenther (Executive Assistant): Go to an automatic car wash! That's my tip.
That, and get some high-quality floor mats like the WeatherTech custom-fit mats in this car. Your car automatically looks and feels much cleaner.
Todd Lassa (Executive Editor): My first tip is, marry someone who likes small cars (Mazda 2 and Miata, for example), so you have less sheetmetal to wash.

More seriously, I always use a liquid car wash soap. My father believed it stripped off the wax, but I'm sure it does the opposite, which is to protect the wax. Waxing is best twice a year, at the beginning of spring, when it's rainy, and early fall. A good wax job assures that water beads and snow/ice slide off the sheetmetal more easily.

Also, be sure to open the doors and clean out the inside of the rocker panels and the doorjambs with a wet cloth. Too many people clean the exterior sheetmetal and the seats, while skipping this part, so when you open the doors, you have this line of dirt between the two.
I'm just glad I don't have to clean whitewalls anymore.

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pageElements.text: Growing up in Connecticut as a talented equestrian and polo player, Lore Smith would gallop her horse as fast as she could.  “That’s why I like to race cars.  I see a connection there,” she says.

"How fast can your car go?" I ask her as we soar and roar, though at a legal speed and in great comfort, along beachside Ocean Drive from Palm Beach to Lake Worth, Florida. “It can go 220. I’ve driven at 180,” she replies with just a hint of speedster pride. “I was at a track in Sebring [the International Raceway in Florida], which has a lot of S curves, and you can see my car has paddle shifters so you can put it in auto for driving around or you can put it in manual to go on the track. I went 180 on that track, and that was a lot of fun!”

Lore’s car is astonishingly beautiful.  It is a Ferrari after all, a 2010 Ferrari California in Blu Pozzi, an elegant navy blue, with a luxurious camel-colored leather-lined interior and blue seatbelts and carpets. “I wanted to keep it understated,” she says with a laugh, as if a Ferrari could ever be understated.

Lore, a Palm Beach star real estate broker, is wearing rust suede Ferrari shoes with silver bows and carrying a Ferrari-made note pad: brand loyalty to the max. She demonstrates how to operate the quiet folding convertible hard top, which opens or closes in a mere fifteen seconds. ”A pretty good piece of engineering,” she notes.
She ordered the rear portion of her cabin as a plush luggage shelf rather than install the standard (that is, standard for a Ferrari California) two smallish additional seats.

I ask her how she shows her clients their future homes in a two-seater. “That’s the ten-million-dollar question,” she replies. “Or maybe it’s the 100-million-dollar question. Basically, I work with clients who are hedge manager types of people. It’s generally the men who look at the houses, and when they see something they want to invest in, they bring their wives and then meet me at the property. My husband has a Jaguar, which seats four comfortably. I find in real estate, nobody gives me any grief with this car.”
Are people ever surprised to see a woman driving a Ferrari?  “Yes.  I like that.  The surprise element.”

Are people ever surprised to see a woman driving a Ferrari? “Yes. I like that. The surprise element.” Lore, who handles luxury residential property transactions for Sotheby’s International in Palm Beach, has been cited on a list of the top 250 agents in the United States by the Wall Street Journal. She had originally been a second-grade teacher, but “I wanted longer vacations and longer lunch hours.” And she found she was "pretty good at selling real estate.”

Lore admits her Italian import was an impulse buy.  “Life is very short, and you might as well enjoy every second of it…I’ve always been a car person.“ Each year, the fabled Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach hosts the Cavallino Classic Concorso d’Eleganza, where hundreds of Ferraris and their owners line up on the manicured lawn to celebrate the formidable vehicles. It was at one such parade of cars that Lore fell for the California.  And now, since becoming a Ferrari owner, she is a participant in the five-day event every January in which various classic and exotic cars and car enthusiasts form a procession through nearby towns, take jaunts around a local raceway, join a Jet Reception at the Palm Beach Airport, and participate in further celebrations at Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago Club.

Prior to the Ferrari, Lore drove a Bentley Continental GTC. “I found the Bentley too heavy as an automobile, too hard to maneuver around.” Instead, the aluminum Ferrari feels light and frisky and sexy and agile. She has encountered no mechanical problems with her car, other than needing a single adjustment of the fluid for the retractable hard top. The 2010 California was the first Ferrari to have a seven-speed dual-clutch automated manual transmission. This front-engine, rear-wheel-drive car is powered by a 4.3-liter V-8 with 460 horsepower and 357 pound-feet of torque. Although not as expensive as some other Ferraris, the California’s sticker price is still in the $200,000 range. The fuel consumption is 13/19 mpg.

Lore and her husband, Tony, are passionate sailors who have chartered sailboats in such far-flung locales as Tonga, the Seychelles, Tahiti, Vietnam, Cambodia, New Caledonia, and Thailand.  I ask her to compare sailing a Ferrari to sailing around the world.  “Well, the Ferrari goes a lot faster than a sailboat!  As we’ve been traveling to Africa over the past four or five years, I would compare the Ferrari to a cheetah [like the one she's posing with here], one of the fastest animals to get from zero to sixty.“ Her Ferrari takes about four seconds.

Of our intoxicating but brief journey along the Gold Coast of Florida in Lore’s California dream car, she says, “I love this particular drive.  If I am stressed out, I pop in the car and take the top down and just drive….You can see how this can put you in an instantly happy mood.”
And of the storied marque that generates so much happiness, Lore Smith says, “The Ferrari is a work of art.”

pageElements.text: If you read A Teenager's First Road Trip last week, you know that I'm a high school junior and I was just given the privilege of being put in charge of planning a cross-country road trip with my mom. On Day 1, we left Austin, Texas, headed north. We've just finished Day 3 of that trip now, and here's how it's going:

Day 2: Dallas to Hot Springs, Arkansas

For the second day of our trip from Austin, Texas, to Ann Arbor, Michigan, we loaded our bags into the 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD. Since our hands were always full when we arrived at the car, we were happy that it came equipped with a power rear liftgate. Having survived a brutal Michigan winter, the temperature of nearly seventy degrees Fahrenheit made us opt for shorts, and of course we made sure the sunroof was fully exposed to get some Vitamin-D-replacing sunshine into the car.

In the bright sunshine, we noticed that the Dallas neighborhood where we'd stayed, in lodgings found on Airbnb, was showing signs of new life. Just down the street, the hammers were already pounding as we drove out of town at 9:00 a.m.

We were excited to get to Hot Springs, in the Ouachita Mountains. We had booked ourselves into The Springs Hotel and Spa. The spa part had us so excited that we had not planned any side trips, so that the pampering could begin. The sky was ominous as we worked our way up I-30. The road was thick with trucks and peppered with orange construction barrels. The GMC Terrain can be equipped to monitor both traffic and weather, which would have been really helpful for our drive. Again, I was awed by the smooth pavement and realized how embarrassing the Michigan roads are for our state. I could imagine someone making a spoof “Pure Michigan” ad about our roads.

We exited I-30 in Arkadelphia, Arkansas, and drove through twisty mountain roads. The excitement was building as we neared the town and drove past scenic lakes with islands in the distance. The miles ticked down on the nav screen as the clouds continued to brew overhead. As we started to drive through Hot Springs,  our enthusiasm started to plummet. It was not the quaint mountain town we had envisioned, but actually, we later discovered, had a population of 35,000. The part of town that we drove through was actually quiet, although run down. But we pushed on, remembering that our exciting spa awaited our arrival, and the therapeutic hot springs would revive us.
The miles ticked down on the nav screen as the clouds continued to brew overhead. As we started to drive through Hot Springs, our enthusiasm started to plummet.

Finally we started to see the bathhouses that we had seen online, and our spirits lifted. We pulled up to our spa hotel, parked around the back of the hotel in a grimy chain-link-lined parking lot, and walked around to the front door. The lobby had obviously seen better days, but we checked in and headed up to our room. The elevator was old and creaky, and my mind wandered to horror movies. We laughed and prayed that we wouldn’t get stuck between floors. We did not.

Once we opened the door to our room, the soundtrack to Psycho should have been playing in the background. Right in the middle of the carpet was a perfect burn in the shape of an iron, the smoke alarm was hanging off the wall, and the vents were so dirty that we feared what was living in the walls. But the cherry on top was a necklace sitting on the floor, in plain view. Yep, we ran out of that hotel faster than Scooby and the gang.

I was ready to get the hell out of Hot Springs, but my mom forced me to take a tour of a bathhouse. It is now part of the National Parks system. It was interesting, but also slightly creepy. She also insisted that we drive up to the Hot Springs Mountain Tower. Apparently baseball legends such as Babe Ruth trained on the trails and took advantage of the hot springs. It didn’t appear to me that much had changed since then. I finally convinced her to continue on to Little Rock.

And guess what? It did rock. Little Rock is not only the capital, but it is modern and clean. We checked into the Residence Inn right downtown. The room was like a mini apartment, with full-size appliances and granite counters. We quickly unloaded and walked right across the street and ate a fabulous meal at Dizzy’s Gypsy Bistro. We both ordered soup, but this was no ordinary soup: each bowl was made on the spot. Who knew soup could be gourmet? We waddled home, showered, and nestled down beneath our fluffy white down blankets.

Day 3: Little Rock to Memphis, Tennessee

As we drove into Little Rock we had seen museums, the Clinton Library, and the electric wires of the River Rail Trolley system. I surprised my mom with tickets to the trolley so that we could tour the town. We jumped on right in front of our hotel. It makes a loop through the downtown, and you can jump off wherever you want. We hopped off near a restaurant that we had read about—the Flying Fish. Its claim to fame is if you give them your Billy Bass, they will give you a basket of catfish. But gimmicks aside, the food was great.

We wandered through River Market Books & Gifts. It had mostly used books and crafts from local artists as well as a lunch counter. The shop was enchanting, and we could have spent the afternoon lost in the old books. But we also wanted to get to Memphis.

We headed out of Little Rock with the help of the nav system on I-40. The highway was packed with trucks, but we ticked off the miles solving whodunit stories and listening to Pandora. The side blind zone alert and lane departure warning assisted us as we worked our way north. The car was equipped with a rear-seat entertainment system, but my mom would not be pleased if I retreated to the rear seats. But perhaps tomorrow I can convince her to let me test the multi-flexible  sliding rear seat.
I believe my mom ignored fuel warning signs that had popped up in the infotainment screen. She needs one that says “Hey, lady, get gas now.”

My mom suddenly noticed our gas gauge was below empty. I believe she had ignored warning signs that had popped up in the infotainment screen. She needs one that says “Hey, Lady, get gas now.” Unfortunately for us, it was at the exact time the highway traffic came to an abrupt stop. My mom was really nervous, but we did make it to the gas station and filled our thirsty tank.

At this point we needed to find an alternate route, so we pushed the OnStar button and asked for assistance. The OnStar people pushed a turn-by-turn route into our vehicle, and we followed it right into Memphis. Strangely, the on-board map didn’t function properly, but the voice commands were correct. We used our iPhones to follow the map.
Priscilla Presley used to have her hair done at this restaurant. We ordered gelato to go, walked back, and promptly fell asleep in the town where Elvis slept.

We were a little worried as we pulled into Memphis that we were entering a rough neighborhood, but once we turned the street of our Airbnb house, we realized that it was a great area. It is in the Cooper-Young Historic District, and it is fantastic. We quickly unloaded and walked the block over to have a quick dinner at The Beauty Shop, where I ate my grilled corn beneath a vintage hair dryer. Apparently, Priscilla Presley used to have her hair done at this restaurant. We ordered gelato to go and walked the block back to our house and promptly fell asleep in the town where Elvis slept.

title: Mastering the Roundabout

metaDescription: Mastering the Roundabout: Hesitate no more! The rules to help you rule the traffic circle.  See them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Every day, drivers like you and me read signage successfully and exercise good judgment on the roads. So why are so many of us freaking out when we approach one of the multitude of roundabouts popping up all over the U.S.?

The roundabout is a smart traffic-calming method, generally involving a single island surrounded by two or more lanes of one-way traffic going counterclockwise. Without traffic lights, it’s up to drivers to find the right time to enter and exit in relation to the rest of the traffic.

Maybe you’ve had no trouble, so far, driving around a roundabout, yet you may still be harboring some resentment for this change in your driving world. Why do we need roundabouts anyway? According to the Michigan Department of Transportation, roundabouts are safer. They reduce speeds as well as potential “conflict points,” making crashes less severe. No traffic signals means about $5,000 a year less in maintenance costs for a single roundabout, as well as what many view as a more attractive and less cluttered road landscape. Perhaps most important, they keep cars moving, which translates to less time stuck at busy intersections.

As foreign as it seems, a roundabout is simply a different kind of intersection. Any circular anxiety you’re feeling can be remedied when you remember a few simple rules of roundabout etiquette: prepare, be aware, and calmly get out of there.

1. Prepare. Slow down as you get close to the roundabout. There’s a lot to look at: signs, lane markers, curved arrows. Determine the correct lane for your destination.
2. Yield before you go. Watch for pedestrians and bicycles, and figure out which lane you need to be in ahead of time.
3. Be aware. Look at what the traffic already in the circle is doing. Understand how close vehicles are to other entry points, and prepare to enter the roundabout when there is a gap in the traffic.
4. Get out of there. Stay in your lane, and don’t stop. Signal, then exit by peeling off and out of the roundabout to the right. If you miss your chance to exit, go around the circle again. Don’t ever change lanes, and don’t stop while you’re in the circle.

After all, drivers all over the world use roundabouts successfully and can handle them, so why can’t we?

pageElements.text:
2015 Honda Fit EX

Price: $16,315 (base model, including destination charge), $19,025 (EX, including destination charge)
Engine: Sixteen-valve 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 130 horsepower, 114 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Continuously variable transmission with Sport mode and paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 33 mpg city/41 mpg highway (base LX with CVT); 32 mpg city/38 mpg highway (EX with CVT)
My favorite standard feature: Expanded View driver’s mirror and multi-angle rearview camera
Option I can’t live without: Honda satellite-linked navigation system
Notable standard features on this model: Multi-angle rearview camera with dynamic guide lines, Honda LaneWatch lane departure warning, push-button start, power moonroof with tilt, intermittent rear wiper/washer, roofline spoiler, heated power side mirrors with integrated turn indicators, HondaLink telematics with Bluetooth streaming audio and Pandora compatibility, seven-inch information touchscreen, Bluetooth HandsFreeLink
Notable options: Honda satellite-linked navigation (on EX-L with Navigation), leather seating (on EX-L), six-speed manual transmission (on LX and EX, $800)
You might also be considering: Ford Fiesta, Hyundai Accent, Nissan Versa Note
Honda is one of several automakers who are stepping up their game year by year in the small-car stakes.

It’s a funny thing about cars in the subcompact category: you might think they are solely the choice of the young and unencumbered, or the person who can’t afford more of a car. Of course, there's always a strong cohort of buyers under thirty-five who like small cars or want to keep their purchase price down. But in addition, there is a growing population of genuine adults—empty nesters, the environmentally conscious, or just minimalists—who voluntarily choose a subcompact car and like it. Perhaps in response to this, Honda is one of several automakers who are stepping up their game year by year in the small-car stakes. So, if you are considering going (or staying) with a subcompact, how about this one?

It’s a good time to ask the question, because Honda has just revealed its all-new 2015 Fit. The Fit has been on the U.S. market since 2006. Honda skipped the 2014 model year to get this all-new, third-generation version out as a 2015, and it goes on sale April 14. I was one of the lucky ones to get behind the wheel just this week and take it for a long country drive. I will get to the point immediately and tell you that it exceeded my preconceived notion of how it would feel to drive, and how it would feel to try to fit people and things inside.

Sliding into the admittedly slimly padded seat, I actually found that it was comfortable, in a low-key way, and the Honda family feeling and look was reassuring. You know what I mean—that clean, crisp, shiny-happy look that appeals to so many Honda cultists. It’s there, even though Honda has added gewgaws to the Fit like "eco assist" lighting on the central instrument binnacle that turns green when you’re getting good gas mileage—such as when you take your foot off the gas entirely. I’d rather see hard numbers, thanks, which I watched on the touchscreen, but I’m sure some people will like it.
Pulling away from the curb, I felt immediately at ease, and not—as I have in some other very small cars—a bit vulnerable in traffic next to tall-boy SUVs and trucks.

This makes sense, because the new Honda Fit has an all-new engine, still a 1.5-liter four-cylinder, but now with 11 more horsepower at 130 hp and 7.5 percent more torque at 114 pound-feet. It also has a new continuously variable transmission. There are a lot of people who dislike CVTs, but most people ought to like this one, which is teamed on the EX and EX-L trim levels with a pair of paddle shifters mounted on the steering wheel. In accelerating from a stop, you do know you're not in the most powerful car on the market, but it almost sounds sporty, and getting up to cruising speed is not unpleasant. I didn't get to try the all-new six-speed manual transmission, available on entry-level LX and midrange EX models only, but you stick-shift people out there should give one a try before you make a decision. Automobile Magazine's reviewer, himself a Fit owner, called it "slick" and "satisfying." Choosing the manual also cuts the price of a Fit by $800, although the CVT-equipped models get about 3 mpg better fuel economy.

Fuel economy is an important part of the package for a car this size, and the Fit delivers, especially with the base LX equipped with the CVT: it achieves the Holy Grail of 41 mpg on the highway. You can also push a button to the left of the steering wheel, marked Econ, that will optimize powertrain operation for added fuel economy. I tried it, and it didn't cause any big dropoff in performance that I could detect.

How did it feel on the road? Picture yourself behind the wheel of this adorable, but undeniably small machine, heading out onto the pothole-ridden back roads of southeastern Michigan in early spring, and what would you expect? Pull over after a few miles and call the chiropractor? Actually, no. The ride was a little on the bumpy side on the worst stretches of pockmarked back road, but thanks to some judicious changes Honda made to both front and rear suspension to improve stability while reducing weight, it was kept to a minimum. At freeway speeds up to 80 mph, it felt smooth, stable, and competent.

Not totally trusting my own standards—possibly lowered by decades as a minivan driver—I checked with an older, wiser journalist, one whose store of technical knowledge is far, far greater than my own, and he called the ride “a bit flinty,” but he liked it, too.

What's really the news in the 2015 Fit, though, is what they've done to make the interior feel much bigger than a subcompact. Honda senior product planner Hiroaki Hamaya pulled out a vacation slide of his surfing outing, showing that he got a nine-foot longboard and two short boards into the back. That's thanks to the 60/40 split folding Magic Seat. Each side folds flat with an effortless flick of a switch, and there really is amazing space behind the front seats when they're folded: 52.7 cubic feet, compared with 38.3 cubic feet in the competing Nissan Versa Note. I opened the hatch and climbed in with the seats folded flat: Yes, I could lie down in the back without going diagonal. Keeping in mind that I'm 5'3", that's still impressive for a car this small. The front seats, too, fold all the way back, almost flat, in what the Honda people called Refresh mode "for relaxing." Not while you're driving, of course.

There are also 4.8 inches more rear legroom, even though Honda made the Fit 1.6 inches shorter in overall length with the new design. Testing that, I pushed the front passenger's seat all the way back and climbed in the second row behind it, and I had more than enough legroom to feel comfortable in the back seat. My co-driver, a solidly built 5'10" male, did not complain, either, when he tried it. My verdict is that this is a car that really would fit four adults, not in limousine style, but without making anyone feel terribly cramped. It's billed as a five-seater, and for kids or short hauls only, that could work. It also opens up possibilities for taking along your dog in a crate, making a massive Costco run, or even (shudder) helping people move, without that small-car feeling of limitation.

Even though the EX I drove had the sunroof, I didn't feel there was a compromise on headroom, which has been the case in several much pricier cars I've driven. You can see how much room Simone has in the photo at the end of this article.

New for 2015

Honda has increased the level of equipment at all trim levels on the 2015 Fit. The center storage console, when you fold up the armrest, is big enough to hold an iPad. There's a smartphone cubby to the left of the instrument panel. A USB port is found on EX and EX-L models. (On the entry-level LX model, according to LX owner Paul Carpenter, there's a USB port connected to the Aux input. "I removed the USB extension and simultaneously removed the Aux port, which is connected. Did not hurt anything; just pushed it back in. Now I put my left index finger over the Aux input when I remove the USB. Works fine." So your USB needs are met no matter which model you buy.) Anyone who drove an old-school subcompact (or is upgrading from one) will be happy to know that such items as cruise control, a tilting/telescoping steering wheel, cup holders, vanity mirrors, and power windows and doors are all standard even on the $16,315 base model. What's more, uplevel Fits now come with push-button start/stop, the app-based HondaLink platform, Siri Eyes Free integration, and SMS text messaging, with voice-recognition touchscreen navigation only on the top-of-the-line EX-L.

Instead of the previous base and Sport models, the 2015 Fit comes in LX, EX, EX-L, and EX-L with Navigation trim levels. Even on the base model, you get a standard multi-angle rearview camera, an expanded-view driver's mirror, cruise control, and a five-inch LCD screen. All models also have standard motion-adaptive electric power steering and vehicle stability assist with traction control. From EX on up, you get a standard sunroof, push-button start and stop, a seven-inch HondaLink touchscreen, and a LaneWatch expanded-view rearview camera. The EX-L adds leather seating and heated front seats and mirrors, and the EX-L with Navigation adds SiriusXM satellite radio and, obviously, navigation on the touchscreen system. Honda expects that 55 percent of buyers will go for the EX model and 35 percent for the entry-level LX, with only four percent choosing the top-end EX-L with Navigation.

Mystic Yellow, Perhaps?

The 2015 Fit overcomes one of my pet peeves about Japanese brands, that they have boring color choices. Eight colors are available, one more than in 2014. The black, silver, and red color choices carry over, but the other five are new, including pearlescent shades of Passion Berry, Mystic Yellow, and White Orchid, plus Modern Steel and Aegean Blue metallic shades. The black one I drove was attractive, but I really think small cars should wear bright, cheerful colors, don't you?

Honda is building the new Fit at a brand-new plant in Mexico, because North America is an important market for this car. A new small SUV is going to be built there, too, starting later this year.  They're targeting Fit sales of 70,000 plus. And I can see the reason for their optimism.

The Verdict:

A subcompact is not for everybody, but one that's this cute and capable is for a lot more people than you might think. If you want to spend $20,000 or less, get up to 41 mpg on the highway, and not feel like you're being penalized for it, the Fit is a strong contender. Even the base model deserves to be called a 2015, considering the amount of modern engineering it has on board. At the same time, this is still not a true family car, and you wouldn't want to drive three kids around in it all day long. But as for visibility, versatility, and looks? That's all there. And I will even go as far as to say I'd feel comfortable if any of the three kids themselves were to have this as a first car.

Peanut Gallery:

Simone Samano, Contributing Writer: In the past, while I appreciated the Fit’s brilliant capacity and gas mileage, I always felt the interior styling and features were lacking and the exterior was appealing but utilitarian. So I was pleasantly surprised by the cleaner, more upscale look and feel on the inside, with the standard upgrades like multi-angle rearview camera and Bluetooth in the 2015 version. The outside made me think of what would happen if a Fiesta hatchback and a Prius C married against their parents’ will, but I liked the sporty look, even if it wasn’t very Honda-like. And a big shout out for those new extended-width mirrors, plus extra kudos to Honda for keeping the windows ample, continuing the great visibility the Fit is known for.

The uplevel EX-L wooed me with its moonroof and large seven-inch touchscreen. I found it easy to use the steering wheel controls as well. Also neatly tucked on the steering wheel were new paddle shifters, a great help getting on the highway, although the plastic of the shifters felt a bit flimsy to the touch. To me this is really a city car, so when parallel parking, the tight turning radius came in handy, as did the “top view” of the multi-angle rearview camera. Sure, I felt some of the bumps and bounces in the potholed roads, but I would expect that in a car this size. The cabin was actually quieter, and roomier in the back, than I expected. In fact, I would say the whole car exceeded my expectations.

There's 4.8 inches more rear-seat legroom in the 2015 Honda Fit.
USB comes on EX and EX-L models of the 2015 Honda Fit, but everybody gets the cupholders and smartphone holder.
Seven-inch touchscreen is standard on EX and EX-L models.
Sunroof with sunshade (which can be closed manually) is standard on EX and EX-L models.
